Biopsy helps in definite differentiation between the two â€“ basal cell cancer has cells that resemble those at the base of the epidermal layer of the skin, whereas squamous cell cancer is made of cells that resemble the upper layer of epidermis. Squamous cell cancers can spread to distant organs, whereas basal cell cancers usually spread only locally.

Question: Which doctor should I consult to detect a rare disease?
Answer: There arenâ€™t specific experts in rare diseases, although it is best to consult an expert healthcare professional who has experience with a particular condition.

Question: If my baby has a rare disease, will it be evident at birth?
Answer: Not all rare diseases are diagnosed at birth. If the baby has some unusual symptoms or characteristics, they may be diagnosed within a few weeks or months. If you suspect anything unusual, check with your pediatrician who will recommend a newborn screening test.

Question: How will I know which specialist to consult if my child has a rare disease?
Answer: Usually, rare diseases are diagnosed by treating pediatricians or physicians. They will further recommend which specialist to consult for treatment of the rare disease. For example, if a child has hemophilia, the child will be treated by a hematologist.

Question: How can I get my child on to a clinical trial?
Answer: Usually, the treating specialist will be updated on the latest in clinical research and trials, and will be the best person to give you the information regarding participation. However, you may also do your own research and connect with specialists and researchers across the globe. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ is a registry of clinical trials conducted globally. Searching the database can bring you in touch with the trial coordinators.

Question: Which doctor should you consult for beauty parlor stroke syndrome?
Answer: You should consult your physician who will refer you to a neurologist.

Question: Can vertebrobasilar insufficiency be caused by any other conditions?
Answer: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency can be caused by any condition where you need to bend your head backward, like while sitting in a dentistâ€™s chair, star gazing or even doing yoga. Make sure that your neck feels comfortable in any of these positions and you will be safe.

Question: How common is beauty parlor stroke syndrome?
Answer: Beauty parlor stroke syndrome is quite rare, and has only been recognized in the past few decades. People with risk factors may be more susceptible to the condition. In several instances, it may go undetected since the doctor or the patient may not associate the symptoms with the beauty parlor treatment.

Question: If I am having repeated episodes of mucous sores with skin lesions who should I consult?
Answer: The general physician should be consulted for sores and history should be taken with regards to the time of occurrence and repeated occurrence of the sores; any symptoms associated with inflammation or ulceration in other organs should also be looked for. A complete systemic examination will help in concluding the diagnosis.

Question: Is Behcetâ€™s disease contagious?
Answer: This condition is not contagious, but a rare inflammatory disorder that is linked to HLA B51 gene.

Question: Which other autoimmune diseases cause inflammatory sores?
Answer: Other autoimmune diseases that have been associated with sores include:

Question: Which doctor should be consulted in Bell's palsy?
Answer: A neurologist and an ophthalmologist are the doctors who must be consulted for this condition.

Question: Is the condition reversible?
Answer: Yes. In most cases after a course of steroids, the symptoms subside although you will need to take precautions like covering your face to avoid exposure to cold.

Question: Is Bell's palsy fatal?
Answer: No, unless there is any underlying condition like trauma to the head or severe diabetes, the condition does not result in death.

Question: Will my children be affected?
Answer: That is difficult to say since only 4 percent seem to have inherited the condition although no specific link has been established.

Question: Will Bell's Palsy happen again?
Answer: In most instances, Bell's palsy affects an individual only once in their lifetime. It is however believed that about 1 in 10 people who have a Bell's palsy have a further episode sometime several years afterwards.

Question: Does Bell's palsy affect any other parts of the body?
Answer: No. Bell's palsy is a local problem confined to the facial nerve and facial muscles.

Question: How does spirituality affect your life?
Answer: You may feel a higher sense of purpose, peace, hope, and meaning. You may experience better confidence, self-esteem, and self-control. It can help you make sense of your experiences in life. When unwell, it can help you feel inner strength and result in faster recovery.

Question: Why is spirituality important in one''s life?
Answer: Healthy spirituality gives a sense of peace, wholeness and balance among the physical, emotional, social and spiritual aspects of our lives. However, for most people the path to such spirituality passes through struggles and suffering, and often includes experiences that are frightening and painful.

Question: How do you practice spirituality?
Answer: Spirituality includes your spiritual practices or spiritual disciplines, which may include prayer, meditation, chanting, breathing exercises and ceremonies or rituals. Spirituality and your spiritual life also include your daily interactions with other people.

Question: What is spirituality awakening?
Answer: Call it "nirvana"; call it "enlightenment"; call it "bliss"; a spiritual awakening begins the moment a person can step back and "awake" to their life with a new sense of being in this world.

Question: Does spirituality make you happy?
Answer: It also turns out that people who have religious or spiritual beliefs are happier than those who don't, no matter what their beliefs. It gives people a sense of meaning. It also gives them a social network.  Happy people are in better physical shape, healthier and heal faster.

Question: Who should I approach for assistance with my grief?
Answer: It is best to get in touch with a qualified psychologist or psychiatrist or a family counselor who will help you work through your grief. They will be able to give a patient ear and share your emotions during this turbulent phase in your life. With their help it is possible to cope and learn to adapt to life despite the loss.

Question: I am going through extreme mood swings and am unable to cope with day to day tasks. I also feel like weeping at most times. Is it normal?
Answer: Mood swings are extremely common as you grapple with the loss of someone very dear. This is a natural part of grieving and this helps you heal faster. You might also experience anger, guilt, sorrow, pain, yearning and even imagine seeing your loved one at familiar places. Allow yourself to feel all these intense emotions. Give yourself time and space to mourn the loss of your loved one. Grieving helps you accept the loss and move on, and is crucial for emotional well-being.

Question: It is six months since I lost someone very close and I feel extremely depressed and do not feel up to anything. I feel like giving up on life.
Answer:
Grief is a universal experience. The manner and intensity of grief vary from person to person. You are obviously filled with memories of the person you have lost and it is not easy to wipe away the years of togetherness. It will take one to two years before you completely recover and learn to live with the loss of the person.
However, if you are unable to work through your grief, seek the support of bereavement counseling. You may contact a psychologist or psychiatrist who can help you sort out your feelings and pick up the threads of your life again. You could also join a support group and share your feelings with others who could be in a similar situation like yours. Talking with them will ease the burden and bring relief.

Question: What is the best way to help a child cope with grief?
Answer: Children react to the loss of a loved one in much the same way as adults do. Most children cry, express emotions such as anger, fear, and it is best to allow them to come out with what they feel. Talking to them and comforting them help ease their pain. Most children recover from their grief faster than adults. Yet, some of them could withdraw into a shell. Such children might need professional help to understand their insecurities better. Being critical, overbearing or impatient at such times will only have a negative effect.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for beriberi?
Answer: A general physician may be able to diagnose and treat beriberi. However, in case of neurological/cardiac complications, it may be necessary to consult a neurologist or cardiologist.

Question: Is there a permanent cure for beriberi?
Answer: If caught early, most of the complications can be reversed with thiamine supplements. However, it is necessary to follow a vitamin B1-rich diet to prevent recurrence.

Question: Which Doctor Should I Consult for Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
Answer: A family physician will assess the patient and take a medical history along with laboratory tests to confirm the diagnosis. The patient may then be referred to a hematologist.

Question: Is there a dominant form of Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
Answer: There are few cases where Bernard-Soulier syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

Question: What are the other names of Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
Answer: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is also known by other names such as congenital hemorrhagiparous thrombocytic dystrophy and hemorrhagiparous thrombocytic dystrophy.

Question: How is Bernard-Soulier syndrome misdiagnosed?
Answer: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is sometimes misdiagnosed as immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

Question: Which doctors treat Best disease?
Answer: Best disease is treated by eye specialists like vitreoretinal disease specialists. A low vision specialist can help to treat the loss of vision. Genetic and occupational counselors also assist in managing the condition.

Question: Is it possible that a person may suffer from Best disease and not know about it?
Answer: Best disease may not show any symptoms during the initial years. It may be detected only if an electro-oculogram is done. In fact, some people may have the disease in their genes but not suffer from any symptoms throughout their life.

Question: Why is occupational counseling required in patients with Best disease?
Answer: Some occupations like flying aircrafts require a perfect vision. Since vision is likely to deteriorate in patients with Best disease, they need to be counseled to avoid such occupations and go in for options that do not require an accurate vision.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for sleep related problems during my pregnancy?
Answer: You can discuss sleep related queries with your gynecologist. If any further assistance is required such as consulting a therapist or counselor, your gynecologist will guide you regarding the same.

Question: What sleep position during pregnancy should I avoid?
Answer: There are two sleep positions which are advised to be avoided during pregnancy, having said that you must not panic if you turn over while sleeping and find yourself waking on your back. Preferably take someoneâ€™s assistance to maintain a left S.O.S. position.

Question: Do I need a pregnancy pillow?
Which Doctor should I Consult for Bibliomania?
Answer: Bibliomania is usually treated by a psychiatrist.

Question: How can We Differentiate Between a Book Collector and a Person Suffering from Bibliomania?
Answer: A book collector is really interested in books. He arranges them well and takes good care of his collection. On the other hand, a patient with bibliomania will collect any type of book, irrespective of whether he already has it or not. He does not arrange the books well. Collecting books becomes an obsession and this obsession interferes with his personal and social life.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bicuspid aortic valve?
Answer: A cardiologist or cardiac surgeon should be consulted for bicuspid aortic valve disease.

Question: Can a bicuspid aortic valve be repaired?
Answer: The bicuspid aortic valve can be repaired only if the damage / calcification is minimal.

Question: How does one select the type of valve for replacement procedure?
Answer: The choice of valve will depend on patientsâ€™ health status, age, lifestyle and other factors. For example, if the patient is not very much active with respect to sports, a mechanical valve may be a good option.

Question: How long does it take to replace an aortic valve?
Answer: The surgical procedure to replace an aortic valve can last anywhere around 2 to 4 hours.

Question: Will surgical procedure for valve replacement involve opening of chest?
Answer: Valve replacement procedure may require sternotomy (opening of chest bone) or may require only a series of small incisions.

Question: How long does it take to recover from open heart valve surgery?
Answer: The normal recovery time after heart valve surgery is usually four to eight weeks.

Question: Which doctors treat bile duct cancer?
Answer: A surgical gastroenterologist or a surgical oncologist may treat bile duct cancer.

Question: Is bile duct cancer and liver cancer the same?
Answer: There are a number of types of liver cancer. Bile duct cancer is one type that arises specifically from the bile ducts.

Question: Does a patient with bile stones always cause cancer?
Answer: No, if a person has bile stones, his risk for cancer increases but he does not always develop cancer.

Question: Can a human being live without a common bile duct?
Answer: Humans cannot live without a bile duct as it is required to store bile which breaks up the food particles into small pieces during metabolism. Any block in the bile duct may result in a serious infection in the gall bladder.

Question: Can alcohol cause bile duct cancer?
Answer: Intake of excess alcohol is the main cause of liver cirrhosis and patients with liver cirrhosis are more prone to Bile duct cancer.

Question: Which doctor should I consult if my child has this problem?
Answer: A pediatric surgeon is the ideal doctor to treat this condition. A hepatologist shall be required in cases of liver transplantation.

Question: Is biliary atresia congenital?
Answer: Biliary atresia can be congenital or acquired. i.e. present either at birth or develop few weeks after birth.

Question: Is biliary atresia genetic?
Answer: No. Biliary atresia is not a genetic disorder. Research yet remains unclear on whether it is caused by a mutation in the genes controlling the formation of bile duct.

Question: Which doctors treat biliary cirrhosis?
Answer: Specialists like hepatologists or gastroenterologists treat biliary cirrhosis.

Question: How does primary biliary cirrhosis differ from primary sclerosing cholangitis?
Answer: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) is an autoimmune disease usually affecting females whereas primary sclerosing cholangitis usually affects males and the cause is not known. Anti-mitrochondrial antibodies are present in most cases of PBC, which are not seen in sclerosing cholangitis.

Question: Does alcohol cause biliary cirrhosis?
Answer: No. Though alcohol is among the most common causes of cirrhosis, biliary cirrhosis is caused as a result of an autoimmune reaction (as in the case of PBC) or due to prolonged obstruction of the bile ducts arising from the liver (as in secondary biliary cirrhosis).

Question: Which doctors treat a Broken Ankle?
Answer: Ankle fractures are treated by an Orthopedician.

Question: How do you heal a Broken Ankle faster?
Answer: Reduction (bone realignment) or placing a splint is the first step to put a displaced bone back into position or to treat a suspected fracture until X-ray confirmation. This prevents extensive soft tissue damage and swelling and accelerates the process of healing.

Question: How long does it take to recover from a Broken Ankle?
Answer: A patient can resume normal activity and bear heavy loads in 12 to 16 weeks, following the injury.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for binge eating disorder?
Answer: You should consult a Psychologist, Psychiatrist, and Dietitian

Question: Is binge eating disorder a mental disorder?
Answer: Yes, binge eating is a mental disorder where people overeat on a regular basis.

Question: Can antidepressants help treat binge eating disorder?
Answer: Yes, antidepressants can help treat binge eating disorder. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as Fluoxetine (Prozac) and Sertraline (Zoloft), may help reduce binge eating and also improve the mood in patients.

Question: How do you stop binge eating at night?
Answer: Identifying the exact cause and triggers can help stop binging.

Question: Is Vyvanse (Lisdexamfetamine) used for binge eating?
Answer: Vyvanse (Lisdexamfetamine) is the first and only medication approved to treat moderate to severe Binge Eating Disorder in adults.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for biochemical recurrence of prostate cancer?
Answer: You should consult an oncologist.

Question: What tests do I need to carry out?
Answer: The initial test that needs to be carried out is the PSA test. Based on the results of this test, your doctor may recommend further tests.

Question: What will the test results tell me?
Answer: If the PSA test indicates that your PSA level is elevated above normal, then you could be having a biochemical recurrence of prostate cancer.

Question: Is there any danger if a biochemical recurrence of prostate cancer occurs?
Answer: If the condition is not treated timely and effectively, it could be dangerous and even life-threatening.

Question: Who treats bipolar disorder?
Answer: A psychiatrist is the one who treats bipolar disorders. However clinical psychologists, psychiatric nurse practitioners, and advanced psychiatric nurse specialists may also prescribe medications (depending upon licensing policies that vary).

Question: What illnesses can co-exist with bipolar disorder?
Should young women with bipolar disorder be put on valproic acid?
If I am taking lithium what precautions do I need to take?
Answer: Valproic acid is known to increase levels of testosterone (a male hormone) and cause polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in women. Hence young girls on this drug should be monitored for this condition. This condition leads to cysts in ovary and cause obesity, excess body hair and also disruptions in the menstrual cycle.

Question: Are drugs used to treat bipolar disorders safe in pregnancy?
Answer: Lithium when taken for a long term can cause problems with thyroid hormone and lead to its under secretion or hypothyroidism, If this happens the energy levels in the body goes down along with other symptoms. Often a thyroid tablet may be needed along with lithium to keep the balance.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for knowing more about the Birth Control Implant and to insert the implant?
Answer: A General Physician may be consulted to understand the various methods to control pregnancy. Based on the advantages and disadvantages of methods and the conditions suitable for the woman, the GP may recommend consultation with a Gynecologist who can advise on the procedure and then insert the implant.

Question: Is it safe to have a birth control implant?
Answer: The implant is very safe. However, all medicaments have some side effects. The healthcare provider will be able to advise the conditions under which the implant can be used.

Question: What happens while inserting or removing an implant?
Answer:
Some people may feel a slight pain when being injected with an anesthetic or a numbing shot. After the pain medication wears out, the arm where the implant was placed may ache for a short time. There may be slight tenderness or swelling around the implant for a few days and it may look bruised.
The removal process is very fast and easy. As is the case during insertion, the doctor would numb the area where the implant is located, make a small cut and remove the implant. It does not hurt when the implant is removed.

Question: What is the cost of an Implant Insertion?
Answer: The birth control implant insertion can cost anywhere around USD 0 to 1,200. However, implants are totally free or at minimal cost under most heath insurance plans or government programs.

Question: How does it compare to other long-acting birth control options?
Answer: The implant is as effective as other birth control methods like sterilization and use of IUDs.

Question: Do the birth control implants protect against STDs?
Answer: The birth control implant alone does not protect against STDs. Use of condoms reduce the chances of getting a sexually transmitted infection. Often, a combination of implant and female condom is used to protect from pregnancy and STDs.

Question: Is it safe to use an implant when breastfeeding?
Answer: Yes, it is safe to use an implant when breastfeeding. It does not affect the breast milk or the baby.

Question: Can the implant make you put on weight?
Answer: Some reports indicate that implants can cause weight gain. However, evidence shows that the women do not actually gain weight but just experience weight gain.

Question: Can you get pregnant while on the implant in your arm?
Answer: No, one cannot conceive or get pregnant while on the implant in the arm. However, there are very rare incidences where pregnancy has been reported while on the implant.

Question: Is Birth Control safe as a long-term option?
Answer: Yes, the birth control chip in the arm is safe long-term.

Question: Can the implant be used on anybody?
Answer: The implant may not be suitable for someone who has

Question: Which specialist doctor prescribes these birth control pills?
Answer: Generally it is the Gynecologist who prescribes it but your General Practitioner or GP can also give you a prescription for it.

Question: What if I forget to take the pill?
Answer: If you forget to take the pill for a day you should take it as soon as you remember and then take the next dose at the usual time. If you forget to take the pill for more than 2 days consult your doctor for alternate contraception.

Question: What are my chances for future fertility?
Answer: Women who want to become pregnant may stop using the pill any time. Fertility may return immediately or after a couple of months.

Question: Do Birth Control Pills affect my fertility?
Answer: The pill does not make you less fertile. If you were fertile before using the pill, taking it should not affect your ability to have children later.

Question: Do I have to "go off" the pill often to give my body a rest?
Answer: Most pills used today are low-dose pills. It is not necessary to "go off" the pill every so often to give your body a rest. But you may be advised to stop the pills if you are having certain side effects due to the pills.

Question: Does the Pill cause breast cancer?
Answer: The pill does not cause breast cancer, but can cause breast cancer to grow more rapidly if you develop it. Do monthly breast self-exams and report any unusual changes or lumps to the clinic.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for birth defects?
Answer: Birth defects detected during early screening can be discussed with the obstetrician and gynecologist. Those that are detected after the baby is born can be discussed with the pediatrician, depending on the birth defect a specialist can be consulted in either case.

Question: What causes intellectual disability?
Answer: The exact cause of intellectual disability cannot be pinpointed in most cases. Genetic causes like an extra chromosome due to accidents or mutations in the genetic material are the next best reason for it.

Question: Does folic acid prevent birth defects?
Answer: Consuming 400 micrograms of folic acid every day during early pregnancy prevents birth defects of the brain and spinal cord by more than 70%.

Question: What are the most preventable birth defects and their causes?
Are mono-chorionic twins prone to birth defects?
When should I undergo a test for BK virus?
Answer: Test for BK virus is usually not required. However, it is advisable to undergo the test if one is getting a transplantation done and is likely to receive strong immunosuppressive drugs.

Question: WhichDoctor Should I Consult for BK Virus Infection?
Answer: Usually, BK virus symptoms are related to the kidney function. Anephrologist can help in overcoming the problems. When the infected person hasundergone an organ transplant, they can consult the respective surgeon toovercome the problems caused by BK virus.

Question: Can the chances of BK virus infection after kidney transplantation be predicted?
Answer: Yes. The strongest predictor for BK virus infection after kidney transplantation is the one developed by The Cleveland Clinic. BKV peak viral loads in blood of an individual of more than 23,000 copies per milliliter can predict BKV kidney infection in the person, after the transplantation.

Question: Is Black Alkaline Water Good for health?
Answer: Animal studies and a few human trials have reported health benefits with black alkaline water intake namely, beneficial effects on bones, heart health, acidity and may also increase longevity.

Question: Is Black Water Harmful?
Answer: There is insufficient evidence to conclude the benefits and disadvantages of black water. Some side effects have been reported with black water consumption. It is advisable to consult an expert before ingestion.

Question: How much black water should you drink a day?
Answer: There is no specific recommended intake level for black water. In general, it is replaced with plain water.

Question: Is black water good for skin?
Answer: A few studies have reported black water is beneficial in preventing aging.

Question: What does Black water do to your body?
Answer: Black water has essential minerals in a higher concentration when compared with plain water, which may impart health benefits.

Question: Is alkaline water good for kidneys?
Answer: Water, in general, is good for the kidneys to flush out toxins. No studies have stated alkaline water to possess additional benefits.

Question: How do you make black water drink?
Answer: Alkaline water can be made using a water ionizer machine or by adding pH drops.

Question: Which doctor should i consult for blackheads?
Answer: One must consult a dermatologist for blackheads.

Question: Can eating fast foods and oily-foods cause blackheads?
Answer: Yes, recent research has linked certain foods and blackheads. Foods high in glycemic index like sugary snacks, soft drinks and bread have shown to increase sebum secretion. They increase blood sugar levels and hormonal levels of androgen which in turn make sebaceous glands secrete higher amounts of sebum, triggering blackheads formation.

Question: Is it OK to squeeze a blackhead?
Answer: No, itâ€™s very bad and harmful. Squeezing blackheads will spread oil and bacteria on the skin surface. It will also make it difficult to treat due to increased risks of infection and inflammation.

Question: Can makeup aggravate blackheads?
Answer: Yes, oil-based makeup can definitely aggravate blackheads. Always look for oil-free, water-based, and non-comedogenic makeup products.

Question: Can i use face products to treat blackheads on chest and back?
Answer: Yes. Blackheads on body occur for the same reason as clogged facial pores and they tend to happen in the chest and back, where oil glands are most abundant. The same facial products can do the trick on the chest and back.

Question: Who is the doctor who treats bladder cancer?
Answer: You should consult a urologist. Advanced stage is treated by medical oncologist.

Question: What is metastasis?
Answer: The process of spreading cancer to other body organs such as bones, liver or lungs is known as metastasis.

Question: How does the grading of cancer help in treatment?
Answer: High-grade cancer cells have a greater degree of abnormality, when viewed microscopically, in comparison to cells from a low-grade tumor. Besides they are also more invasive. Hence, treatment is based on the grading besides staging.

Question: Is it necessary to go for a second opinion?
Answer: Urologists are at the fore-front in treating bladder cancer. If the patient does not wish to undergo radical surgery, he or she may choose to consult a radiologist or medical oncologist. The patient may need to find a urologist whom he or she is comfortable with, since this will need a close follow-up and constant monitoring of disease status. The patient must always go for a second opinion.

Question: Is surgery a compulsory option?
Answer: Treatment is usually tailor-made to suit individuals. The patient must talk to the doctor and understand the treatment   (which may include surgery, radiation or chemotherapy) that has been decided for him, its implications and side effects.

Question: What is adjuvant chemotherapy?
Answer:
In this treatment, drugs are administered after surgery to kill the remaining cells or to shrink the tumor to facilitate surgery.
This "adjuvant" chemotherapy is designed to kill any cancer cells remaining after surgery and to increase the chance of a cure.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for urinary symptoms?
Answer: You should consult a urologist who will investigate further and treat.

Question: What are the complications of bladder diverticula?
Answer: Due to chronic urinary stasis within the bladder, patients with bladder diverticula can develop bladder stones and frequent urinary tract infections. Other serious complications include bladder rupture and development of cancer within the diverticulum.

Question: Which imaging method is superior for the diagnosis of bladder diverticula?
Answer: Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) is superior in the diagnosis of bladder diverticula. Bladder ultrasound with color doppler enhancement is another useful imaging method since it helps diagnose the defect, identify presence of widening of the far end of the ureters and to distinguish from other conditions having similar clinical features. Finally, the upper urinary tract (kidney and ureters) should be imaged since bladder diverticula can cause hydroureteronephrosis (dilation of ureter and kidney).

Question: Which imaging helps to detect lateral bladder diverticula?
Answer: Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is particularly useful in the diagnosis of lateral bladder diverticula.

Question: Is robotic surgery superior in diverticula excision?
Answer:
Robotic diverticulectomy has several advantages over conventional open surgery. The minimally invasive approach leads to reduced post-operative discomfort and faster recovery time, and the superior visualization provided by the robotic surgical system also helps in the extensive urinary reconstruction required in the operation, with minimal blood loss and often decreasing the time needed to perform the procedure.
On the flip side, this option may be available only in select centers, needs surgeons skilled in robotic surgery and may be highly expensive.

Question: What are the complications of diverticulectomy surgery?
Answer: The most serious specific complication of diverticulectomy surgery is an injury to the ureter. Less serious complications include urine leakage within bladder, which may get better on its own if the Foley catheter is maintained for a few days following surgery.

Question: Will surgical removal of the diverticulum relieve the urinary symptoms?
Answer: The excision of the diverticulum generally improves symptoms caused by that particular lesion, although treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., outlet obstruction) is required to prevent recurrence of additional diverticula in the future.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bladder exstrophy?
Answer: Bladder exstrophy is usually diagnosed at birth by the pediatrician, who may refer the case to a pediatric surgeon or a pediatric urologist. Adult patients with bladder exstrophy may visit a urologist for treatment.

Question: What is the long-term prognosis or outcome of bladder exstrophy?
Answer: Bladder exstrophy if left untreated can cause social issues due to the bad smell coming from the patient. In addition, the patient is also at a risk of kidney failure or cancer of the exposed bladder. Surgery especially in the case of incomplete bladder exstrophy often results in a good outcome, and the patient can lead a normal life with normal continence of urine. Many patients require repeat surgeries. A failed initial surgery reduces the chances of success with future surgeries in achieving good bladder capacity and continence of urine. Surgeries can also cause complications, which may require further treatment.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bladder spasms?
Answer: A physician should be first consulted who will refer you to  a urologist.

Question: Can bladder spasms cause constipation?
Answer: Constipation is one of the causes of bladder spasms as it can cause an obstruction in the flow of urine.

Question: What are nerves in the spine that control the bladder?
Answer: The nerves that control the bladder are connected to the central nervous system. These nerves are the sacral nerves; in particular they are the pelvic splanchnic and the pudendal nerve.

Question: What is a neurogenic bladder?
Answer: A neurogenic bladder is when the neurogenic supply to the bladder is affected. This may result due to the damage in the nerves into an overactive bladder or a flaccid bladder.

Question: What is an overactive bladder?
Answer: An overactive bladder can result in a constant urge for urination due to inability for the bladder to store urine and result in urinary incontinence. This affects the quality of life of the patient placing them in embarrassing situations.

Question: Which doctor treats bladder stones?
Answer: Bladder stones are treated by a urologist.

Question: Do people with bladder stones also have kidney stones?
Answer: Not necessarily. Some people with bladder stones may also have kidney stones while others do not.

Question: Can children get bladder stones?
Answer: Yes. Some children may be at an increased risk for bladder stones. These include those who have undergone bladder augmentation surgeries for congenital abnormalities.

Question: Can bladder stones cause cancer?
Answer: If a stone is present in the bladder for a long time, it can cause chronic irritation of the inner lining of the bladder which can lead to cancer.

Question: Can medications be used to treat bladder stones?
Answer: Bladder stones are usually treated with surgery. Alkalization of the urine with potassium citrate can be used to dissolve uric acid stones. Antibiotics are necessary to treat infections.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bleeding diathesis?
Answer: You should consult a hematologist or immunologist for bleeding diathesis.

Question: Is it possible to prevent bleeding diathesis?
Answer: Yes, by applying certain treatment methods like blood transfusion and plasma exchange therapy it is possible to prevent bleeding diathesis.

Question: Are all clotting problems inherited?
Answer: No, all clotting disorders are not inherited. Clotting disorders can also be acquired, for example they can occur from certain medical conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure, pancreatitis, and inflammatory bowel disease.

Question: Who treats bleeding disorders?
Answer: A hematologist is the specialist who can treat patients with bleeding disorders effectively.

Question: What is Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)?
Answer: It is a condition that occurs more during child birth and may cause both bleeding and clotting. It can occur as a child birth complications, in sepsis due to an endotoxin or in case of a malignancy. Clots are formed throughout the body as a result of which increased number of clotting factors are used up leading to excessive bleeding.

Question: What is the role of Vitamin K in bleeding disorders?
Answer: Several clotting factors are Vitamin-K dependent hence a deficiency of this vitamin could result in bleeding.

Question: Is there any hope for a cure for hemophilia in the future?
Answer: Gene therapy has not yet arrived at a permanent cure for hemophilia in humans although there abounds certain success stories with dogs.

Question: Are there any other blood types besides the ABO blood group?
Answer: There are many other types of antigens which may occur on the surface of red blood cells. However, most of them are classified as "minor" and are not as important as ABO and rhesus. They are the Duffy, Kell, Kidd, MNS, and P systems. Tests for antigens from these systems are not included in routine blood typing.

Question: Are there subtypes of blood group A?
Answer: There are about 20 different subgroups of blood group A of which A1 and A2 subtypes are the most common.

Question: Why is blood group O negative considered the universal donor?
Answer: A person having O negative blood group lacks all the antigens and hence has antibodies against A and B antigens in their plasma. Hence they can donate blood to people with any blood group.

Question: Is there a criteria for blood donation?
Answer: The American Red Cross association has certain rules for donating blood. One is the person must weigh at least 110 lbs. Also, if they are 18 years or younger they must meet additional height and weight criteria for whole blood donation.

Question: What is Apheresis?
Answer: In apheresis, blood is circulated through an apparatus in order to remove only a particular component; the remaining blood is put back into circulation.

Question: What are the conditions for blood storage?
Answer: Frozen red cells are stored at - 85 Â°F up to 10 years whereas less-dense blood plasma is split into components and each of them are stored according to different criteria.

Question: When can you not donate blood?

Question: What is the Bombay blood group?
Can the parent and the fetus have different Rh factors?
Answer: When somebody lacks the basic H antigen on their red blood cells, they are known to have a Bombay blood group. Hence, these individuals also lack A and B antigens since the H antigen is their precursor. Their plasma develops antibodies towards the H antigen as well as antigens A and B. Hence they can only receive blood from people who have the Bombay blood group.

Question: Is Rh incompatibility between mother and fetus serious?
Answer: Yes. The mother may be Rh negative but the baby could be Rh positive if it inherits the D antigen from the father.

Question: Which doctor should I visit in case of blood in stools?
Answer: You could visit your family doctor or a surgeon to check for the cause of blood in stools. You may be referred to a specialist depending upon the suspected cause.

Question: What are the tests used to diagnose the cause of blood in stools?
Answer: A carefully taken medical history and thorough physical examination help in diagnosing the cause of blood in stools. Some tests that assist in the diagnosis are:

Question: What is fecal occult blood?
Which doctor should I consult for high blood pressure?
Answer: A general physician may be able to measure blood pressure and also suggest the need for monitoring of blood pressure at home. He can also instruct you about the correct usage of blood pressure cuffs.

Question: What are normal blood pressure readings?
Answer: Optimal blood pressure is less than 120/80 mm Hg, where systolic blood pressure is 120 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure is less than 80 mm Hg.

Question: Is there a difference between left-arm and right-arm blood pressure?
Answer: Yes, it is common to notice differences between left-arm and right-arm pressure. Studies have been conducted to claim that a difference of 10 mm Hg or less can be considered to be normal variation of blood pressure between the two arms and should not raise concern. Consult your health care provider if the difference is higher than 10 mm of Hg.

Question: Blood Pressure Screening - Frequently Asked Questions
Answer: Blood pressure varies with age and a number of other factors. However, a systolic blood pressure of more than 140 and a diastolic blood pressure of more than 90 are considered abnormal and the patient is said to suffer from hypertension. Normal blood pressure is less than 120/80 mmHg(9✔ ✔Trusted SourceAbout HypertensionGo to source).

Question: What is a high blood pressure?
Answer: You may consult your general physician for high blood pressure. You may need to consult a cardiologist if your blood pressure is very high or if you suffer from complications(10✔ ✔Trusted SourceHypertension management in general practiceGo to source).

Question: Which doctor should I see for high blood pressure?
Answer: If your blood pressure is not too high, your doctor may initially advise lifestyle changes and a reduction in salt in your diet. If the blood pressure still does not come under control or if it is too high, medications may be needed(11✔ ✔Trusted SourceGuide to Lowering Blood Pressure  - Blood Pressure CalculatorGo to source).

Question: What is normal blood pressure at night?
Answer: Normal daytime and night-time blood pressure levels are 135/85 mm Hg and 120/70 mm Hg respectively.

Question: What are the conditions associated with hypertension?
Answer: Atherosclerosis, heart failure, kidney disease, stroke, myocardial infarction are the conditions that are associated with hypertension.

Question: Is blood pressure medicine more effective if taken at night?
Answer: Yes, blood pressure medications provide larger benefit if taken at night rather than in the morning. Studies indicate that anti-hypertensives cut down the risk of heart related conditions and lower blood pressure when taken at night.

Question: How do I switch medication from morning to night?
Answer: Never change the dose and frequency of medicine on your own. Do consult your doctor before switching the medication.

Question: What are the different blood types?
Answer:
Everybody has a blood type. These include: A, B, AB or O. Every person is either Rh-positive or Rh-negative. If one has type B blood, it can be either B positive or B negative. When receiving a blood transfusion, the recipientâ€™s type and Rh must be perfectly matched to avoid risks and reactions.
Blood type O is known as the universal donor as anyone can receive this blood type. Blood type AB is known as the universal recipient as they can receive blood from any type A, B or O.
A Rh-positive person may receive Rh-negative blood in times of emergencies when there is no time to check and screen. However, a Rh-negative person must never receive Rh-positive blood.

Question: What is a blood bank?
Answer: A blood bank is a healthcare facility where blood is collected, stored, screened and made available to people in need. Blood banks are often part of hospitals or standalone facilities. One must always approach a blood bank when blood is required for safety and avoidance of risks from blood.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Blood borne diseases?
Answer: A hepatologist or hematologist should be consulted for Blood borne diseases.

Question: What is a pathogen?
Answer: A pathogen is an infectious agent such as a virus, bacteria, prion and fungus that can produce disease.

Question: Can chlamydia spread through blood transfusion?
Answer: Chlamydia is a bacterial infection and can only be transmitted through sex with somebody with the infection. It is not possible to get it through blood, especially a transfusion.

Question: Which hepatitis is blood-borne?
Answer: Hepatitis B (HBV), hepatitis C (HCV), and hepatitis D (HDV) are all transmitted through exposure to infected blood. Hepatitis A is only rarely transmitted through the blood.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Blountâ€™s disease?
Answer: You should consult a pediatric orthopedic (bone specialist for children) surgeon.

Question: Can bowed legs be considered to be a deformity?
Answer: Yes, this is true in the case of Blountâ€™s disease. But in case of physiological bowed legs, it is not considered to be a deformity as it becomes normal with age.

Question: Is Blountâ€™s disease genetic?
Answer: A genetic link has been suggested as a possible cause of Blountâ€™s disease.

Question: Can bowed legs cause knee problems?
Answer: Yes, especially if left untreated.

Question: How can I tell if my child has Blountâ€™s disease?
Answer: If you see bowing of one or both of the legs, it could be due to Blountâ€™s disease and you should immediately consult a pediatric orthopedic surgeon.

Question: Is it possible to cure Blountâ€™s disease?
Answer: Yes, if diagnosed at an early age and with timely treatment.

Question: Blue Man Syndrome - Frequently Asked Questions
Answer: You should consult a Cardiologist.

Question: Which specialist doctor should I consult for blue man syndrome?
Answer: Long term usage of amiodarone causes bluish-grey discoloration of skin, which is known as blue man syndrome.

Question: What drug causes blue man syndrome?
Answer: Yes. One of the side effects of amiodarone is that it can cause the skin to turn blue. This is quite rare though.

Question: Can amiodarone cause your skin to become blue?
Answer: Some of the side effects include photosensitivity, blue-gray discoloration of the skin, thyroid dysfunction, corneal deposits, abnormal liver function tests, and bone marrow suppression.

Question: What are the side effects of amiodarone?
Answer: Several drugs can cause the skin to turn blue. Some of them include amiodarone which is used to treat irregular heartbeat; colloidal silver which is used in dietary supplements and ezogabine which isÃ‚ used for seizures.

Question: What drugs can turn skin blue?
Answer: Argyria is a skin condition that causes the skin to appear blue or grey. This happens when the body has been exposed to too much silver. The syndrome can occur as a result of a high-dose or extended exposure to small amounts of silver.

Question: Can silver cause bluish discoloration of skin?
Answer: Yes. It can happen to anyone with long term usage of amiodarone. However, it is not clear why men are more affected than women.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for body dysmorphic disorder?
Answer: Generally it is best to visit a psychiatrist for body dysmorphic disorder as he can analyze the personâ€™s thoughts and behaviors clearly. It may take some convincing to encourage the patient to meet the psychiatrist since most patients do not realize that they are suffering from a psychiatric condition.

Question: Can the disorder be treated without medication?
Answer: BDD can be treated only with cognitive behavior therapy in milder cases. However, severe cases should be started on medications.

Question: How long will it take to cure?
Answer: Although symptoms may not go completely, there will definitely be an improvement after the treatment. SSRI antidepressants should not be stopped suddenly. Instead, the dose must be reduced gradually, only when the doctor feels it is fine to do so.

Question: Whom do I consult for obesity?
Answer: Consult your general physician for obesity.

Question: What are the complications of excess body fat?
Answer: Excess body fat, especially in the abdominal area increases the risk of heart disease. It also increases the risk of diabetes and malignancies.

Question: How to prevent excess fat accumulation in the body?
Answer: Regular exercise and calorie restricted healthy diet can prevent the excess fat accumulation in the body.

Question: Is it safe to wear shapewear while sleeping?
Answer: Wearing a shapewear makes it tight around you and this can hinder a relaxed sleep pattern. The material of which the shapewear is made can rub across the skin during movements in sleep and cause redness or rashes, or cause excess sweat.

Question: How long should I wear shapewear if I use it daily?
Answer: Manufacturers claim that wearing shapewear for 4 to 5 hours a day can help in weight reduction. However, the user has to decide her own requirement based on the experience and comfort levels. Wearing a shapewear for special occasions is recommended rather than continuously for long-term use.

Question: Will the seams and joints of the shapewear be visible on my dress?
Answer: No. The seams usually project inwards towards the body and are not visible even on a tight hugging dress.

Question: Do bodyshapers help in weight loss?
Answer: Manufacturers claim that body shapers can reduce weight by reducing appetite and causing sweat. The sweat is one of the ways to remove body toxins. However, the user must be careful and keep herself well hydrated when using shapewear.

Question: Can I wash shapewear in my washing machine?
Answer: Shapewears can usually be washed in regular washing machines. Please see the care-instructions of the manufacturer of the shapewear before buying.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for the treatment of boils?
Answer: You should consult a dermatologist or a skin specialist for the treatment of boils. Boils that need surgical drainage may be treated by a surgeon.

Question: How will the doctor know if my furunculosis is resistant to penicillin?
Answer: Before the administration of an antibiotic, doctors usually request for a laboratory test called culture and sensitivity. In this test, the discharge from the lesion is put in a medium where the bacteria present in it will grow. The bacteria are then exposed to several antibiotics to check if they are sensitive to a particular antibiotic or not. Ideally, an antibiotic should be started only after this test is done. However, since the test takes time, in serious cases, an antibiotic that is likely to be effective is used first, and is then changed according to the culture and sensitivity test report.

Question: What is the difference between a furuncle and a carbuncle?
Answer: Furuncles and carbuncles are both skin infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus. While a furuncle or a boil affects a single hair follicle, a carbuncle is a collection of boils under the surface of the skin.

Question: Can any local antibiotic be used for the treatment of a furuncle?
Answer: No. Only antibiotics that are effective against Staphylococcus aureus will be effective in treating a furuncle. Some local antibiotics like polymyxin have no effect and therefore will not be useful.

Question: How common is the Bombay Blood group in India?
Answer: One of 10,000 Indians are found to have Bombay Blood Group.

Question: Does Bombay blood group only affect Indians?
Answer: Bombay blood group is also seen in individuals besides Indians, though it is much rarer, amounting to one in a million cases in Europe.

Question: What happens when a Bombay Blood group individual receives blood transfusion from an ABO blood group?
Answer: The patient is at a high risk of suffering from acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bone cancer?
Answer: You should consult an orthopedic surgeon, who may work along with a surgical oncologist and other specialists to treat your bone cancer.

Question: Is bone cancer curable?
Answer: Bone cancer can be cured in early stages if it is completely treated. However, like other cancers, there is no fool-proof method to state that every cancerous cell of the body has been removed. There is a possibility that the cancer can recur, therefore the patient should be observed regularly through clinical examinations and radiological tests for recurrence of the cancer.

Question: What is the outcome of bone cancer depend on?
Answer: The outcome of bone cancer depends on the size and type of the cancer, the age and weight of the patient at the time of diagnosis, the presence of predisposing genetic factors or fracture in the affected bone, and the local and distant spread of the cancer.

Question: Is bone cancer hereditary?
Answer: Bone cancer itself is not hereditary. However, several hereditary conditions increase the risk for bone cancer. For example, families with Pagetâ€™s disease may find that bone cancer is more common among them.

Question: Which doctors do bone marrow transplantation?
Answer: Bone marrow transplantation is performed by physicians including oncologists specialized in doing the transplantation.

Question: Should I ask my doctor to preserve my babyâ€™s umbilical cord once she is born?
Answer:
Preserving the umbilical cord after the baby is born is definitely a good option.
However, the high cost for storage in private cord banks could definitely be a deterrent. The umbilical cord could also be stored in public banks; however, public banks do not assure the same stem cells will be provided to the person or family when required.

Question: Where can I find donors for bone marrow transplantation?
Answer: Siblings or close relatives are preferred for bone marrow transplantation. If they are not available, donors may also be found in national and international bone marrow registries.

Question: What complications could I have as a donor?
Answer: Marrow donors may suffer from complications like pain and discomfort at the site of injection. Donors administered growth factors prior to harvesting could sometimes undergo complications like bone pain and splenic rupture.

Question: What is the cost of bone marrow transplantation?
Answer: The cost for bone marrow transplant may vary for each patient depending on the type of transplant.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bone metastases?
Answer: You should consult an orthopedic doctor.

Question: What is the prognosis for bone metastases?
Answer: The prognosis for bone metastases is unfavorable as most types of metastatic cancer cannot be cured with current treatments. The goal of these treatments is to stop or slow the growth of the cancer and relieve symptoms caused by it.

Question: What is the survival rate for metastatic cancer?
Answer: Most patients with metastatic bone disease survive for 6 to 48 months.

Question: Can cancer that has metastasized be cured?
Answer: Once cancer spreads, it is hard to control. Most types of metastatic cancer cannot be cured with current treatments.

Question: When should we visit the doctor?
Answer: It is best to visit the doctor when there is recurrent bone pain or fractures.

Question: What is the difference between primary bone cancer and bone metastasis?
Answer: Cancers that start in the bone are called primary bone cancers. Bone metastasis is when cancer starts in a different part of the body but takes hold in the bone.

Question: Whom should I go to have a Botox treatment done?
Answer: You should go to a cosmetologist or a plastic surgeon to get this treatment done.

Question: Is Botox safe?
Answer: If the treatment is carried out by a trained professional in medical settings, then it is quite safe.

Question: Why is Botox treatment costly?
Answer: It is costly because it involves experts from various different specialties.

Question: Which doctors should I consult for botulism?
Answer: You should consult your family physician when you notice symptoms of muscle weakness. You may be referred to the emergency department for further evaluation.

Question: Identify which food is favourable for Clostridium botulinum growth?
Answer: Clostridium botulinum is found in fermented, preserved, low acid, low sugar, or canned food that is not stored well.

Question: What is BOTOX?
Answer: BOTOX is a sterilized form of botulinum toxin type A. It is used to treat blepharospasm, strabismus, and facial spasms and to make the face wrinkle free and smooth.

Question: What is botulism commonly misdiagnosed as?
Answer: Botulism symptoms may be misdiagnosed as stroke, myasthenia gravis, opium overdose, or Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome.

Question: What happens when botulinum antitoxin is administered late?
Answer: Prolonged stay in the hospital, respiratory failure due to progressive paralysis of the respiratory muscles, and death are observed on delayed treatment of patients with botulinum antitoxin.

Question: Can botulism be referred to as food poisoning?
Answer: One type of botulism occurs due to contaminated food and hence causes food poisoning.

Question: Who stands at risk to be affected with botulism?
Answer: Drug users and infants below one year, are most at risk of being affected with botulism.

Question: How is botulism transmitted?
Answer: Botulism develops when inactive spores of Clostridium botulinum bacteria find their way into low-oxygen environments, such as infected stools, improperly stored and preserved food, or through injection sites used for recreational drugs. These spores thrive in the new environment releasing toxins and cause botulism.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for brachytherapy for prostate cancer?
Answer: Your consulting Urologist who will redirect you to radiation oncologist for receiving radiotherapy and brachytherapy.

Question: Is hospital stay required for the procedure?
Answer: No. Usually it can be done as a day care procedure, but sometimes an overnight stay maybe required for seed implantation brachytherapy and 2 days for high dose brachytherapy.

Question: When can I resume work?
Answer: As soon as you are discharged from the hospital.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for brain metastasis?
Answer: Since brain metastases occur due to prior cancer conditions, you must visit your oncologist to verify the symptoms observed. The diagnosis will be based on the combined observations of the oncologist, radiation oncologist, neurosurgeon, and other relevant medical experts.

Question: Is there a cure for brain metastases?
Answer: Survival rate is low for brain metastases. With improved diagnosis and treatment strategies, the quantity of life has slightly improved but there is no complete cure.

Question: How does metastatic brain cancer affect survival?
Answer: The survival of individuals with metastatic brain cancer depends on the overall health of the individual, the number of brain lesions, and the type of tumor involved in the metastasis. Poor health, lesions in inaccessible parts of the brain, large number of lesions, primary tumors like melanoma, lesions in areas of the brain that affect movement or speech, are also unfavorable indicators of survival.

Question: What is the frequency of metastasis in the brain?
Answer: Nearly 80% of metastases are observed in the cerebrum.

Question: What are the other conditions that can cause misdiagnosis of brain metastases?
Answer: Hemorrhages, primary tumors, and abscesses may be diagnosed as brain metastases.

Question: What is the frequency of incidence of brain metastases from primary lung cancer?
Answer: Nearly 25% of primary lung cancer patients are affected with metastases to the brain.

Question: Which specialist doctor treats brain tumor?
Answer: You should consult a neurosurgeon or a neurooncologist.

Question: What are the causes of a brain tumor?
Answer: The ultimate cause of brain tumor is not known but various factors such as radiation exposure and polyvinyl chloride increase the chance of developing a brain tumor.

Question: Is it inherited from one generation to the other?
Answer: No, it is not inherited. But individuals with a family history of gliomas are likely to develop brain tumors.

Question: Is surgery necessary for brain cancer?
Answer: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment for malignant and benign carcinoma of the brain. The success rate is very high.

Question: Is it curable?
Answer: Yes, it is curable in the case of benign tumors but in the case of malignant cancers, the prognosis is very poor.

Question: Which specialist should be consulted if I want to rule out brain tumor in my child?
Answer: You should consult a neurosurgeon. Depending on the tumor and required treatment, you may be referred to a neurologist or a pediatric neuro-oncologist.

Question: Are brain tumors in children common?
Answer: Approximately 1 in every 20,000 children is diagnosed with a brain tumor.

Question: Can a benign tumor be left untreated?
Answer: In the brain, even a benign tumor can cause severe symptoms by pressing on neighbouring structures and affecting their function depending on the tumor location. Even benign tumors should be treated promptly.

Question: Is brain surgery dangerous to life?
Answer: Brain surgery requires great deal of skill and experience. Make sure your surgeon has experience in the type of surgery that has been recommended. In experienced hands, the outcome of surgery for removal of tumors is very encouraging.

Question: What are glial cells, astrocytes and oligodendrocytes?
Answer: These cells are supporting cells of the brain. The neurons or nerve cells are the functional units of the brain.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA)?
Answer: A qualified audiologist typically performs the Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry procedure and interprets the results.

Question: What kind of sedation is given for the procedure?
Answer: A mild sleeping pill is given for the patient to remain calm and still during the procedure. This is important to avoid the recordings of signals generated by muscle movements. Children and infants are given mild sedation as prescribed by a pediatrician.

Question: Is BERA sensitive in picking up small acoustic neuromas?
Answer: BERA may not be able to pick up small acoustic neuromas, which will need an MRI instead.

Question: Can BERA check the functioning of the auditory pathway up to the auditory cortex of the brain?
Answer: Yes. Late response potentials, that is, the potentials recorded between 80 and 500 milliseconds are believed to rise from the auditory cortex. The procedure is done specifically to test the auditory area of the brain and is known as Cortical Evoked Response Audiometry. However, higher functions of the cortex, such as language comprehension, cannot be assessed using BERA.

Question: Which doctor should I consult if I suspect breast cancer?
Answer: Your gynecologist / obstetrician is usually the first person who can help you. However, if the cancer has spread, an oncologist is the best person to be approached.

Question: How does chemotherapy work?
Answer: Chemotherapy is a "systemic" therapy. This means that the drugs will go throughout your body and theoretically kill all cancer cells within your body. But certain chemotherapy drugs are known to kill only certain types of cancer cells; therefore, the chemotherapy drugs are selected according to the type of cancer one is affected with.

Question: How is chemotherapy given?
Answer: Most chemotherapy is given intravenously (IV) so that it reaches directly into the blood system. This allows the drugs to be rapidly absorbed and destroy the cancer fast. Sometimes chemotherapy can be given in a pill form.

Question: What are the effects of radiation treatment?
Answer: External radiation therapy does not cause one's body to become radioactive. There is no need to avoid being with other people because of treatment. Even hugging, kissing, or having sexual relations poses no risk of radiation exposure. Approximately 2 to 3 weeks after the first radiation treatment, one may experience changes to the skin areas of the chest wall and breast. These changes are an expected part of the therapy and are temporary.

Question: Are all breast lumps cancerous?
Answer: Most breast lumps are benign (not cancerous). They cannot spread outside of the breast to other organs. Fibrocystic changes usually cause most of these lumps. Fibrosis refers to excessive formation of scar-like connective tissue; cysts are fluid-filled sacs. Women with fibrocystic changes often experience breast swelling and pain. The breasts may feel lumpy and the nipple may discharge a clear or slightly cloudy green or gray fluid. Fibroadenomas or papillomas are common breast lumps.

Question: Which doctor treats breast cancer during pregnancy?
Answer: Breast cancer during pregnancy is treated by an oncologist in close association with the obstetrician.

Question: Does pregnancy influence the risk of any other cancer?
Answer: Pregnancy reduces the risk of cancer of the ovary and the endometrium, the inner lining of the uterus.

Question: How is mammography performed?
Answer: During mammography, the tissues of the breast are pressed between two plates of the mammography machine and an x-ray is taken. It is an outpatient procedure routinely performed for screening of breast cancer.

Question: When can a woman treated for breast cancer plan her pregnancy?
Answer: Physicians often recommend a gap of two years after treatment and before getting pregnant to watch for recurrences of breast cancer, which may affect the decision to have a baby or not, and for the ovarian function to recover. Contraception should be used when the woman is undergoing treatment with chemotherapy and radiation treatment. Some women who want to get pregnant after the treatment may prefer freezing their egg once they are diagnosed with cancer and before receiving any treatment.

Question: Which doctors do mammography?
Answer: Mammography is done by a Radiologist. Generally a Surgeon will guide you to undertake the test.

Question: What happens if the mammography test comes abnormal?
Answer: If the mammogram comes abnormal, the woman may have to undergo further radiological tests and maybe a Fine Needles Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) or a needle Biopsy to rule out breast cancer.

Question: Does mammography have any side effects?
Answer: Mammography may cause anxiety and slight pain during the procedure. It also exposes the woman to radiation. However, the dose of the radiation is very low and the benefits of the procedure outweigh the risks. The results of the test may not be 100% accurate. Some breast abnormalities other than cancer may appear suspicious on mammogram. Thus the woman may be subjected to further unnecessary tests. Mammograms may also not yield correct results in women with breast implants.

Question: Which doctor should I consult if I have a breast lump?
Answer: Consult a general Surgeon.

Question: I find a lump in my breast should I wait to see if it wanes or consult a doctor?
Answer: If you find that there is something unusual in your breast it would be appropriate to consult your doctor right away.

Question: If my breasts feel lumpy despite the doctor saying that it is only a cyst what should I do?
Answer: If worried, it is better to get a second opinion.

Question: I always have â€˜lumpyâ€™ breasts. What then is â€˜normalâ€™?
Answer: The trick is to familiarize yourself with your breasts. Anything unusual must be subjected to medical examination. However, there is no reason to panic, as the vast majority of these lumps are benign.

Question: Which doctor specialist should I see if I need to be screened for a breast lump?
Answer: Seek an appointment with a General Surgeon or a surgeon who has special interest in breast  surgery.

Question: Does preventive surgeries guarantee against breast cancer?
Answer: No, it does not. It reduces the risks considerably. However, the surgeries cannot completely rule out cancer development.

Question: If I am BRCA positive does that mean I will develop cancer later on?
Answer: Being BRCA positive does not mean that you will definitely develop cancer. It only puts you at a higher risk and must be treated as a sign of warning.

Question: Are BRCA genes found in everyone?
Answer: Yes, they are. BRCA genes are tumor suppressor genes and they survey our system for abnormalities. One of the reasons why cancer develops is because these genes undergo mutation.

Question: Which doctor should I consult if I am diagnosed with breech presentation of the baby?
Answer: You should consult a Gynecologist

Question: What is breech presentation?
Answer: By around 8 months, most babies settle down in head down position, known as a cephalic presentation. A baby is said to be in breech presentation when the buttocks of the baby are presenting first at the bottom of the uterus.

Question: Why does Breech Presentation occur?
Answer: In most cases of breech presentation no direct cause is found. Conditions that will make a breech presentation more likely include abnormalities of the womb such as fibroids, twin pregnancy, a low-lying afterbirth (placenta) and a premature delivery.

Question: What is moxibustion?
Answer: Moxibustion is Traditional Chinese medicine that uses burning herbs to stimulate acupuncture points, and it may be helpful in turning breech babies when applied to the little toe. Its effect may be through increasing fetal activity.

Question: What is meant by External cephalic version?
Answer: If your baby is in a breech position, your doctor may try turning him around by pushing strategically on your belly so that it's in the head down position. This procedure is called external cephalic version, and it is usually done in a hospital setting where the baby's heart rate can be carefully monitored.

Question: Can a breech baby be delivered without a cesarean?
Answer: Although breech babies can be delivered vaginally, it's generally safer and easier to deliver babies head first from the vagina. So, many times doctors deliver breech babies by cesarean delivery.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for broken heart syndrome?
Answer: You should consult your family physician who will refer you to a heart specialist.

Question: What are the other names for broken heart syndrome?
Answer: The alternate names for broken heart syndrome are stress-induced cardiomyopathy and apical ballooning syndrome.

Question: What is the prevalence of broken heart syndrome?
Answer: The prevalence of broken heart syndrome in the world is 0.02% approximately.

Question: What is Reverse Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy?
Answer:
Reverse Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is a very rare form of broken heart syndrome where the presentation of the patient is different from regular broken heart syndrome. In such cases, patients display symptoms at an earlier age than those with regular broken heart syndrome.
There is an increased involvement of the heart muscle, higher biomarker levels, less fluid accumulation in the lungs, and reduced shortness of breath. Stress plays a very critical role as a cause for Reverse Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Despite abnormal ECG recordings, the coronary arteries are normal.

Question: Can I die of broken heart syndrome?
Answer: Yes, the broken heart syndrome may cause death. The contraction of heart can lead to complete cardiac failure, but the chances are very less.

Question: Which doctors should I consult for broken jaw?
Answer: An Orthopedic doctor can be consulted for broken jaw.

Question: Is surgery for mandibular jaw fracture an emergency?
Answer: Mandibular fracture was treated as an emergency with patients rushed into surgery within 6 hours of injury to avoid complications of surgery that include:
