Answer: Physical examination and tests will be carried out to assess the level of progress made. This again, differs with individuals.

Question: Which specialist should I contact if my child has allergic reactions to certain foodstuffs?
Answer: You should contact an allergy specialist.

Question: How can one distinguish symptoms of common cold from allergy?
Answer: Both allergic rhinitis and common cold may cause runny nose, sneezing, and nasal stuffiness. However, it may be possible to distinguish between the two conditions by the following:

Question: Can relocating to a new place cure my allergic rhinitis and asthma?
Is immunotherapy a cure for allergy?
Answer: Unlikely. You may develop allergy to plant pollens or other allergens in the new place too.

Question: What are the foods commonly associated with allergic reactions?
Answer: There is no cure for allergy, but medicines can control the symptoms. Immunotherapy (allergy shots) does not provide a cure, but can offer relief from symptoms for a prolonged period.

Question: What is food intolerance? Is it the same as food allergy?
Answer: Any food can potentially cause allergic reactions. However, most allergic reactions may be caused by one or more of the following foods - milk, peanuts, soy, wheat, eggs, tree nuts, fish and shellfish.

Question: What are the features of food allergy?
Answer: Food intolerance occurs because the body is unable to digest certain foods eg lactose in milk. Symptoms usually include vomiting and diarrhea, and are not life threatening. Food intolerance is not immune mediated and is different from food allergy.

Question: Do food allergies last lifelong?
Answer: Symptoms can be variable and involve any system, not just the gut. Skin and respiratory symptoms can also occur. Occasionally, even life threatening symptoms can occur with a steep fall in blood pressure and severe breathing difficulties.

Question: Which doctor should I see if my child has asthma?
Answer: You must consult an allergist / immunologist (a pediatrician with at least two additional years of specialized training in the diagnosis and treatment of problems such as allergies, asthma, and autoimmune diseases).

Question: Does asthma run in families?
Answer: The tendency to develop allergies including allergic asthma often runs in the family. There are, however, a number of other things that can cause children to develop asthma.

Question: What do you do in case of an asthma attack?
What is the first-aid for asthma?
What do you do when you do not have your inhaler?
Is there a cure for asthma?
What climate is best for a person with asthma?
At what age does asthma start? Is asthma contagious?
Can you die from an asthma attack?
Answer: At present there are methods to relieve asthma. Thanks to research this might change in future.

Question: Why does asthma worsen at night?
Answer: No specific climate is ideal for people with asthma, since there are so many triggers for symptoms, which differ from person to person. If you move to a new area triggers in the new environment may provoke your symptoms more or less than where you lived before.

Question: Is there a risk with asthma or its medications during pregnancy?
Answer: Asthma can start at any age; many children with asthma have had their first asthma attack before the age of 6. No, asthma is not contagious.

Question: What side effects should be expected from the medications?
Answer: Yes, but most people who have an asthma attack get help and get well. However it can kill you when it is not treated the right way. United Kingdom has the largest number of deaths due to asthma followed by the rest of Europe.

Question: Which specialist should I consult to rule out childhood cancer?
Answer: You should consult a pediatric oncologist.

Question: Why do little children get cancer?
Answer: There is no definite cause found in many cases. In some cases a genetic or familial factor may be found.

Question: Are childhood and adult cancers similar or different?
Answer: They are very different in nature.

Question: Are children with Downâ€™s syndrome more likely to develop cancer?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Will my insurance cover the cancer treatment expenses?
Answer: Please contact your insurance provider to find out.

Question: Can prenatal tests diagnose cancer in unborn child?
Answer: Scanning during pregnancy may permit early detection of brain tumors. However, definitive diagnosis is only confirmed after birth by histology.

Question: What is role of vaccination in preventing cancer?
Answer: Vaccination against HPV prevents cervical cancer. Hepatitis vaccination prevents childhood onset of disease and risk of developing liver cancer in adults.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Childhood Nephrotic Syndrome?
Answer: A Nephrologist or a Pediatrician should be consulted for Childhood Nephrotic Syndrome.

Question: How will I know if my child has nephrotic syndrome?
Answer: You may come to know that your child has nephrotic syndrome until you take your child for routine blood and urine tests. The results of the tests can show if the child has too much protein in urine and not enough protein in the blood.

Question: What should I know about the steroid treatment?
Answer: When taking steroid treatment you should take care of your child properly. If the child becomes ill, immediately visit doctor. Your child will require a course of high dose steroids with each relapse. Consult the doctor regarding any changes in dosage. Steroids dosing has to be managed very carefully.

Question: What do I have to do at home?
Answer: You need to test your childâ€™s first urine for protein every morning as long as edema persists and then less frequently. Also, record weight and temperature daily.

Question: Which doctor should I visit to get a test for chlamydial infection done?
Answer: You should visit your gynecologist or venereal disease specialist to get tested for chlamydial infection. In some cases, your general physician or an internist or a family physician may also conduct the test.

Question: When should a woman stop screening for chlamydial infection?
Answer: Though there is no specific recommendation regarding when to stop screening for chlamydial infection, screening may be stopped once a woman has reached menopause. This is because the woman is no longer exposed to the complications of chlamydial infection like ectopic pregnancy and infertility which she is normally exposed to before menopause.

Question: What are the other tests used to diagnose chlamydial infection?
Answer: Other tests used to diagnose chlamydial infections are:

Question: What happens if the test result is positive for chlamydial infection?
Which doctor do I consult?
Answer: A general physician or an internist or a family physician can be consulted.

Question: Which Organs can be affected by Chlamydia?
Answer: Chlamydia is the most common sexually transmitted disease (STD). It can infect the penis, vagina, cervix, anus, urethra, or eye.

Question: Is it a common infection?
Answer: Yes, it is a common infection. But because the signs of chlamydia often go unnoticed, an individual can develop serious health complications before recognizing that they are infected.

Question: How is it transmitted?
Answer: It may be transmitted during vaginal, anal, or oral sex and can be transmitted even if there are no signs or symptoms of infection. Chlamydia can also be passed from an infected mother to her newborn during delivery.

Question: What are the symptoms?
Answer: The symptoms may vary from an abnormal discharge (mucus or pus) from the vagina or penis or experience of pain while urinating.

Question: Do they appear soon after infection?
Answer: Symptoms usually appear within 7 to 21days after being infected. Usually it goes unnoticed.

Question: Can a pregnant woman pass on the infection to the baby?
Answer: Yes, it may be passed on to the baby by the infection of the birth canal. It is very important for pregnant woman to have a screening test done.

Question: Does having the infection cause harm to the newborn baby?
Answer: Yes, the infection when passed to the newborn may cause serious eye infection or pneumonia. It may also lead to premature delivery and low birth weight babies.

Question: Are there any complications if left untreated?
Answer: The complications If Left Untreated can be, ectopic (tubal) pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease in woman, infertility in men and women, and it would lead to an uncontrolled spread.

Question: How is it diagnosed?
Answer: It is diagnosed in the laboratory, where a swab from the vaginal, rectal or urethral opening is taken and culture tests will be done.

Question: How is it treated?
Answer: The infection can be treated completely by antibiotics prescribed by your doctor.

Question: If infected and treated for chlamydia infection can there be a recurrence of infection?
Answer: Yes, the treatment is not for lifetime, you can get infected repeatedly if you do not take careful precautions.

Question: How can I protect myself?
Answer: You may follow some simple methods to try and protect yourself.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for my child to rule out choanal atresia?
Answer: If your child was not diagnosed with choanal atresia at the time of birth but you have cause to suspect that the condition may be present, it would be a good idea to consult a pediatrician or a pediatric otolaryngologist/pediatric ENT specialist.

Question: Is surgery really necessary and is there nothing I can do at home?
Answer: Surgery is the only effective treatment for the problem, but it will only be recommended if necessary. It is important that you follow the recommendations of your health care provider, especially if surgery is being recommended as an emergency procedure. In situations where there is no immediate threat to the child, you can delay the surgery and consult with other pediatric specialists. The recommendation is however unlikely to change.

Question: Which Doctor Should I Consult to Rule out Cholecystitis?
Answer: You may consult a General Practitioner in the initial stages of the disease. However if surgery is required then a General Surgeon or Gastroenterologist can be consulted.

Question: How can Obesity Cause Cholecystitis?
Answer: Usually the levels of cholesterol in obese persons are on the higher side and having high levels of cholesterol in the blood is the main cause for developing gallbladder stones.

Question: How to Prevent Repeat Attack of Cholecystitis?
Answer: A repeat attack of Cholecystitis can be prevented by keeping body weight in a normal range. You are advised to lose weight gradually if you are obese. A weight loss of about 2 kilograms per month is recommended. Also intake of fatty food has to be avoided and emphasis should be more on vegetables, fruits and whole grains.

Question: What is a Pseudolith or a "Fake Stone?
Answer: The gall bladder is a reservoir for bile. Sometimes the bile stored in the gallbladder thickens to form a sludge which is also known as a pseudolith or fake stone.

Question: Is Laparoscopic Surgery or Open Surgery the Best Option for Gallbladder Removal?
Answer: Both surgeries are equally effective, however, the resulting scar on the abdomen due to surgical incision is much smaller and less visible after Laparoscopic surgery.

Question: Are Gall Stones Found Equally in Both Males and Females?
Answer: Gallstones are two to three times more frequent in females than in males.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for cholestatic jaundice?
Answer: One must consult the primary physician who will recommend the required diagnostic tests to identify the cause of the jaundice. The patient will then be referred to a specialist (hepatologist or gastroenterologist) for appropriate therapeutic interventions.

Question: What is the difference between physiological jaundice and cholestatic jaundice in the newborn?
Answer: Physiological jaundice is caused because the immature liver of newborn is unable to effectively metabolize the bilirubin and resolves within 2 to 3 weeks. Cholestatic jaundice persists beyond the first 3 weeks of a newbornâ€™s life and is due to congenital defects in liver and biliary tree, bile secretion and transport.

Question: What is the prognosis of cholestatic jaundice due to pregnancy?
Answer: Cholestatic jaundice in pregnancy resolves itself after the baby is born.

Question: Is cholestatic jaundice fatal?
Answer: In the case of infants, if cholestatic jaundice is diagnosed correctly in the early stages, then the infant can be treated effectively and fatal outcomes can be avoided. In adults, the prognosis depends on the cause and how soon it is detected.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for cholesteatoma?
Answer: An ENT surgeon should be consulted for cholesteatoma.

Question: Is a cholesteatoma serious?
Answer: In the initial stages the cholesteatoma usually does not have pose any serious threat. But as the cholesteatoma grows larger it may cause serious complications such as damage to the eardrum and bones inside the middle ear and facial paralysis.

Question: Is a cholesteatoma painful?
Answer: Cholesteatoma usually does not cause pain. But the associated infection may result in pain, redness and swelling behind the ear.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for cholesteryl ester storage disease?
Answer: One must consult a family physician who will recommend the necessary tests to diagnose the condition.

Question: What are the other names for cholesteryl ester storage disease?
Answer: Cholesteryl ester storage disease is also referred to by the following names:

Question: What are the new forms of therapy that are being researched for CESD?
What are the diseases that display similar symptoms as CESD?
Answer: Gene therapy is being studied in which a functional gene can be introduced to produce a functional lysosomal acid lipase enzyme. This functional enzyme can compensate for the mutated enzyme that is present in CESD patients. Enzyme replacement therapy is also being explored for the treatment of CESD.

Question: Which Doctors Treat Chorioangioma?
Answer: Chorioangiomas are treated by obstetricians and gynecologists taking care of the pregnancy.

Question: What is the Difference Between Chorioangioma and Choriocarcinoma?
Answer: Choriocarcinoma is a malignant tumor of the placenta, though it may arise from testes and ovary as well. Choriocarcinoma can spread through blood to the lungs. On the other hand, chorioangioma is a benign tumor.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for choriocarcinoma in females?
Answer: Women may consult their gynecologist for issues on vaginal bleeding or in the case of complications in pregnancy, where there is no movement of the fetus.

Question: What are the different types of gestational trophoblastic diseases?
Answer: The different types of gestational trophoblastic diseases, include placental site trophoblastic tumor, invasive mole, partial hydatidiform mole, choriocarcinoma, epithelioid trophoblastic tumor, and complete hydatidiform mole.

Question: What is the incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia from all types of pregnancies?
Answer: The incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia resulting from all types of pregnancies is 1:40 000.

Question: What is non-gestational ovarian choriocarcinoma?
Answer: Non-gestational ovarian choriocarcinoma is an extremely rare form of choriocarcinoma. Metastases to the brain indicate the poor outcome of the disease. Surgery along with chemotherapy and radiotherapy is the suggested order of treatment for non-gestational ovarian choriocarcinoma. Periodic follow-up of hCG levels will alert an individual to any future risk of developing the condition.

Question: How does Christianson syndrome occur?
Answer: Christianson syndrome occurs due to changes in a particular gene called SLC9A6. The condition runs in families and is inherited through the X chromosome.

Question: How is Christianson syndrome passed to the offspring?
Answer: Christianson syndrome is inherited through the X chromosome. In males each cell contains one X and one Y chromosomes, while females have two X chromosomes. So, in males if the X chromosome is affected, the individual exhibits signs of Christian Syndrome. But in females, both the X chromosomes have to be affected to exhibit the symptoms of Christianson Syndrome.

Question: How common is Christianson syndrome?
Answer: Christianson syndrome is an extremely rare condition.

Question: How is Christianson syndrome treated?
Answer: Treatment involves maintenance with symptomatic care, as no specific treatment is available for this condition.

Question: Which Doctor Should I Consult for Chromoblastomycosis?
Answer: A skin specialist can help in the treatment and control of chromoblastomycosis.

Question: Is there a vaccine for chromoblastomycosis?
Answer: There is no known vaccine for chromoblastomycosis. The disease is caused due to exposure to fungus from vegetation like decaying wood and contaminated stagnant water. Hence, it can be prevented by avoiding contact with such objects or cleaning up with disinfectants after such contact.

Question: Can the nodules of chromoblastomycosis turn into cancerous lesions?
Answer: Some rare complications of chromoblastomycosis turning into squamous cell carcinoma have been reported by doctors. It is best to get the disease treated on time with various combinations of the therapy options.

Question: Is chromoblastomycosis found worldwide?
Answer: Although the fungal skin infection has been reported worldwide, more cases are found in rural areas of the tropical region. Madagascar in Africa has reported the highest incidence of the disease.

Question: If my coworker is suffering from chromoblastomycosis, am I prone to the infection?
Answer: Risk of getting infected from a coworker with chromoblastomycosis is very less. However, one must be careful with open wounds on the skin as they attract not only fungus but also other kinds of germs.

Question: How is chromoblastomycosis related to elephantiasis?
Answer: When the fungus infects the lymphatic tissues, the ducts that drain the lymph are obstructed. This condition leads to obstruction of the lymph and fluid retention, causing edema and swelling. Usually, the condition affects the limbs, more often the legs, and is called elephantiasis.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for bronchitis?
Answer: A pulmonologist should be consulted for bronchitis and all other respiratory disorders.

Question: Is there a cure for chronic bronchitis?
Answer: There is no cure for chronic bronchitis. As the name suggests it is a chronic condition that lasts for years or for life time. Treatment will help to relieve symptoms, prevent complications and slow the progression of the disease.

Question: What is a COPD flare-up?
Answer: When symptoms worsen suddenly - when your breathing becomes really hard, you cough or wheeze more or produce more phlegm, it is a COPD flare-up. The first thing to remember is not to panic. Take any quick relief oral medications or inhalers you might have. Use oxygen if prescribed. If symptoms do not get beetroot in 48 hours, go to the hospital.

Question: What is emphysema?
Answer: Emphysema is also a type of COPD. In emphysema, the alveoli or air sacs of the lungs are gradually destroyed. The inner walls of the air sacs weaken and rupture, the surface area reduces which depletes the amount of oxygen that reaches the bloodstream. Long-term exposure to air borne irritants is the main cause of emphysema. The main symptom of emphysema is shortness of breath that developed gradually.

Question: What is the difference between chronic bronchitis and emphysema?
Answer: Chronic bronchitis causes inflammation in the lining of the trachea and bronchial tubes of lungs. This inflammation causes excess mucus secretion and is characterized by productive cough. Emphysema involves destruction of the air sacs or alveoli of the lungs. As a result, the amount of oxygen that reaches the bloodstream is depleted.

Question: Which doctor is to be consulted for CFS?
Answer: It is very important for CFS patients to seek treatment with a doctor who is familiar with the disorder. An initial consultation with the family doctor or general physician can raise suspicion of CFS. Further recommendation or consultation can then be based on the underlying symptoms and the severity.

Question: Does CFS affect women more than men?
Answer: Based on available data, it has been found that the condition is two or more times pronounced in women, as compared to men. However it is not clear if the trend is due to increased susceptibility of women to CFS or due to under reporting of similar symptoms by men.

Question: Is CFS a genetic disorder?
Answer: Despite years of research on CFS, it has not been possible to pinpoint the factors causing CFS. A largest ever study conducted at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention highlights that CFS may have a genetic link. In other words, individuals with certain specific genes may be more susceptible to develop CFS due to altered activity of the gene. These genes which play a critical role in mediating stress response can either confer an increased or decreased CFS risk. More studies are needed at this juncture to aid better understanding of the role of genetics in causing CFS.

Question: Does CFS affect children as well?
Answer: Although the presence of CFS in adults has been well documented, very little is known about the prevalence of CFS among children and young adults. Some studies have documented the presence of CFS in children less than 5 years old. In a sample of 100, 000, nearly 5 to 6 children and 10-19 young adults are likely to suffer from CFS, according to a study conducted by Australian researchers.

Question: Which specialist doctor should be consulted for treatment and follow up of chronic granulomatous disease?
Answer: Consult a Hematologist or a General Physician. For biopsy a General Surgeon may need to be involved.

Question: Do CGD ever affect girls?
Answer: The most common genetic type of CGD affects only boys. There are however some genetic types that affect girls.

Question: Which races are more susceptible to CGD?
Answer: No racial predilection is known.

Question: What are the complications of CGD?
Answer: Kell antigens form a group of antigens on the human red blood cell surface. Gene deletions make patients with CGD sensitised to Kell antigens after blood transfusions, i.e. antibodies are produced against these antigens. This leads to complications after subsequent transfusions. Hence it is important to examine the Kell-antigen status in patients.

Question: Which specialist doctor to consult for Chronic Histiocytic Intervillositis?
Answer: You should consult a Gynecologist for Chronic Histiocytic Intervillositis.

Question: What does Histiocytosis mean?
Answer: A histiocyte is a type of immune cell that is normally found throughout the body, but is especially common in the bone marrow, blood, skin, liver, lungs, lymph nodes, and spleen. In histiocytosis, the histiocytes invade tissues that are not typically home to them and harm them.

Question: What is Villitis of Unknown Etiology and how common is it?
Answer: Villitis of Unknown Etiology (VUE), is a serious pattern of placental injury that primarily affects term placentas. Even though it has some traits with viral villitis, it has distinct clinical and histologic features. It is a frequent lesion that impacts 5% to 15% of placentas.

Question: What are the three most common placental abnormalities?
Answer: The three most common placental abnormalities are placental disorders are called placenta previa, placenta accreta, placenta increta or percreta. Among these the most common placental anomalies in terms of position and anatomy are low-lying placentas, placenta previa, and abnormally invasive placentas. Due to substantial blood loss prior to, during, or after delivery, these diseases can have serious effects on the mother and fetus.

Question: How do I keep my placenta healthy?
Answer: During pregnancy, the recommended iron intake almost doubles. Thus, iron-rich vegetables like spinach, broccoli, and kale are essential for pregnant women. Low iron levels can cause a deficit and obstruct the delivery of nutrients and oxygen to the placenta.

Question: What percentage of Placental Abruptions are fatal?
Answer: Premature placental detachment before delivery, or placental abruption, is frequently a serious obstetric emergency for the fetus and is linked to significant congenital abnormalities, stillbirth, hypoxia, and preterm. Life-threatening complications can result from placental abruption for both the mother and the fetus. Placental abruption can cause the mother to go into shock because of blood loss. 10% of babies die during pregnancy due to placental abruption.

Question: What leads to placental inflammation?
Answer: Lymphocytes, plasma cells, and/or macrophages infiltrate the placenta in chronic inflammatory lesions, which can be caused by immunological responses (maternal anti-fetal rejection) or infections (viral, bacterial, or parasitic).

Question: How can you tell if your placenta has a damage?
Answer: Doctors may prescribe to check for placental insufficiency by doing an ultrasound to examine the fetus' size and placental characteristics, such as calcium deposits or placental thickness. A non-stressful fetal test that keeps track of the infant's heartbeat and contractions is also done.

Question: Who treats Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia(CLL) patients?
Answer: A Haematologist can treat the condition. Sometimes it is a hematologist with a specicial interest in oncology.

Question: Can CLL be cured?
Answer: CLL is not curable but it can be treated and managed effectively. Many people with CLL are leading normal and useful lives.

Question: When should treatment start?
Answer: The early-stage patients are not treated while it should start immediately in patients with advanced disease.

Question: Are complementary therapies available for CLL?
Answer: So far there are no proven complementary therapies available. However, some patients do find solace in some forms of alternative medicines.

Question: Is vit C advisable?
Answer: Vit C is recommended to prevent malignancy. For those who are already affected, stick to the basic recommended dose.

Question: Do the patients need to be on a diet?
Answer: It is advisable for the patients to avoid uncooked food and certain dairy products. They may also benefit by limiting commercial food.

Question: Can a bone marrow transplant be done on any patient?
Answer: A proper donor is required who is appropriately matched to the patient. The donor also needs to be healthy who can withstand the procedure.

Question: How do I find the suitable donor?
Answer: The best donors are close relatives like siblings or parents. The next best choice is an unrelated volunteer who is tissue matched. They can be availed through voluntary organizations or other panels.

Question: What is remission?
Answer: It is a state where the disease is not detectable or it is detected in a fashion that does not produce symptoms.

Question: Which doctors treat COPD?
Answer: COPD may be treated by general physicians or specialists called pulmonolgists.

Question: Does pipe and cigar smoking also result in COPD?
Answer: Pipe and cigar smoking are less frequent causes of COPD since the tobacco content in their smoke is less than that in cigarettes.

Question: Do all cases of chronic bronchitis come under COPD?
Answer: No.  Only those cases with airway obstruction are classified under COPD.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for chronic renal failure?
Answer: A Nephrologist or a Physician with interest in kidney diseases. Nephrologist is a physician, whereas if surgery is necessary a surgeon performs it and this usually is a urologist.

Question: Can I catch kidney disease from someone who has it?
Answer: No. Kidney disease is not contagious. You cannot catch it from someone. Most kidney disease is caused by diabetes, high blood pressure and conditions that can run in families. If you are a family member of someone who has diabetes, high blood pressure, or kidney disease, it is a good idea to ask your doctor to check your blood pressure and kidney function at your checkup.

Question: What are kidney stones?
Answer: A kidney stone occurs when substances in the urine form crystals. Kidney stones can be large or small. Large ones can damage the kidneys; small ones may be able to pass in the urine. Since crystals have sharp edges, passing even small stones can be very painful. Treatment depends on what the stones are made of.

Question: What is PTH?
Answer:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is produced by several small, bean-like parathyroid glands in your neck. Its "job" is to tell your bones to release calcium into your bloodstream. Too much PTH can become a problem in people with kidney disease.

Healthy kidneys convert a hormone called calcitriol to its active form of vitamin D. Calcitriol lets your body absorb calcium from food you eat. When your kidneys are not working well, they start to make less calcitriol - so even if you eat calcium, your body can't absorb it. PTH kicks in to make sure you always have enough calcium in your blood. Over time, this can weaken your bones.

A blood test can show if your PTH levels are above normal. If they are, your doctor may prescribe a form of active vitamin D.

Question: I have a family member with polycystic kidney disease (PKD). Should I be tested?
Answer:
Since 60-70% of people with PKD have a family member with PKD, asking your doctor about being tested seems like a good idea. The first test used for PKD is an ultrasound to look at the kidneys and see if there are cysts. No contrast dye is needed, so this is a non-invasive test. Depending on tour age and cysts that are found, a diagnosis can be made.
This is more important if you are considering donating a kidney to someone who is related to you.

Question: If I have signs of kidney disease, what should I do?
Answer: After you have basic screening tests done, if you have signs of kidney disease, you should ask for a referral to a nephrologist, a specialist in treating kidney disease. A nephrologist will perform an evaluation then suggest medications or lifestyle changes to help slow the progression of kidney disease.

Question: I just found out I have kidney failure. Does this mean I am going to die?
Answer: No. Dialysis or a kidney transplant can keep you alive when your kidneys fail. The more you learn and take part in your treatment, the better you can feel. Some people live for decades with kidney failure and there are others who are on dialysis for many years and continue to work and have a relatively normal lifestyle, however most studies show that the quality of life after a kidney transplant is better than being on life time dialysis.

Question: When should I be referred to a nephrologist?
Answer:
You should be under the care of a nephrologist if your creatinine clearance, a measure of your kidney function, is 30 mL/min or lower. This translates to stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD).

When you first find out you have CKD (even if it is stage 2 or 3), seeing a nephrologist at least once can help you develop a plan of care. A nephrologist can help you and your primary care doctor to:

Question: Are there any drugs or diet that can help me if I have chronic in Kidney disease?
What kind of Lifestyle changes are recommended if I have Kidney disease?
Answer: Ongoing research continues on dietary changes and drugs that may help slow the progression of CKD. Examples include:

Question: am diabetic and have early kidney disease. What should I do?
What should be my blood pressure if I have kidney disease?
Answer: Lifestyle changes such as losing weight, exercising, meditating, eating less salt and drinking less alcohol can help lower your blood pressure.

Question: When should I start the process to get a kidney transplant?
Answer:
If you have diabetes, strict controls of your blood glucose levels can help slow the progression of kidney disease.

Keep your hemoglobin A1c, which measures blood glucose control over the last three months, to less than 6.5%. To reach this level of strict glycemic control, you will need to monitor your blood glucose closely to avoid hypoglycemia. You may need to use frequent insulin injections or an insulin pump. Talk to your doctor about your diabetes treatment options.

Question: If I get a rejection after transplant, can it be treated or will I lose my transplanted kidney?
Answer:
Study after study has confirmed that good blood pressure control can help slow the rate of CKD. This is especially true in people who have diabetes and protein in the urine (proteinuria). Keeping blood pressure under control also helps prevent heart disease and stroke.

According to National Kidney Foundation (NKF) guidelines, you should strive to keep your blood pressure at or below 130/80 if you have CKD. If you have diabetes and/or proteinuria too, their current suggested target blood pressure is even lower at 125 / 75.

For most people with CKD, blood pressure drugs are also needed. The first blood pressure drug is likely to be an "angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor" (ACE inhibitor) or an "angiotensin receptor blocker" (ARB), because these drugs have been proven to slow the rate of some types of kidney disease. Other types of blood pressure drugs such as a diuretic (water pill) or a calcium-channel blocker may be added, as needed. Ask your doctor what you can do to keep your blood pressure at a healthy level.

Question: Which doctor is to be consulted for managing chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)?
Answer: The first step is to speak to your primary care physician. Then based on the findings, your physician might refer you to a neurologist or neurosurgeon.

Question: CTE is noted in individuals participating in contact sports. Is it a rare disease?
Answer: Yes. CTE is a rare disease. It occurs because of repeated concussions to the brain with no preventive measures being taken at the right moment. Though, not all individuals with concussions develop CTE.

Question: Can CTE diagnosed before death?
Answer: There are no reliable procedures to diagnose CTE. Diagnosis of CTE requires evidence of deposits of tau proteins in the brain and degeneration of brain tissue that can be observed only upon autopsy. A set of neurological tests is however being explored for the diagnosis of CTE.

Question: When should I see a doctor after an injury?
Answer: CTE develops over many years after repeated brain injuries. It is advised to visit the doctor if the following symptoms occur.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for ciguatera toxicity?
Answer: Your regular GP or a gastroenterologist should be consulted soon after symptoms become evident.

Question: What is symptom recurrence and sensitization in ciguatera poisoning?
Answer:
People who suffered from Ciguatera poisoning could experience a recurrence of neurological symptoms on consumption of alcohol, nuts, nut oil or fish. To avoid this, such food types should not be consumed.

In addition, they may suffer from increased sensitivity to fish that may be contaminated with ciguatera. The same amount of fish might not produce any symptom among normal individuals.

Question: Is ciguatera the only type of marine toxin?
Answer: Ciguatera is the most common type of marine toxin but there are other marine toxins that could affect human on consumption of contaminated fish.

Question: Are home testing kits available?
Answer: There are many testing kits that are available in the market but their effectiveness is still under question. Laboratory testing is highly specific but it is expensive.

Question: Are all coral reefs ciguatoxic?
Answer: No. Not all coral reefs are ciguatoxic. Ciguatoxic fish are usually found in the Pacific Ocean, Indian Ocean and the Caribbean Islands.

Question: What is the toxic dose for ciguatera?
Answer: The toxic dose is 23-230.

Question: Whom should I consult if I am suffering from circadian rhythm sleep disorders?
Answer: You can consult a sleep specialist or a   general physician.

This routine should   be followed even on the days off from work.

Question: I am   a shift worker and often fall asleep while working. I cannot sleep during the   day and it is creating problems. I donâ€™t know what to do.
Answer: As it was mentioned before the trick is to get   adequate sleep. If you are keen on working at night, first develop a positive   attitude. Many great inventions and artistic creations have been developed   burning the midnight oil. Follow a specific routine. Try to keep yourself alert   at night by taking short breaks from work and exercising. In your time off from   work get the required amount of sleep. If in spite of repeated attempts you are   not able to adapt to your work, the only option left is to leave shift work.

Question: How are circadian rhythms  studied?
Answer: Humans or model organisms that have   similar â€œclockâ€� genes are used to study circadian rhythms. The researchers   control the subjectâ€™s environment by altering light and dark periods to look for   changes in gene activity.

Question: Will studying about   circadian rhythm contribute to human   health?
Answer: Learning about biological clocks helps in   the treatment for sleep disorders and learning about the genes responsible helps   in understanding the biological systems in the human body.

Question: Which Doctor should I Consult for Claustrophobia?
Answer: A psychologist or psychiatrist can be consulted for Claustrophobia.

Question: How can I Overcome Panic Attacks?
Answer: Relaxation is the best technique to overcome panic attacks. It releases muscular tension and reduces the strength of a panic attack. Reading books and yoga can help in relaxation.

Question: How do You Differ Normal Fear and Phobia?
Answer: Children may feel afraid to enter a dark room or be alone in someplace. This does not mean that they have a phobia. Childhood fears are natural but if they tend to avoid those situations even after growing up, then you must consider it as a phobia.

Question: Which is Better: Self-Help or Therapy for Claustrophobia?
Answer: Self-Help will suit phobias wherein controlling yourself may make you feel comfortable in a particular situation, but claustrophobia causes pain attack, which is more serious. Therefore, therapy is best for claustrophobia as it will have a great track record and involves about four to six sessions.

Question: Which doctor should be consulted for Cleidocranial Dysplasia?
Answer: If the dentist diagnoses the condition, then he will refer to an orthopedic doctor, an orthdontic surgeon or a cosmetic surgeon depending on the priority.

Question: Is there any way to prevent Cleidocranial Dysplasia?
Answer: Since the disease is transmitted genetically Cleidocranial Dysplasia cannot be prevented.

Question: Is Cleidocranial Dysplasia fatal?
Answer: No, there is no evidence to prove that the disease is a primary cause of death. People with CCD can be expected to lead a normal, productive life with symptomatic management.

Question: Will my children inherit the condition if I have CCD?
Answer: This is usually an inherited condition. There is a 50% chance that a child will have it. Two-thirds causes of the condition are genetic.

Question: Will my children get the condition if I do not have CCD?
Answer: This is a rare condition and it is unlikely for it to happen in your child. However if it does happen it is due to the mutation of a gene and is called a spontaneous genetic mutation. However the chances of having another child with it are very small.

Question: Will everyone know my details ?
Answer: No, The trial reports never have any patients names or other details that could identify you. The data is maintained strictly confidential.

Question: What are the Benefits and Risks of Participating in Clinical Trials?
Answer: According to the type and purpose of the trial, the benefits and risks vary significantly.

Question: Can I be withdrawn from the study at any point of time?
Answer: Possible Benefits of Trials

Question: Would I receive any compensation if I participate in a trial?
Answer: Possible Risks of Trials

Question: Would I receive any medical compensation in case of an adverse event?
Answer: Access to currently available therapies that could be potentially more effective compared to already available therapies.

Question: Which doctor should I see for clubfoot?
Answer: You should see a pediatric orthopedic surgeon.Physiotherapy also has a role in treating clubfoot.

Question: How long should the treatment continue?
Answer: There are chances for the deformity to relapse even though it is corrected. So the child needs continuous check up and treatment throughout his growing age.

Question: Can surgery be done immediately to the newborn baby, as soon as the clubfoot is detected?
Answer: No, surgery is done, only when the conservative treatment fails for the child. The child should be of sufficient size so that the structures like bones, tendons, ligaments, muscles can be identified, during surgery for correction. The right age for surgery is six months of age and above.

Question: What happens if the clubfoot is left untreated?
Answer: If clubfoot is left untreated, the child's foot will be automatically turned inwards and the child will not be able to place his foot flat on the ground and finds difficult to walk. The child may begin to walk on the outer surface of the foot and the toes. This causes hardening of the skin and development of corns and ulcers over the outer border of the foot. Wearing shoes becomes difficult, and over a period of time it may become a crippling and unsightly condition.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for a cochlear implant?
Answer: An ENT specialist and an audiologist are involved together to determine the eligibility of the cochlear implant surgery. An ENT specialist will perform the surgery and the fine-tuning or mapping of the device and further auditory and speech training is given by the audiologist and the speech and language therapist.

Question: Do I have the freedom of choosing the brand of cochlear implant device?
Answer: The brand of the cochlear implant has to be selected after a thorough discussion with the cochlear implant team â€“ the ENT specialist and the audiologist. This is because the features of the device must match the userâ€™s hearing requirements. The cochlear implant team helps you to make informed decisions about the device options and further care and rehabilitation.

Question: Can I wear my cochlear implant device during shower or swimming?
Answer: Water resistant cochlear implant devices are now available in the market. While choosing the model of the cochlear implant, discuss the possibilities of water-proof devices with your physician and therapist.

Question: Will my insurance plan cover cochlear implant cost?
Answer: Many insurance plans cover the cost of cochlear implants as it has been proven that they improve the quality of life.

Question: Which is more economical for a child born with hearing impairment â€“ hearing aid rehabilitation or cochlear implant and its training?
Answer: A group of scientists, supported by National Institutes of Health, have made a comparison of costs of both the issues. They have reported that the cost of cochlear implant (surgery, mapping and training included) is about $60,000, while the hearing aids, therapy, services, special education, adaptation and integration of a hearing impaired child is more than $1million before the age of three years.

Question: Can cochlear implants cure deafness?
Answer: A cochlear implant does not cure hearing impairment or deafness, but is a prosthetic substitute which stimulates the cochlea (auditory portion of the inner ear).

Question: How long is the recovery period?
Answer: Children bounce back from cochlear implant surgery quickly. Usually they return to work after one week, but exercise and other forms of physical activity should be limited for 3 weeks.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Coffin-Lowry syndrome?
Answer: For this syndrome, a well-qualified, experienced and trained physician in the field of genetics needs to be consulted. In addition, consultations with other specialists can be done based on the specific requirement.

Question: How common is Coffin-Lowry syndrome?
Answer: The exact incidence of Coffin-Lowry syndrome is not known, but it is rare and is estimated to affect about 1 in 40,000 to 50,000 people.

Question: How is Coffin-Lowry syndrome inherited?
Answer:
Coffin-Lowry syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. In an X-linked inheritance, the mutated gene causing the disorder is present on X-chromosome (one of the two sex chromosome). Males have one X chromosome and one Y chromosome, while females have 2 X chromosomes in each cell. This means that all males with the defect will suffer from the condition. Since the defect is â€˜dominantâ€™, even if it is present only on one X chromosome, the female will also suffer from the syndrome. However, since the gene on the other X chromosome in the female may be normal, the symptoms may not be very severe.

A male passes his X chromosome to his daughter and Y chromosome to his son. Thus, the daughter of an affected male can inherit the condition. On the other hand, the son does not get the defective gene and will be free from the syndrome.

However, it has been noted that most people who suffer from the syndrome do not have a documented family history of the condition.

Question: What other names are used for Coffin-Lowry syndrome?
Are there any organizations/support groups for Coffin-Lowry syndrome?
What are the different terms used for cold intolerance?
Answer: Cold intolerance is also known as cold allodynia, trauma-induced cold-associated symptoms (TICAS), cold hypersensitivity, abnormal cold intolerance (ABCI), and cold sensitivity.

Question: Does cold intolerance have an impact on the quality of life of an individual?
Answer: Yes, cold intolerance could affect people who work in cold environments forcing them to opt for other careers.

Question: Are there alternative forms of treatment for cold intolerance?
Answer: Currently, there are no specific treatments other than symptom-relieving management techniques for cold intolerance. Alternative therapies, such as reflexology and traditional chinese medicine are also being used to treat cold intolerance.

Question: Who should I consult if my baby is crying continuously?
Answer: If conservative measures do not help and the baby continues to cry then you should consult your pediatrician or child specialist to rule out other underlying causes.

Question: How can you tell if your baby has colic?
Answer: The diagnosis of colic is made only after ensuring that the child is well nourished with a healthy weight gain and not suffering from any other acute or chronic disease conditions. All other possible causes of the babyâ€™s discomfort and crying episodes have to be ruled out before confirming this diagnosis.

Question: Can breastfed babies have colic?
Answer: Colic is seen in healthy babies. A child who is breast fed adequately may also have colic. In some cases avoiding dairy products, nuts, wheat, eggs in breastfeeding mothers have found to reduce colic in child. But if the colic persists then the mother may revert to a normal diet.

Question: How do you stop a colicky baby from crying?
Answer: Soothing the baby, checking whether the child is cold, wet or hungry and providing comfort to the baby with additional support from family members will help in reducing crying episodes. At times, all these measures may be futile, the parents should understand that this is a temporary condition which will resolve.

Question: How long does colic last?
Answer: Colic in a healthy baby will improve on its own and often lasts for upto 3 to 6 months. This is one of the major challenges face in the early phase of parenthood.

Question: Who treats colorectal cancers?
Answer: A general surgeon or a gastroenterologist or a Colo-rectal Surgeon treats colorectal cancers.

Question: What are the early symptoms of colorectal cancer?
Answer: The early symptoms of colorectal cancer are unexplained weight loss, change in bowel habits from what is considered normal for a given individual - either constipation or diarrhea - unexplained anemia (low blood count), and visible blood in the stool. It is also important to remember that colon cancer may be silent and not associated with any symptoms.

Question: Does blood in the stool always indicate colorectal cancer?
Answer: Blood in the stool could also be due to hemorrhoids, anal fissures or tears, infections of the colon, inflammatory bowel diseases, and colonic diverticula. Blood in the stool may also occur from lesions in the stomach and small intestine such as peptic ulcer disease, and Crohn's disease.

Question: Looking at the rectal bleeding is it possible to identify its source?
Answer: It may not be possible; bleeding from hemorrhoids and anal fissures is usually bright red, while that from colorectal cancers is occult (hidden). But rectal bleeding of any amount is never normal and should not be ignored, as some causes of rectal bleeding such as colon cancer are more serious than others. So consult your doctor and get the bleeding properly checked out.

Question: What is the best colon cancer-screening test?
Answer: Colonoscopy is considered to be the "gold standard." It is the only method that has a high sensitivity for all polyps, both small and large, and which presents the capability of removing them at the time of the procedure.

Question: Can young people below the age of thirty with no positive family history get colorectal cancer?
Answer: In general, it is very uncommon for young people to get colorectal cancer. However, there are two well-recognized hereditary syndromes namely Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) and Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC) in which cancer can develop in young people.

Question: What are the options available for those people with a positive family history?
Answer: If a positive family history is present, children at risk may be screened for a gene mutation with a genetic test. They should also start having sigmoidoscopies or colonoscopies starting at 10 or 12 years of age and repeated every 6 to 12 months to look for the presence of polyps. Once numerous polyps start developing surgery is planned. The good news about these diseases is that the surgical options are very good and now the colon can often be removed by a mini-or laparoscopic approach. The bowel is put directly back together and no bag is necessary. People move their bowels normally.

Question: What effect does diabetes have on colon cancer?
Answer: People with diabetes have a greater chance of developing colon cancer. They also tend to have lower survival rates and higher recurrence rates.

Question: How does smoking increase colon cancer risk?
Answer: There are two ways by which smoking can affect the colon. Tobacco smoke transports carcinogens to the colon and tobacco use increases the size of polyps.

Question: I was diagnosed with colon cancer a year ago; how often should I have a blood test?
Answer: You should have a CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen) blood test every three months for the first two years after your cancer diagnosis, then every six months for about five years after that. CEA testing, combined with CT (computed tomographic) scans, can improve survival rates.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for coloboma?
Answer: You should consult and eye doctor (ophthalmologist).

Question: How can I prevent coloboma in my baby?
Answer: Coloboma caused due to an inheritable genetic defect cannot be prevented. But environmental factors can definitely be controlled. Avoidance of exposure to alcohol and Vitamin A supplementation during pregnancy can help reduce the chances of coloboma.

Question: What doctor should I consult?
Answer: A surgeon or a gastroenterologist can manage colon polyps. Further references are decided by him as and when required (in the case of a cancer, for example, the service of an Oncologist is required).

Question: Do colon polyps recur even after complete removal?
Answer: Yes they can.

Question: What does the future hold for prevention of colon polyps?
Answer: Attempts to develop a radiologic colonoscopic test for screening and surveillance of polyps are going on. Authentic results are awaited.

Question: What about genetic counselling?
Answer: As already mentioned in the article, colon polyps can run in families. Hence an incident of colon polyps calls in for genetic counselling.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for color blindness?
Answer: An Ophthalmologist can help in diagnosis and management of color blindness.

Question: Should I train myself for passing any type of Color Blindness Test?
Answer: There is no training required for passing any type of color blindness test. The tests involve detecting the innate ability of the eyes to identify and discriminate colors.

Question: Is color corrective lens useful in the management of color blindness?
Answer:
A few persons with color blindness may find that using color corrective lenses may make their vision brighter and more vivid. They may perceive certain colors for the first time.

For people who find corrective lenses beneficial, it may help in their workplaces like computers and electronics, graphics and fine arts.

Question: Is color blindness a disease?
Answer: Color blindness is not a disease. It is a condition that results from wrong coding of the cone cells of the retina due to altered genetic makeup. The condition is not progressive, that is, it does not deteriorate with age or time. It is not infectious and there is no known cure for the same.

Question: Are animals and birds color blind?
Answer:
Different animals and birds have varying degrees and different types of color blindness.

Dogs, cats and mice see mostly grays, some blues and yellows. Bulls see only black and white shades. Some animals like squirrels, monkeys and insects see a good range of color. Pigeons are known to be the best at color detection among all creatures on earth.

Question: What doctors and specialists can treat colorectal cancer?
Answer: A team of surgical oncologist, gastroenterologist, practologists (colorectal surgeons) can treat colorectal cancer

Question: What is a polyp?
Answer: Polyps are mushroom-like growths that form when cells lining the colon grow, divide and reproduce in an unhealthy, disorderly way. They can become cancerous over time, and invade the colon wall and surrounding blood vessels.

Question: My doctor removed an adenoma during a colonoscopy procedure I had. What is an adenoma?
Answer: While an adenoma is a benign polyp or a non-cancerous growth in the lining of the large intestine, they are considered to be precursors of colon and rectal cancer.

Question: Should I be afraid if I find a little bit of blood in my stool. Could I have colorectal cancer?
Answer: A number of different conditions can cause blood to appear in your stool. It is still best to get it checked by the doctor as bleeding is one of the earliest signs of colorectal cancer.

Question: How long does a colonoscopy procedure take?
Answer: The procedure typically lasts between 15 and 30 minutes. When complete, your nurse will take you into a recovery area, where the sedation quickly wears off.

Question: Are there any drugs available that can help prevent colorectal cancer?
Answer: Chemoprevention or the use of drugs to prevent cancer from developing in the first place is being researched and anti-inflammatory drugs that helped keep intestinal tumors from forming have been found, albeit with some side effects.

Question: Which doctor should I visit for screening for colorectal cancer?
Answer: You should visit your general physician or gastroenterologist for the screening test.

Question: Which test should I opt for screening for colorectal cancer?
Answer: The choice of screening test depends on a number of factors. First of all, the test should be available in your area. Secondly, it depends on your personal preference. Before deciding, you should also consider which test will diagnose your condition better â€“ for example, a stool test may be very easy to perform, but its accuracy is much less than that of a colonoscopy.

Question: Why should a fecal occult blood test be done yearly whereas a colonoscopy every 10 years?
Answer: A fecal occult blood test is not as sensitive as a colonoscopy to detect colorectal cancers. A fecal occult blood test comes positive only if there is bleeding from the polyp or cancer, which occurs intermittently. On the other hand, a colonoscopy involves a complete direct examination of the lining of the colon and rectum. Hence, a fecal occult blood test should be done more often than a colonoscopy.

Question: Which doctor should I visit to get a colonoscopy done?
Answer: You should visit a gastroenterologist to get a colonoscopy done. The success of the procedure, that is, the chances of detecting a cancerous lesion, depends on the skill of the examiner; hence it would be better to get the test done by an expert with adequate experience in the field.

Question: What is the difference between flexible sigmoidoscopy and colonoscopy?
Answer: Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a faster procedure compared to colonoscopy. It does not require sedation and the person can return to work soon after the procedure. In contrast, colonoscopy takes longer time and requires sedation. Some people may prefer to be sedated, thus this could be an advantage in such patients. Colonoscopy permits examination of the entire colon whereas in sigmoidoscopy, only the lower portion of the colon is examined. Thus a number of cancers especially those on the right side could be missed in flexible sigmoidoscopy. Flexible sigmoidoscopy should be repeated every 5 years whereas colonoscopy every 10 years.

Question: Which doctor should I visit to get a double-contrast barium enema done?
Answer: You should visit your health care provider if you are interested in getting a Double-contrast barium enema done. He will refer you to a radiological center that carries out this test.

Question: What is the difference between single contrast and double-contrast barium enema?
Answer: Single contrast barium enema is a procedure where only a barium enema is administered to the patient and the images thus obtained studied. In double-contrast barium enema, following the barium enema, air is introduced through the anus. This causes the barium to coat the lining of the colon in a single layer and allows better visualization of any abnormalities in the wall of the colon.

Question: How long will the procedure take?
Answer: It may take from 1 to 2 hours to do the procedure.

Question: Is the procedure likely to cause pain?
Answer: The procedure is not painful but may cause some degree of discomfort You will have a digital rectal examination followed by insertion of a soft tube in your rectum.

Question: Which doctor should I visit to get flexible sigmoidoscopy done?
Answer: You should visit a gastroenterologist to get a flexible sigmoidoscopy done. Sometimes, general practitioners may also do the procedure.

Question: Is there anything called rigid sigmoidoscopy?
Answer: Rigid sigmoidoscopes are also available, but flexible sigmoidoscopes are preferred since they allow better visualization of the inner lining of the large intestine with minimal discomfort to the patient.

Question: What is the difference between flexible sigmoidoscopy and colonoscopy?
Answer: Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a faster procedure compared to colonoscopy. It does not require sedation and the person can return to work soon after the procedure. In contrast, colonoscopy takes longer time and requires sedation. However, colonoscopy permits examination of the entire colon whereas in sigmoidoscopy, only the last part of the colon is examined. Thus a number of cancers especially those on the right side could be missed in flexible sigmoidoscopy. Flexible sigmoidoscopy should be repeated every 5 years whereas colonoscopy every 10 years.

Question: Which doctor prescribes anticoagulants?
Answer: Anticoagulants will usually be prescribed by the cardiologist or other specialist doctors treating the condition that requires anticoagulation.

Question: Among the anticoagulants currently available, which can be taken orally?
Answer: Warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, edoxaban and apixaban can be taken orally.

Question: Which specialist should I consult to treat liver diseases?
Answer: Liver diseases are treated by a hepatologist or a gastroenterologist. A liver transplant is performed by a liver transplant surgeon.

Question: Is there an entity such as a toxic hepatitis?
Answer: When the liver is exposed to certain harmful chemical substances, there is an inflammatory reaction called toxic hepatitis. It can be caused by alcohol, drugs like acetaminophen, and even some nutrients. The toxic hepatitis may occur in a matter of hours or may take months to develop. The inflammatory response may subside once the exposure to the drug ceases or may lead to permanent damage and scarring of the liver.

Question: How does the concept of live donor work in liver transplant?
Answer: Unlike kidneys where a person can donate one of his kidneys, a live liver donor donates a part of his liver to the recipient. The interesting thing is that the liver has a remarkable capacity for regeneration and it grows back to its original size in the donor and to the normal in the recipient as well.

Question: What are MELD and PELD scores?
Answer:
MELD is Model End stage Liver Disease and PELD is Pediatric End stage Liver Disease.

The MELD score is used for persons above 12 years and PELD score is used for children below 12 years.

When a person is assigned to a waiting list for liver transplant, the MELD /PELD scores are calculated to determine how urgently the person needs the transplant i.e the probability of his dying within 90 days without a transplant.

The MELD score ranges between 6 to 40, and a higher score indicated more urgency.

Patients with acute liver failure likely to die within a week without a liver transplant are accorded the highest priority.

Question: Are there any contraindications to a liver transplant?
Answer: A person with liver failure might be considered unfit to undergo a liver transplant for the following reasons.

Question: What is hepatic encephalopathy?
Which doctor would I consult for compartment syndrome?
Answer: Your family doctor might initially see you for the symptoms. He may later refer you to an orthopedic surgeon, podiatrist or a doctor specializing in sports medicine for further treatment.

Question: When should I seek medical care for compartment syndrome?
Answer: You should seek medical care immediately if you experience any unusual pain, swelling, numbness, tingling, weakness or soreness mainly in the legs or arms while doing any activity or exercise or after an injury. Remember, these symptoms may be associated with conditions that may require immediate medical treatment. Ignoring these symptoms and exercising through the pain could lead to permanent muscle or nerve damage.

Question: What are the associated risks if I donâ€™t get medical help on time to treat compartment syndrome?
Answer: If treatment is delayed for any reason, then you could have irreversible muscle and nerve damage. If left untreated, it can cause lasting damage; you may need to have part of the injured arm or leg removed. You could also experience heart problems, infection, rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown) and kidney damage.

Question: Can surgery be done on both legs at the same time if you have compartment syndrome in both?
Answer: Generally, surgery is performed on one leg at a time. There should be a minimum of six weeks of time between surgeries to make sure there is complete healing and recovery.

Question: When can I expect complete recovery from surgery?
Answer: The recovery from surgery depends upon the amount of dead tissue present. If the surgeon finds no dead tissue at the time of fasciotomy, then you can expect to have full recovery soon, however if he does then recovery can take approximately 1 to 2 months.

Question: Would the compartment syndrome recur after surgery?
Answer: Few cases of recurrence of compartment syndrome have been reported, however they are quite rare.

Question: Which doctor should I consult forchronic regional pain syndrome?
Answer: You can initially consult your familyphysician or GP who can treat the condition with pain killers and refer you tophysiotherapy. For persistent severe pain you will be referred to a painspecialist for evaluation and management.

Question: Can chronic regional pain syndrome be cured?
Answer: There is no cure for CRPS. However withmedications, physiotherapy and counseling most patients experience significantimprovement in their symptoms. A few patients suffer from severe persistentsymptoms.

Question: Am I eligible for disability benefits if I am diagnosed with CRPS?
Answer: You might be eligible for Social Security disability benefits (SSD or SSI) if the pain persists even after a year. You may have to produce concrete evidence for your pain complaints.

Question: What is the difference between CRPS and reflex sympathetic dystrophy?
Answer: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS)Type 1 is otherwise referred to as reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome. Experts believe that RSD occurs due to dysfunction of the nervous system leading to excessive impulses being sent to the affected site resulting in chronic pain.

Question: Can CRPS be caused by autoimmune disease?
Answer: One of the theories suggested for CRPS is an autoimmune cause. If autoimmunity is suspected, testing for autoantibodies(antinuclear antibody) may be performed.

Question: Which doctors treat compound fractures?
Answer: An orthopedic surgeon treats compound fractures. Depending upon the severity of the injury other specialists like vascular surgeon or plastic surgeon may be also be involved in the treatment.

Question: What is the treatment of choice for compound fractures?
Answer: Compound fractures require urgent treatment to clean the area of injury of any infective material, and surgery to stabilize the fractured bones. Debriding and irrigating the wound decreases the risk of infection.

Question: What are the complications associated with compound fractures?
Answer: Complications associated with compound fractures include infection including bone infection, delayed healing, and a build-up of pressure within muscles that could result in tissue damage.

Question: Which doctor does a CT scan?
Answer: This radiological procedure is done by a qualified radiologist.

Question: How is a CT scan better than X ray?
Answer: The imaging done by CT scan is far more accurate and detailed than that of an X-Ray, which helps in better diagnosis.

Question: When is it advisable to opt for a CT scan?
Answer: CT scan is often in the last layer of diagnosis and should be used only when the doctor feels it is absolutely necessary.

Question: How safe are CT scans especially for children?
Answer: CT scans are often considered unsafe because of the high amount of radiation involved in it. There may be some skin irritation, rashes involved, also the chances of getting cancer increases. Hence it should be wisely used especially in the case of children as they are much more vulnerable.

Question: Do the contrast materials used in CT scanning cause allergies?
Answer: Contrast materials may cause allergies to some people who are sensitive. Hence the physicians advise them to take allergy medications much before the actual scan.

Question: Can pregnant women undergo CT scanning?
Answer: Generally best avoided as the radiation dose can potentially harm the fetus and is much higher than a plain X-ray. Alternatives include ultrasonography and MRI as they are not associated with known adverse fetal effects. However if CT cannot be avoided, it is advisable to inform the radiologist beforehand to take proper precautions to ensure extra care and safety.

Question: What if I am claustrophobic - can the CT scan procedure heighten my Claustrophobia?
Answer:
Generally MRI procedures cause much more problems with claustrophobia then CT scan procedures. 
However if you suffer from claustrophobia the CT scan procedure can make you more anxious. If you are concerned, it maybe best to do some breathing exercise or consult your psychiatrist before the procedure. Sometimes drugs may help calm down your nerves. The good thing about CT is that the procedure takes only one to five minutes. Also the CT tube is wider and during the test the table moves and you are not just lying still.

MRI procedure can take 30 to 40 minutes and you have to lie still on the table, hence the aggravation of claustrophobia is much more.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Computer vision syndrome (CVS)?
Answer: An eye doctor (ophthalmologist) should be consulted for CVS.

Question: Is Computer Vision Syndrome permanent?
Answer: Computer vision syndrome does not cause permanent damage.

Question: How long does computer vision syndrome last?
Answer: The computer vision syndrome may last from few minutes to couple of hours after stopping the use of computer. However symptoms may intensify with continuing usage of computers.

Question: Who can be affected by CVS?
Answer: People who work at the computer for more than three hours a day are mostly affected by CVS.

Question: Is there any age limit for CVS?
Answer: No. All age groups are affected by CVS.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
Answer: You should consult an endocrinologist (a doctor specializing in hormone therapy).

Question: Can congenital adrenal hyperplasia be dangerous?
Answer: Yes. This can be life-threatening in case of the classic or severe form of CAH when there is an adrenal crisis.

Question: Is congenital adrenal hyperplasia hereditary?
Answer: Yes, is it an autosomal recessive condition.

Question: What is the prevalence of congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
Answer: Classic CAH occurs in 1:15000 births, while the non-classic form occurs in 1:1000 births worldwide.

Question: Can congenital adrenal hyperplasia be considered a disability?
Answer: Not in the true sense of the term. But since the condition can sometimes cause infertility, it may be regarded as a disability.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for my unborn child, if my previous baby is diagnosed of having a birth defect?
Answer: You can consult a genetic counselor and a pediatric cardiologist.

Question: Who are the specialists involved with heart defects?
Answer: Pediatric cardiologists specialize in the care of babies and children who have heart problems while cardiac surgeons are specialists who repair heart defects using surgery.

Question: What is the prognosis for babies born with congenital heart defects?
Answer: Surgery to repair heart defects is required only twenty five percent of children in the United States. Most babies born with a CHD can live up to at least 18 years of age due to advancements in diagnosis and treatments available. However, if the defect is severe, chances of reaching adulthood becomes rarer.

Question: Are all types of heart diseases congenital in nature?
Answer: No, but most of them are. Rarely, heart damage due to an infection could give rise to heart disease. This is an â€œacquiredâ€� form of the disease as opposed to congenital. Examples are Kawasaki disease and rheumatic fever. Sometimes, children can be born with or acquire heart problems like arrhythmia or irregular heartbeats.

Question: Has there been considerable progress in the prognosis of congenital heart defects?
Answer: Definitely. The overall mortality calculated as the risk of dying after a congenital heart surgery was about 30% in the 1960s and 1970s whereas it is around 5% now.

Question: Can children born with these defects lead a normal life?
Answer: Most children with simple defects survive into adulthood and lead normal lives although they may need restrictions in exercises and sports that might cause a strain to their heart. In severe defects, children can present themselves with some developmental delay or other leaning difficulties.

Question: What are some of the financial impacts of congenital heart defects on families?
Answer: Families undergo a lot of emotional and financial pressure especially if the defect is serious and warrants specialized treatments and post-surgery care. Extensive financial resources are sometimes needed both while in and out of the hospital. Families need some kind of assistance to cope in such circumstances.

Question: What is infective endocarditis?
Answer: Children with severe heart defects are at a risk for infective endocarditis, that is, an infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves. Regular brushing and regular visits to the dentists are important so as to not allow bacteria to get into the system.

Question: Who operates on children with septal defects?
Answer: A cardio-thoracic surgeon with interest in pediatric cardiac surgery usually operate on the patients.

Question: Who follows up these children?
Answer: A pediatric cardiologist (physician) follows up the children.

Question: What are holes in the heart?
Answer: Atrial and ventricular septal defects are the most common forms of congenital heart disease. They are generally called as hole(s) in the heart. A septum is a wall separating the left and right side of the heart. The atrial septum separates the atria or the upper chambers. The ventricular septum separates the ventricles or the lower chambers.

Question: How do they form?
Answer: There are no definite answers as to why a septal defect was formed. But, studies have shown relationship of genes responsible in the development of the heart is found on chromosome 21. Also half of the patients with Downâ€™s syndrome have septal defects and about 25% of patients with septal defects have Downâ€™s syndrome. Sometimes septal defects can be hereditary or due to environmental causes. There can be children with septal defects without any genetic reasons.

Question: Can pregnant women have chest x-rays?
Answer: Some doctors believe that no diagnostic X-rays can increase the chances of having a fetus with congenital problems. This risk is reported to as less as one in a million. To be on the safe side, a pregnant woman should postpone her elective X-rays. If it is must then the uterus can be shielded during all X-rays. Risk is high for lower back, abdominal or pelvic x-rays. If possible, these tests should be replaced with a less ionizing radiation test like ultrasound.

Question: Are congenital abnormalities common in babies of women over 40 years of age?
Answer: Most women over 40 years of age have normal pregnancies. Yet, they are more prone to have babies with congenital defect, mostly relating to chromosomal abnormalities (e.g. Downâ€™s syndrome). There are tests like amniocentesis that can diagnose these conditions prenatally.

Question: Which doctor should I consult if I want to rule out congenital hypothyroidism in my baby?
Answer: You should see a pediatric endocrinologist. The diagnosis should be made before 2 weeks of age to initiate therapy immediately.

Question: I am pregnant. How can I prevent congenital hypothyroidism in my baby?
Answer: Take iodine supplemented salt to prevent iodine deficiency. If you are taking any drugs for thyroid disease or any other conditions, consult an endocrinologist for further advice.

Question: My first child was diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism. What are the chances that another child will be affected similarly?
My son was diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism at birth. Should I be worried?
Are there any long term complications of taking thyroid hormones?
Answer:
If the condition was diagnosed early, it usually leads to a good outcome. Newborns diagnosed and treated within the first month or so usually have normal intelligenceHowever, as a group such children tend to show lower academic performance compared to siblings and mild learning disabilities may occur in some.

Continue to have regular check-ups with the pediatric endocrinologist and do thyroid hormone measurements periodically. Thyroid hormones have to be taken for life.

Question: Which specialist doctor should be consulted for Congo Fever?
Answer: You should see a general physician or an internist or a family physician or an Infectious disease specialist.

Question: What are the possible sources of infection of Congo Fever ?
Answer: Congo fever or CCHF occurs by contact with infectious blood, body fluids, due to improper sterilization of medical instruments, reuse of injection needles, and contamination of medical supplies.

Question: Who are the people who are at the most risk to get Congo fever?
Answer: The majority of cases occur among those who work in livestock industry, such as agricultural workers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians.

Question: If I am exposed to blood or tissue of Congo fever patient what precautions are required?
Answer: You should take daily temperature for at least 2 weeks to ensure that you are not likely to get the fever.

Question: Can death occur from Congo Fever?
Answer: Yes it has been reported in 9% to as high as 50% of the cases but early diagnosis and proper treatment can lower this rate. Treatment should include fluid and electrolyte balance, oxygen and antibiotics for secondary infections. Antiviral drug ribavirin should be started as soon as the diagnosis is established.

Question: Is there a Vaccine for Congo Fever prevention?
Answer: No vaccine has so far been developed.

Question: Which type of ticks is responsible for Congo fever?
Answer: Prof. Bob Swanepoel of the National Institute for Virology in Johannesburg a pioneer in the research of Congo fever says- "The world distribution of CCHF virus coincides pretty well with the distribution of Hyalomma ticks (Africa, eastern Europe and Asia). Locally, Hyalomma species are called "bontpootluise". "Bont" means multicolored or variegated, and refers to the reddish-brown and white bands on the legs of ticks of the genus Hyalomma.â€� Other ticks can transmit, but this is rare.

Question: Which doctor should I go to if I have conjunctivitis | Pink Eye?
Answer: You can consult a general physician or an Ophthalmologist.

Question: How is infectious Conjunctivitis | Pink Eye treated?
Answer: Infectious conjunctivitis, caused by bacteria, is usually treated with antibiotic eye drops and/or ointment. Other infectious forms, caused by viruses, canâ€™t be treated with antibiotics.

Question: What is Conjunctivitis?
Answer: Conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva, a thin, transparent layer covering the surface of the inner eyelid and the front of the eye. It affects people of all ages.

Question: What is Giant papillary Conjunctivitis (GPC) ?
Answer: Giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC) is a form of allergic conjunctivitis most often seen in soft contact lens wearers. People with asthma, hay fever or animal allergies may be at greater risk. The cause of GPC is probably an allergic reaction to collected debris on contact lenses.
