Question: What are the Important things to take into Account When Switching Policy to another Company ?
Answer: Before switching it is important to do good homework and have a valid reason to switch. Some of reasons to switch may include the following:

Question: How Will Portability Help Customers?
What If Customer Applies For An Increased Sum Insured In The New Policy?
Answer: Portability will empower unsatisfied consumers to move to an Insurance Company of their choice. Especially in the Retail segment, Portability will bring in more competitive environment and better service experience.  In the current scenario, renewal of health policies can become a headache for the customers. In the portability scenario in the long run, Insurance Companies will have to win their renewals through better service, responsiveness and claims experience. The no. of policies an insurer is able to retain will reflect the customer satisfaction.

Question: What can be the Impact on Premiums?
Answer: For instance, if the customer has a policy which has been continuously renewed for the last 5 years and has a sum insured of Rs. 2 lakhs and now he / she wants to port the policy to another insurance company with a higher sum insured of say Rs. 5 lakhs the portability relief in waiting periods in the new policy would only be to the extent of Rs. 2 lakhs sum insured.  The waiting periods for the additional sum insured of Rs. 3 lakhs would be similar to a fresh policy.

Question: Are Insurers Bound To Accept a Proposal For Portability? Can they Reject It?
Answer:
There is a good chance of a price war in the younger age segment. Insurers could slash premiums in the lower age bands to attract portability of existing customers.  On the other hand, portability are not likely to help policy holders in the older age bands (say, 50 and above) and policyholders who suffer from pre-existing ailments. As such proposals are likely to be denied by the new Insurance Company.

Senior citizens and people with pre-existing ailments (especially chronic ones) would not benefit a lot from portability.

Question: How Will Data Sharing Between Insurance Cos: Affect Consumer / Industry?
Answer: The proposal and underwriting processes of Insurance companies will not change due to portability. The sum insured in the expiring policy cannot be the basis of what the new insurer will be ready to accept. The acceptance of risk would depend on the normal risk underwriting process. In fact, due to an already existing policy being declared for portability, the underwriting could demand additional claims history information for the past policies from the customer.Once the proposal is accepted, the waiting period credits would have to be given in the new policy. The underwriter of the insurance company will continue to hold the discretion to deny a proposal.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for understanding these concepts better?
Answer: A lifestyle medicine doctor would ideally help you to understand these concepts better.

Question: How will I know if my health-related quality of life (HRQOL) is deteriorating?
Answer: You may experience symptoms related to your physical, mental, and emotional well-being, as well as losing interest in interacting socially.

Question: What should I do if I suspect that my HRQOL is deteriorating?
Answer: First consult your family physician, who will thoroughly examine you and if required, refer you to a specialist according to your ailment.

Question: How can I improve my HRQOL?
Answer: You can improve your HRQOL by following a healthy lifestyle â€“ eating a balanced and nutritious diet, doing regular physical exercise, performing yoga and meditation for mental well-being, and having regular health check-ups for early detection of disease.

Question: Whom should I consult while buying a cell phone if I am using a hearing aid?
Answer: You should inform the cell phone sales person if you are wearing a hearing aid to make sure you get a phone that is hearing aid compatible. You can also consult your audiologist to make sure that the hearing aid will be compatible with the cell phone.

Question: How do I know if a cell phone is compatible with my hearing aid?
Answer: The product label on the cell phone will indicate if the phone is compatible with a hearing aid. A cell phone â€“hearing aid combined score also helps to indicate clarity. However, each personâ€™s experience with the phone is different, and therefore, it is necessary to try the phone before you buy it.

Question: Do cell phones compatible with hearing aids look different from other phones?
Answer: No, cell phones compatible with hearing aids look similar to other phones available in the market.

Question: Which doctor should I visit to get a hearing test done for my baby?
Answer: If you wish to get a hearing test done for your baby, you should visit your babyâ€™s pediatrician who will refer you to an audiologist to do the tests.

Question: What happens if my baby has a hearing problem?
Answer: If your baby has been found to have a hearing problem, treatment will depend on the individual case. Some cases may require surgery.  Some may require hearing aids.  Communication skills will also have to be taught to the infant and parents as the baby grows up.

Question: Do the hearing tests have any complications?
Answer: The hearing tests themselves do not have any complications.  Using screening tests for hearing may cause undue anxiety in the parents if the test results come positive when a hearing defect is actually absent.   Surgeries for hearing loss detected during screening may be associated with complications like meningitis.

Question: What are cochlear implants?
Answer: Cochlear implant is a surgically implanted device, which is suitable for those with damaged inner ear (cochlea). It helps people with moderate to profound hearing loss

Question: Whom should I consult when I suspect of having symptoms of heart attack?
Answer: You should consult with a cardiologist.

Question: What are the major risk factors for heart disease?
Answer: The major risk factors for heart disease are smoking, high cholesterol levels, high blood pressure, physical inactivity, obesity, diabetes, age, gender, and heredity (including race).

Question: Are women as prone to Heart Disease as men?
Answer: There is a myth that women aren't as prone to heart disease as men. This is not true. Women account for nearly half of all heart attack deaths.

Question: How do I differentiate an anginal pain from a pain caused by heart attack?
Answer: Angina is a recurring pain or discomfort in the chest that happens when some part of the heart does not receive enough blood temporarily. A person may notice it during exertion, but is usually relieved within a few minutes by resting or by taking prescribed angina medicine. However, the symptoms of heart attack lasts longer and are not relieved by rest or pain medications.

Question: What are various tests available to detect heart attacks?
Answer: Electrocardiograms, blood tests, coronary angiography, cardiac catheterization, echocardiogram, stress tests, and MSCT angiogram can all help in diagnosis of heart attack.

Question: What are treatment options available to treat heart attack?
Answer: The treatment options include medications, angioplasty and stent placement, atherectomy and coronary artery bypass grafting. The choice of treatment will depend on the extent of the disease.

Question: Once after having a heart attack and receiving treatment will I get another attack?
Answer: Having had a treatment for heart attack does not mean that you will never have another heart attack, but certain lifestyle modifications and preventive steps taken will help reduce the risk of another attack.

Question: What are preventive measures that will help reduce the risk of heart attacks?
Answer: Lifestyle changes like quitting smoking, limiting the intake of alcohol, having a balanced diet, regular exercise and treatment of underlying conditions that increase risk of heart attack with proper medications can all help in preventing heart attacks.

Question: Which doctors treat heart cancer?
Answer: Heart cancer may be treated by a cardiac surgeon along with an oncologist.

Question: What does it mean when they say five-year survival rate?
Answer: Five-year survival is a benchmark set by physicians to understand the prognosis in a standardized manner globally. It simply means persons surviving more than five years after first diagnosis of their cancer. It is usually assessed for estimating the prognosis of the disease. It can vary amongst the different types of cancer.

Question: How do one Prevent Heart Cancer?
Answer:
Since the exact cause of primary heart cancers is not known, it is difficult to prevent them. However, we can reduce the risk of secondary heart cancers by avoiding the exposure to things that cause cancer. Stop smoking or use of tobacco products, excessive exposure to sun or radiation and other factors which can stimulate growth of cancer cells.
Regular screenings for cancer should be done such as mammogram for breast cancer, PAP smears for cervical cancer and colonoscopy for colon cancer. The earlier a tumor is detected, the better is the outcome.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for an abnormal heartbeat?
Answer: A cardiologist or Cardiac Electrophysiologist can help you in identifying the condition that is causing the abnormal heartbeat and help you manage the underlying medical condition.

Question: If I have a fast heartbeat, am I stressed out?
Answer: Heart rate goes up due to various reasons other than stress. The reasons include physical activity, fever or even during hot summer days.

Question: If my heart rate is normal, then I donâ€™t have to worry about my blood pressure.
Answer: Usually, heart rate and blood pressure rise and come down together. But when blood pressure is higher, heart rate may not go up. It is important to check the blood pressure regularly.

Question: My heartbeat seems to be erratic, like missing a beat. Do I have a heart attack?
Answer: Erratic heartbeat, also called palpitations, may occur due to various reasons that may not be essentially related to the underlying medical condition. Diet pills, fever, hyperthyroidism, menopause, stress and exercise are some of the non-medical causes of heart rate increase. However, if the palpitations are occurring without any such reasons, and are occurring for the first time, it is better to check with your doctor.

Question: Does slow heartbeat mean a weak heart?
Answer: Slow heart rate does not always indicate a weak heart. A healthy heart or a heart that is well-conditioned with a lot of physical activity can have a slow and steady heartbeat. Slow heart rates can be considered as an indication of a medical problem only when it leads to feeling dizzy, shortness of breath, pain in chest and loss of consciousness.

Question: What is the myth about baby heart rate?
Answer: It is a common myth that fetal heart rate can be used to determine the babyâ€™s sex during pregnancy. While normal fetal heart rate is between 120 to 160 beats per minute, people think that faster fetal heart rate indicates a girl and slower indicates a boy. However, no studies have conclusively proven that heart rate is a true predictor of the babyâ€™s sex.

Question: Which Doctor should I consult in case of heart murmurs?
Answer: You should consult a cardiologist in case of heart murmurs.

Question: Are all the heart murmurs hereditary?
Answer: No. Both the congenital or acquired heart conditions can cause murmurs.

Question: How do I prevent rheumatic fever?
Answer: In the case of streptococcal throat infection, take all the medications prescribed by the doctor even if you have improved in terms of symptoms.

Question: How frequent are the murmurs innocent in children?
Answer: 50% to 90% children between 4 and 7 years can have murmur with a normal heart.

Question: My child is diagnosed to have an innocent murmur, what precautions do I need to take?
Answer: No special precautions are necessary. Your child can play with other kids and have a normal life.

Question: Which doctor should I visit if I experience heartburn?
Answer: You should visit a gastroenterologist if you experience heartburn.

Question: What are the tests done to evaluate heartburn?
Answer: The doctor may do an endoscopy to evaluate the heartburn and to check for the extent of complications. Other tests include an upper GI series, esophageal manometry to measure the pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter, and pH measurements to test for gastric acid secretion and reflux into the esophagus.

Question: How is heartburn treated?
Answer: Heartburn is treated using antacids, and medications to reduce acid secretion and reduce the chances of reflux. Foods and activities that cause heartburn should be avoided. Surgery may be required in severe cases, especially in those who develop complications.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for HELLP syndrome?
Answer: If you discover any signs related to HELLP syndrome, contact your obstetrician and gynecologist.

Question: Is HELLP syndrome always associated with preeclampsia?
Answer: No. Although HELLP syndrome is a complication of preeclampsia, only about 10-20% cases of preeclampsia develop HELLP syndrome.

Question: What happens in placental abruption?
Answer: Placenta is a structure responsible for the nourishment of the developing baby. In placental abruption, the placental lining peels from the inner lining of the uterus prior to delivery.

Question: How is preeclampsia treated?
Answer: In most cases, preeclampsia is resolved after delivery of the baby. Corticosteroids are used in severe preeclampsia to improve liver and platelet function. Magnesium sulfate is the first choice of treatment to prevent seizure.

Question: How does HELLP syndrome affect babies?
Answer: HELLP syndrome can affect the survival rate of the baby after delivery as women with the syndrome tend to have premature deliveries. For example, if a child is born with a weight of more than 1000 g, the survival rate and health of a child is the same as that of one born to a non-HELLP syndrome mother. However, if the weight is less than 1000 g, then the child will need to be monitored at the hospital and further tests will be needed to ensure the safety of the child.

Question: Is there a risk of HELLP syndrome in the future?
Answer: There is a 20% chance of developing HELLP syndrome in future pregnancies.

Question: When does HELLP syndrome occur?
Answer: HELLP syndrome can occur any time after the second trimester to six months post delivery. Mostly, HELLP syndrome occurs in the third trimester and 24 to 48 hours after delivery.

Question: What can be done to prevent HELLP syndrome?
Which doctor should I consult for hematuria?
Answer: For Frank hematuria â€“ urologist should be consulted. If there is persistent micro-hematuria â€“ a Nephrologist should be consulted.

Question: How is hematuria evaluated?
Answer: Repeated urine testing is performed. If blood is found in the urine, the next step would involve a cystoscopy, which is a procedure to look inside the bladder. This can be by either a flexible or a rigid scope and maybe done as an out patient procedure. Imaging tests such as CT or MRI are also performed.

Question: What if I have blood in my urine?
Answer: Do not panic right away as most causes are not life-threatening. Make sure that you get your urine tests repeated. Your health care provider will inform you if you need to have further tests performed.

Question: Who is more likely to develop hematuria?
Answer:
People who have an enlarged prostate or urinary stones are most likely to develop hematuria. Many men over the age of 50 are at risk due to an enlarged prostate gland.
Women with urinary infections too can develop hematuria.

Question: What is a dipstick test?
Answer: The dipstick test for hematuria is simply a non-diagnostic test for hematuria. A positive result is simply a color change due to oxidation of a test strip reagent. But it is not an accurate test as a false positive can result from hemoglobinuria, myoglobinuria and menstrual blood in the urine sample. However it is a quick test and useful if once hematuria is proven by the lab test.

Question: Will I have hematuria even if I donâ€™t see blood in my urine?
Answer: Microscopic hematuria occurs when blood in the urine is invisible to the naked eye. In many cases, it goes away without causing any problems. You will never know you have it, until you get a urine test.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hemiplegia?
Answer: You should consult a neurologist.

Question: What is the difference between hemiparesis and hemiplegia?
Answer: Hemiparesis is the weakening of the muscles on one side of the body, while hemiplegia is the paralysis of one side of the body.

Question: Is there a relationship between hemiplegia and epilepsy?
Answer: Hemiplegia involves paralysis of one side of the body due to brain damage on the opposite side, whereas epilepsy is characterized predominantly by seizures due to aberrant electrical activity of the brain.

Question: Will my baby be cured from hemiplegia?
Answer: No. But there are treatment options that are available to ease some of the symptoms.

Question: Will my child have to attend a school for special kids?
Answer: Not necessarily. Most of the hemiplegic children can attend traditional schools, except those with extreme mental impairment.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hemochromatosis?
Answer: Hemochromatosis is treated by doctors of various specialties since several organs are involved. Since the liver is most commonly affected, a hepatologist would be the primary person involved in the treatment, along with a hematologist.

Question: What is the prognosis of a patient with hemochromatosis?
Answer: If hemochromatosis is detected early, treatment can be started early and organ damage can be avoided. Thus, the person can lead an almost normal life even if he/she is genetically predisposed to developing hemochromatosis. If treatment is started after the onset of symptoms but before permanent organ damage has occurred, the outlook is still positive - the patientâ€™s liver, diabetes, heart and skin changes may improve with treatment. Patients who are not treated or in later stages of the disease could die due to heart failure, liver failure or liver cancer.

Question: Should I get myself tested for the gene for hemochromatosis?
Answer: Testing for the abnormal hemochromatosis gene is not routinely recommended in normal individuals unless you have a strong family history. Even if you have the gene, you may not suffer from the condition unless you have another predisposing factor.

Question: Which doctor treats hemolytic anemia?
Answer: Hemolytic anemia is usually diagnosed by a family physician or a pediatrician, who may refer the patient to a hematologist.

Question: What is the cause of small red blood cells?
Answer: Small red blood cells, also known as microcytic anemia, appear primarily due to iron deficiency. Some of the other causes include lead toxicity, hemoglobin E disorder, chronic disease and thalassemia.

Question: What is hemolytic disease of the newborn?
Answer: Hemolytic disease of the newborn can happen when the blood groups (A, B, AB or O) or the Rh-factors (positive or negative) of the motherâ€™s and the babyâ€™s blood do not match. Symptoms most commonly occur if the mother is Rh factor negative and the baby is Rh factor positive. The motherâ€™s immune system recognizes fetusâ€™ red blood cells as foreign and starts destroying them. The typical symptoms of this form of anemia are newborn jaundice and edema. The baby is treated with blood transfusions. The Rh negative mother should receive an injection called RhoGAM to prevent hemolytic anemia in the baby.

Question: What are the possible complications of hemolytic anemia?
Answer: Patients with hemolytic anemia may suffer from gallstones and kidney failure. The low red blood cell levels can result in heart failure.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for piles?
Answer: You can consult a general surgeon.

Question: What are the complications of piles?
Answer: Complications of hemorrhoids include:

Question: What is strangulation of piles?
What is photocoagulation?
Answer: Second degree hemorrhoid after prolapse may be cupped by external anal sphincter resulting in strangulation. This is accompanied by severe pain. If not reduced promptly, clotting of blood in the piles may follow.

Question: Can hemorrhoids cause stomach cramps?
Answer: Application of infrared coagulation to hemorrhoids that do not prolapsed is called photocoagulation. This is painless and can be done in an out-patient department.

Question: How does a doctor diagnose internal hemorrhoids?
Answer: Hemorrhoids do not cause stomach cramps. Proper medication should be taken immediately if there is any signs of bleeding.

Question: Can you get hemorrhoids from sitting too long on the toilet?
Answer: Internal hemorrhoids are diagnosed by examining any abnormalities in the anal canal and rectum. The doctor may insert a gloved, lubricated finger into the rectum during a digital rectal examination.

Question: How long will it take to recover from Hemorrhoids?
Answer: Straining to have a bowel movement by sitting too long on the toilet can cause hemorrhoids.

Question: What is a Burst Hemorrhoid?
Answer: Recovery of Hemorrhoids may take few days to several months depending upon the severity and type of the hemorrhoids.

Question: What is the difference between hemorrhoid and colon polyp?
Answer: When the blood vessels of the hemorrhoids are inflamed it may rupture resulting in burst hemorrhoids

Question: What is the cost of the treatment for piles?
Answer: Hemorrhoids are external swelling of the veins outside the anus while colon polyps are benign outgrowths which may be cancerous.

Question: Which doctor should be consulted for symptoms of encephalopathy in a patient with liver disease?
Answer: If the symptoms are acute, the patient may require emergency care in the emergency department. If the symptoms are mild, they may be treated by the treating hepatologist.

Question: How does ammonia affect the brain?
Answer: Ammonia is highly toxic to the nerve cells (neurons) and the supporting cells (glial cells and astrocytes) of the brain. These cells become severely damaged leading to neurological abnormalities, seizures and finally coma.

Question: Can hepatic encephalopathy be prevented?
Answer:
There are a number of known triggers for the development of HE. It is essential that the patient is careful to avoid these triggers, and maintain a balanced and healthy diet and lifestyle to prevent HE.
Frequent assessment of neurological function is recommended to diagnose MHE, which is difficult to diagnose clinically.

Question: Is cirrhosis of the liver curable?
Answer: Cirrhosis signifies irreversible damage to the liver. The prognosis is better in patients with compensated cirrhosis who have not developed jaundice, variceal bleeding or ascites. In decompensated patients, the survival rates are poor and such patients are candidates for liver transplant.

Question: What is fetor hepaticus?
Answer: Fetor hepaticus is referred to as the â€˜breath of the deadâ€™ as it is commonly seen in end stage liver failure. The breath has a sweet fecal smell. It occurs in portal hypertension where portal blood containing thiols enter the lungs. Ammonia or ketones in the breath may also cause the distinctive odor.

Question: Which doctor can be consulted for hepatitis C treatment?
Answer: A specialist in Internal Medicine can diagnose the condition. You will be referred to a Gastroenterologist.

Question: Is Hepatitis C infection curable?
Answer: The infection is considered â€œcuredâ€� if a test called sustained viral response (SVR) measures the absence of detectable RNA of the virus in blood serum for at least 24 weeks after discontinuing treatment. Data suggests that the virus does not recur.

Question: Can I spread the hepatitis C infection without having symptoms?
Answer: Yes, it is possible as symptoms are usually not detected sometimes for years.

Question: How is it possible to have hepatitis C infection and not know it?
Answer: It is possible because the patient does not look or feel sick even with the infection.

Question: Is it dangerous to visit someone with hepatitis C?
Answer: No, it is not. Casual contact like talking, hugging, kissing, holding hands, and shaking hands do not result in spread of the disease.

Question: Can women with hepatitis C breastfeed their babies?
Answer: There is no evidence that breastfeeding spreads HCV. Hence breastfeeding is safe. However, if the mother has a co-infection with HIV, i.e. she has both HIV and HCV infection, she should abstain from breastfeeding since the chances of spreading HCV to her child are more.

Question: Is it safe to drink alcohol if I have hepatitis C?
Answer: No. It has been found that alcohol promotes the proliferation of hepatitis C virus in human liver cells.

Question: Can I take my usual medications if I have hepatitis C?
Answer: Consult with your doctor before taking any drug. Many of the drugs, especially the â€˜hepatotoxicâ€™ ones (those that damage the liver) are unsafe in a setting of hepatitis C.

Question: Can the normal liver enzyme results be normal and the patient still have the infection?
Answer: Yes. Many patients with the infection have normal liver enzyme levels.

Question: What is end-stage hepatitis C?
Answer: In end-stage disease, the liver has been irreversibly scarred and has lost most or all of its functions. The infection could also cause bleeding of the gastrointestinal tract and brain and nervous system damage.

Question: How do you take care of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infected blood spills?
Answer: Even dried blood is infectious. A dilution of one part household bleach to 10 parts water has to be used to clean infected blood. Use of gloves is a must while cleaning.

Question: Can Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and HCV viruses exist together?
Answer: Yes, they can. A person can be infected with both the viruses at the same time. Co-infection is common in people (50â€“90%) who are intravenous drug users.

Question: How long is the HCV active outside the body?
Answer: HCV can survive at room temperature on environmental surfaces for up to 3 weeks.

Question: Can HCV be transmitted through insect bites?
Answer: No, it has not been proved that HCV can be transmitted through insect bites.

Question: Is it necessary to test for Hepatitis C infection while being pregnant?
Answer: No. It is not a part of routine pregnancy tests that are performed.

Question: How does a person with chronic Hepatitis C infection take care of his liver?
Answer: Avoiding alcohol and checking with the doctor before taking any prescription pills, supplements or over-the-counter medications Precautionary measures have to be taken to avoid further liver damage. It is also important to get vaccinated against the Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B viruses.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hepatomegaly?
Answer: A gastroenterologist should be consulted in case of hepatomegaly.

Question: What does it mean when both liver and spleen are enlarged?
Answer: It means that both the liver and spleen have become bigger than their normal sizes. Liver and spleen share common blood circulation via the hepatic portal system, hence many disease processes affect both organs. Malaria, kala azar, viral hepatitis, obstruction to portal and hepatic veins, cirrhosis, and blood cancer are some known causes.

Question: What is steatosis?
Answer: Steatosis is deposition of fat in the liver cells. This deposition of fats in the liver leads to an increase in liver size. This condition is reversible in the early stages. If neglected, it may lead to permanent scarring and cirrhosis.

Question: What is non alcoholic fatty liver disease [NAFLD]?
Answer: It is enlargement of the liver due to fat deposition in people who consume very less alcohol or do not drink alcohol.

Question: What is the normal size of the adult liver?
Answer: The average width of the liver is around 21 - 22.5 cms. The vertical height is estimated to be 15 - 17.5 cms. From the front to back, the liver measures 10 - 12.5 centimeters.

Question: What is the normal weight of the adult liver?
Answer: The average weight of the liver is between 1.2 - 1.6 kgs. The liver is about 1/18 of total body weight in the fetus and 1/36 of total body weight in an adult.

Question: Where is the liver located in the body?
Answer: The liver is a wedge-shaped organ situated in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It is just below the diaphragm and hidden by the rib cage. A small portion of the liver extends to the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.

Question: What causes fatty liver?
Answer: Regular intake of alcohol, obesity, diabetes, intestinal bypass surgery for obesity, starvation, protein malnutrition, drugs such as corticosteroids and tetracycline are common causes.

Question: What are the symptoms of fatty liver?
Answer: There are usually no specific symptoms in the early stages. Non specific symptoms may include tiredness, nausea, excess weight in abdominal area, an increase in liver enzymes, cholesterol and triglycerides levels.

Question: What is the meaning of hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration?
Answer: It means enlargement of the liver due to fat deposition in the liver cells. This gives the liver a glazed appearance.

Question: What can be considered excessive alcohol consumption?
Answer: More than 2 drinks per day for women and 3 drinks per day for men is considered excess alcohol consumption.One drink is equivalent to:

Question: How is fatty liver confirmed?
Does eating fatty food lead to fatty liver?
Answer: Presence of enlarged liver, high levels of liver enzymes, images of liver obtained from ultrasound and CT scan, and liver biopsy confirm fatty liver.

Question: How does excess fat get into the liver cells?
Answer: No. Eating fatty food itself does not result in fatty liver.

Question: What is the effect of diabetes on hepatomegaly?
Answer: It is probably due to an increase in fat extraction from the intestine or transfer of fats from other parts of body to the liver along with reduced breakdown of fat by liver.

Question: Which specialist treats hepatorenal syndrome?
Answer: A gastroenterologist or hepatologist along with a nephrologist treats hepatorenal syndrome.

Question: Is hepatorenal syndrome immediately fatal?
Answer: Not always. With advances in treatment of renal impairment and management of liver failure, the patient survival can be prolonged.

Question: What is the cure for hepatorenal syndrome?
Answer: At present, a successful liver transplant offers the only chance of a cure in HRS.

Question: What is the abdominal infection that increases the risk of hepatorenal syndrome?
Answer: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is an abdominal infection which increases the risk of developing hepatorenal syndrome. The infection occurs when a person has liver inflammation (cirrhosis) for a longer period of time.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hepatotoxicity?
Answer: You should consult the primary physician who will recommend the necessary diagnostic tests to determine and confirm the liver damage. You may be referred to a hepatologist.

Question: How much time does it take for symptoms of drug-induced hepatotoxicity to occur?
Answer: The onset of drug-induced hepatotoxicity ranges from a few hours to several months (between 1 and 12 months) after starting the medication. Sometimes the toxicity occurs following completion of the course.

Question: Is drug-induced hepatotoxicity fatal?
Answer: Some drugs can induce fatal hepatotoxicity especially if the hepatotoxicity has not been recognized early and steps have not been taken to resolve it.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for HER2-positive breast cancer?
Answer: You should consult an oncologist (cancer specialist).

Question: Can recurrence occur in case of HER2-positive breast cancer?
Answer: With the advent of targeted therapies using monoclonal antibodies and newer types of chemotherapeutic drugs, the chances of recurrence are low.

Question: Which lab test result is better â€“ HER2-positive or HER2-negative?
Answer: If the test result is HER2-negative, it is better as the chances of recurrence are much lower and the survival rate is higher, compared to HER2-positive breast cancer.

Question: Is HER2-positive breast cancer more serious than others?
Answer: Yes. This is because HER2-positive breast cancer tends to be much more aggressive and refractory to hormone therapy than other types of breast cancer.

Question: Is it possible to cure HER2-positive breast cancer?
Answer: Yes. Nowadays, with the availability of novel targeted therapies for HER2-positive breast cancer, it is possible to cure the patient, especially if diagnosed at an early stage.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for a herniated disc?
Answer: You should consult an orthopedic surgeon.

Question: Is a herniated disc very serious?
Answer: Herniated disc in general is not very serious as it responds well to conservative treatments like medications and exercise. However, the condition may require surgery if it does not respond to conservative therapy.

Question: Can a herniated disc heal by itself?
Answer: Usually a herniated disc can heal by itself over time. The pain may subside in due course even without treatment.

Question: Is there a chance of paralysis from a ruptured disc?
Answer: Paralysis can occur in serious cases where the herniation exerts excessive pressure on the spinal nerve.

Question: Can a herniated disc occur from a fall?
Answer: A fall can cause a herniated disc, but is extremely rare.

Question: Which doctor should you consult if your child has Herpangina?
Answer: Consult your childâ€™s pediatrician if you suspect your child has herpangina.

Question: Is herpangina contagious?
Answer: Yes. Herpangina is caused by a group of viruses that are highly contagious and can spread from person to person. Herpangina is contagious during the active stage of the infection.

Question: Is herpangina and hand-foot-and-mouth (HFM) disease the same?
Answer: Herpangina and hand-foot-and-mouth disease are caused by the virus from the same family. Both cause oral blisters and ulcers, but the location of the oral blisters differs. Herpangina lesions occur at the back of the mouth, whereas HFM occurs at the front of the mouth.

Question: Does my child get immune to herpangina if he/she suffered from it?
Answer: Herpangina can be caused by 22 different serotypes of enteroviruses. The child could get herpangina due to the different virus serotype later.

Question: How long does the problem last and when should I seek further advice?
Answer: The ulcers in the mouth usually heal in 5-10 days. Consult for further advice if the child has an uncontrollable fever, if the symptoms do not subside in a week or if the child seems dehydrated.

Question: Which specialist should I consult if I have hiatus hernia?
Answer: You should consult a general surgeon or a gastroenterologist.

Question: Is hernia gender specific?
Answer: No, both males and females are equally susceptible to get a hernia.

Question: Is heartburn a sign of heart attack?
Answer: Heartburn pain can be mistaken for a heart attack or heart disease. But, usually heartburn pain is not associated with any physical activity. While exercise can increase the pain resulting from heart disease or the onset of a heart attack and rest may temporarily relieve the pain. Chest pain from hiatus hernia and/or esophageal spasms may be extremely difficult to distinguish from chest pain of cardiac origin. The symptoms of pain spreading from below the sternum (breastbone) to the neck, jaw, and arms can mimic the symptoms of coronary artery disease. If you experience any of these symptoms, immediately seek medical care.

Question: What can I eat with a hiatal hernia?
Answer: Lean meats, lots of vegetables, low-fat dairy, whole grains and water as the only beverage can be consumed with hernia. Post-surgery, the doctor will advise you start of on a liquid diet. When progressing to a solid diet, chew well, eat moist foods and eat small meals during the day.

Question: How long does it to take to heal after surgery?

Question: Is my child still susceptible to get meningitis after he/she receives the Hib vaccine?

Question: Can the Hib vaccine cause meningitis or pneumonia?
Answer: No. Hib vaccine will not cause these diseases.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for high blood pressure?

Question: What is â€˜White Coat Hypertensionâ€™?
Answer: Having high blood pressure during pregnancy can be dangerous for both the mother and the fetus. High blood pressure can harm the motherâ€™s kidney and other organs and can lead to certain complications during pregnancy. It can decrease blood flow to the placenta, thereby reducing the oxygen supply and nutrients to the baby leading to risk of low birth weight. It can also cause early delivery due to placental abruption. In most serious cases, the mother can develop pre-eclampsia or toxemia of pregnancy, which can threaten the lives of both the mother and the fetus.

Question: What is ambulatory measurement of blood pressure?

Question:
How good is the treatment for high 
cholesterol?
Answer: A little work can make a big difference. Every 1% reduction in your cholesterol LDL or bad cholesterol level lowers your risk of heart disease by 2%. Each increase of 1 mg/dL (not percent) of your good cholesterol or HDL decreases your risk 2% to 3%.

Question: I've heard that a couple of drinks of alcohol a day will help my cholesterol. Is this true?
Answer: It is true that modest alcohol ingestion will raise the "good" (HDL) cholesterol. It appears that the equivalent of one or two ounces can raise the level by 5% to 10%. Red wine may provide some additional benefits. However, this should never be used as an excuse to start drinking. Remember that regular alcohol consumption can increase the levels of triglycerides and increase risk of heart disease, fatty liver and cirrhosis.

Question: What is the normal range of testosterone by age in females?

Question: What is androgen insensitivity syndrome?
Answer: Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a condition that affects sexual development before birth and during puberty. People with this condition are genetically male but their bodies are unable to respond to male sex hormones and they may have mostly female external sex characteristics or signs of both male and female sexual development.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Hirayama disease?

Question: How can Hirayama disease be managed?
Answer: Hirayama disease can be managed either by conservative or surgical therapy.

Question: How can students regain their ability to write if they have Hirayama disease?
Answer: Writing is an integral component of a student's life. Being afflicted by Hirayama disease can be devastating for students. Therefore, students having the disease should be advised to wear a neck collar and perform hand muscle strengthening exercises.

Question: How can Hirayama disease be prevented?

Question: Which doctor treats Hirschsprung disease?
Answer: Hirschsprung disease is treated by a pediatric surgeon or pediatric gastroenterologist.

Question: Is Hirschsprung disease hereditary?
Answer: Hirschsprung disease is associated with certain genes as well as some genetic syndromes like Down syndrome. In addition, a family history of Hirschsprung disease also increases the risk of another baby suffering from the same condition.

Question: What is enterocolitis?
Answer: Enterocolitis refers to inflammation of the colon. It may be a complication of Hirschsprung disease, or may occur following surgery for Hirschsprung disease. It is a life-threatening condition, which can cause a swollen abdomen, bleeding from the rectum, fever, diarrhea and vomiting. It may need hospitalization with resuscitation, antibiotic treatment and decompression followed by colostomy once the patient is stabilized.

Question: Can Hirschsprung disease be diagnosed during pregnancy?
Answer: An ultrasound during pregnancy may be able to detect Hirschsprung disease only if the full colon is involved.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hirsutism?

Question: How much time is required for treatment of hirsutism?

Question: Can hirsutism affect males?
Answer: Hirsutism as a medical problem is often seen in women. Though the condition can occur in men too; it is less obvious in males. However, hirsutism occurs equally in male and female pre-pubertal children.

Question: Which doctor should I consult?

Question: What is ocular histoplasmosis?
Answer: Ocular Histoplasmosis is a disease caused by the spread of Histoplasma capsulatum to the eyes. It can cause defective vision in later stages.

Question: Is histoplasmosis treatable?
Answer: Histoplasmosis is a treatable disease, but it might cause complications even if completely cured. Ocular Histoplasmosis is treatable but not curable.

Question: Can Histoplasmosis be life threatening?
Answer: Yes in severe cases and immuno-compromised this is a possibility. In the patients who are hospitalized for histoplasmosis in the U.S., a study estimated the crude mortality rate to be approximately 5% for children and 8% for adults.

Question: Which doctor should I go to if I have hives?

Question: Is hives contagious?

Question: Which doctor should I see if I experience hoarseness?

Question: When should I see the doctor if I have hoarseness?

Question: What should I do if I am in an occupation that requires my voice?

Question: Which specialist treats Hodgkins Lymphoma?

Question: Can Hodgkins lymphoma be completely cured?

Question: What should the patient do during treatment?

Question: Some of the questions a patient might wish to ask the doctor:
Which doctor should I consult to rule out homocystinuria in my child?
Answer: You should consult a child specialist or pediatrician.

Question: What is the role of homocysteine in the body?
Answer: Homocysteine is normally converted to other amino acids for use by the body. Many people with a high homocysteine level have folate (also called folic acid), vitamin B6, or vitamin B12 deficiency in their diet. Replacing these vitamins often helps restore the homocysteine levels to normal.

Question: What are the risk factors of homocystinuria?
Answer: One of the risk factors is if someone in the family has homocystinuria because the condition can be inherited. Other possible risk factors include being a native of Germany, Norway, Ireland or Qatar where the condition is common.

Question: What are the complications of homocystinuria?
Answer: Complications of high homocysteine levels include an increased risk of blood clots leading to heart attacks and stroke. Other complications include early osteoporosis or brittle bones by age 15 years, fatty liver and damage to pancreas (pancreatitis).

Question: What is the prognosis of homocystinuria?
Answer: Early diagnosis and initiation of treatment is key to preventing complications and possibly reverse some of the initial symptoms. Follow the modified diet lifelong and having periodic evaluations by specialists can help prevent complications.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Hookworm infection?
Answer: A general physician or an internist or a family physician or a gastroenterologist can help in the treatment of hookworm infection.

Question: How can hookworm infection lead to iron-deficiency anemia?
Answer: Hookworms attach themselves to the walls of the small intestine and thrive on the human blood that flows through the intestinal walls to absorb nutrition from the digested food. This leads to a reduction in Red Blood Cells and plasma apart from iron and other important nutrients. Iron-supplement is a part of the treatment program for hookworm infection.

Question: How is protein deficiency related to hookworm infection?
Answer:
Adult hookworms secrete a potent inhibitor of digestive enzymes, causing malabsorption of protein. This creates a deficiency in protein in the body.
Nutritious diet with enough protein content is recommended as a part of hookworm infection treatment.

Question: Is there a possibility of the hookworms becoming drug-resistant?
Answer: Hookworms in livestock have shown drug resistance. The human nematodes have longer reproducing times and the antihelminthic treatment is targeted towards the hookworm directly. These two are the reasons why human nematodes are less likely to develop resistance to anti worm treatment. However, the chances of re-infection are more in both animals and humans if other measures are not taken for prevention of hookworm infection and to improve the sanitation and hygiene of the community.

Question: Is there a vaccine against hookworm infection?
Answer: Vaccine for hookworm infection is in the research stage. The research targets the two stages in the development of hookworm, namely, the larvae and the adult stage. However, vaccination and periodic mass deworming can be successful only if other aspects such as poverty, sanitation and community education are improved.

Question: Which doctor should I consult to treat hormonal headaches?
Answer: You can consult your family doctor or GP for troublesome and recurrent headaches. He will prescribe medications or refer you to the appropriate specialist (neurologist, gynecologist, or internist) for further evaluation and treatment.

Question: How long do hormonal headaches usually last?
Answer: Hormonal headaches usually occur in the two days before the menstrual period and first two to three days of the period. In general they may last for two to three days and are more severe than other headaches.

Question: Can caffeine help hormonal headaches?
Answer: During hormonal headaches, the blood vessels in the brain dilate resulting in increased blood flow, causing headaches. Caffeine narrows the blood vessels and may be helpful in pain relief.

Question: Do headaches signal perimenopause?
Answer: Not in all. In some women who suddenly develop headaches around perimenopause, this may be due to fall in the female hormone levels that normally occur at this time. There are several causes for headaches and if persistent it is advisable to consult a doctor for further evaluation.

Question: Are hormonal headaches dangerous?
Answer: Hormonal headaches cause more discomfort rather than being dangerous. However, visit a doctor if your quality of life is getting affected and you are unable to do your routine activities. Although most headaches in general are harmless, seek medical attention for frequent and persistent headaches to rule out some other serious condition.

Question: Which specialist should I consult to rule out hormonal imbalances?

Question: Can saliva samples be used to measure hormone levels?

There is varying opinion among doctors as to the best method of measuring hormone levels.
Certain hormones, such as thyroid, are best tested with serum (blood) testing. However, hormones such as the adrenal hormones and steroid hormones can be assessed using salivary samples.

Question: What is bioidentical hormone replacement therapy?
Answer: Bioidentical hormone or natural hormone replacement therapy usually refers to compounds that have the same molecular and chemical structure as hormones that are naturally secreted in the body.

Question: Are bioidentical hormones safer compared to synthetic hormones?
Answer: Opinions vary. Advocates of bioidentical hormones claim they are safer and more effective but there is not enough evidence to validate these claims.

Question: Are bioidentical hormones approved for clinical use?

Question: Can hormones affect your emotions?

Fluctuating levels of female hormones estrogen and progesterone can cause mood swings, low levels of serotonin cause depression, increased levels of norepinephrine cause arousal and aggression. Endorphins are associated with happy mood and oxytocin is referred to as the love hormone to cite a few examples.

Question: Can you stop breastfeeding and start again?

However, this is not difficult to overcome. You should spend more time cuddling the baby and having more skin-to-skin contact. This should help the baby get back to breastfeeding quickly.

Question: How long will it take for the menstrual cycle to be back on track after I stop breastfeeding?
Answer: Mothers who are breastfeeding may not get their periods for up to several months. However, in most women, the ovulation and, hence, the periods return within a few months of breastfeeding. This may or may not affect the milk supply.

Question: What are some physical changes that arise after stopping breastfeeding?
Answer: Some physical changes that may arise when the mother stops breastfeeding include pain in the breasts leakage, some mild irritation, and engorged breasts. However, these can be managed easily. Some women also tend to experience mood swings as the hormone levels start changing.All the mothers would agree that breastfeeding is not just a physical process, but also leads to intense emotional bonding between the mother and her baby. So, the mother may have a dilemma on her mind when it comes to stopping breastfeeding. However, know that this is completely normal and the mother gets to decide the time when both she and the baby are comfortable and ready for a change.

Question: How do you deal with unprofessional behavior in the workplace?

Question: Why is sport important for mental health?

Question: Which specialist doctor to consult for COVID-19?

Question: What can I do to cope with the effects of COVID-19 quarantine?

Question: Which doctor should I consult for cancer pain?

Question: Does everyone with cancer have pain?

Question: Does a person taking opioids become addicted to it?

Question: What are the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on mental health?

Question: How can I take care of emotional health during the coronavirus pandemic?

Question: Is it possible to stay hopeful in difficult times?

Question: Is cutting carbs unhealthy?
Answer: To maintain proper weight you just need to limit carbohydrates not completely eliminate it. If you avoid it totally it can have adverse effect.

Question: Does eating late night lead to gaining weight?
Answer: Yes, as during day your body is active so calories are burnt and utilized but at night you are not so active hence they can pile up as fat.

Question: Which specialist doctor do I need to consult for COVID-19?

Question: Is there a link between COVID-19 and weight?

Question: Why COVID-19 is more deadly in people with obesity?

All of these symptoms tend to worsen when affected with the Coronavirus, hence increasing the chances of hospitalization and higher fatality rates.

Question: Does COVID-19 make you lose weight?

A lot of energy is lost in trying to keep breathing to stay oxygenated; this could be one of the possible causes too.

Question: Which specialist doctor to consult for diabetes?

Question: What is a normal blood sugar spike after eating?
Answer: For healthy individuals, the blood sugar levels are <140 mg/dL after eating.

Question: Is 200 mg/dL of blood sugar normal after eating?
Answer: No. 200 mg/dL is considered a high post-meal blood glucose level. Blood sugar more than or equal to 200 mg/dL post-meal is diagnostic of diabetes.

Question: How can I lower my blood sugar ASAP?
Answer: Thereâ€™s no magic ingredient to reduce glucose levels immediately. Consuming a balanced diet and being active is the key to long-term glucose control.

Question: What should blood sugar be 2 hours after eating?
Answer: For normal people, it should be <140 mg/dL, and for diabetes individuals, it should be <180 mg/dL. A level between 140 to 200 mg/dL is diagnostic of pre-diabetes.

Question: What is a normal blood sugar level immediately after eating?

Question: How long after eating does blood sugar return to normal?
Answer: Generally, after 2 hours of eating, the blood sugar returns to normal.

Question: What level of blood sugar is dangerous?

Question: When to test blood sugar after eating?

Answer: A psychiatrist can be conducted for mental disorders.

Question: How does a family dynamic affect childrenâ€™s behavior?
Answer: Family dynamics can affect how a child thinks, feels, and behaves. Children in toxic families may experience poor self-esteem, trust issues, anxiety related to being abandoned,increased risk of physical illness, higher susceptibility to addiction, and guilt.

Question: What are dysfunctional dynamics?
Answer: Dysfunctional family dynamics refer to unhealthy or problematic family relationships characterized by harmful behaviors such as manipulation and guilt-tripping, poor interactions and poor conflict management.

Question: What are examples of family dynamics?
Answer: Family dynamics refers to the interactional patterns between members. This is affected by various factors, for example, age, roles, gender, and cultural norms.

Question: How to respond to toxic family members?
Answer: Communicating clearly, taking responsibility for oneâ€™s own actions only, being mindful, and trying to see their perspective can help respond to toxic family members.

Question: How to help a child in a dysfunctional family?
Answer: A child in a dysfunctional family can be helped by a support system, child protection agencies, therapy, and school involvement.

Question: Which specialist doctor to consult for nutritional insufficiency?
Answer: A nutritionist or a registered dietitian should be consulted for nutritional insufficiency.

Question: How does HCG make you lose weight?
Answer: HCG may promote weight loss by increasing metabolism and stimulating the hypothalamus to use the stored fat for energy.

Question: How much can you lose on HCG in 40 days?
Answer: In general, women can lose about 25 to 23 pounds and men can lose about 35 to 45 pounds.

Question: Why is HCG banned?
Answer: Adverse outcomes have been reported with HCG products for weight loss. Hence, the FDA does not encourage following HCG diet.

Question: What is going to replace HCG?
Answer: A healthy, balanced diet with moderate calorie restriction and regular physical activity will always be the healthy option for weight loss.

Question: Is it possible to enhance growth hormone naturally?
Answer: Exercise, stress, hypoglycemia, and some amino acids have all been proven to enhance HGH release, whilst high glucose, free fatty acids, and other amino acids have been shown to suppress it(14✔ ✔Trusted SourceIncreased Human Growth Hormone After Oral Consumption of an Amino Acid Supplement: Results of a Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Crossover Study in Healthy SubjectsGo to source).

Question: Is it possible for me to obtain human growth hormone?
Answer: Human growth hormone is not available in tablet form. Some dietary supplements that claim to increase HGH levels come in pill form, but research shows no benefit. The Food and Drug Administration classifies HGH as a restricted drug(14✔ ✔Trusted SourceIncreased Human Growth Hormone After Oral Consumption of an Amino Acid Supplement: Results of a Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Crossover Study in Healthy SubjectsGo to source).

Question: What are the side effects of synthetic hGH?
Answer: Carpal tunnel syndrome Increased insulin resistance and/or Type 2 diabetes Swelling in your arms and legs (edema) Joint and muscle pain Enlargement of breast tissue (gynecomastia) in people assigned male at birth increased risk of certain cancers(15✔ ✔Trusted SourceCarpal tunnel syndrome and gynaecomastia during growth hormone treatment of elderly men with low circulating IGF-I concentrationsGo to source).

Question: What exactly is human growth hormone?
Answer: Human growth hormone (hGH or GH) is a protein that is created in the body and is crucial not only during childhood but also throughout maturity. The pituitary gland, also known as the "master gland," secretes various hormones that regulate the functions of other glands, including growth hormone(16✔ ✔Trusted SourcePhysiology, Pituitary HormonesGo to source).

Question: Is taking human growth hormone recommended?
Answer:
Abuse and misuse
It is also used to help those who are undergoing chemotherapy. However, abusing human growth hormone, or IGF-1, has catastrophic consequences. Long-term exposure to high levels of human growth hormone can result in irreversible acromegaly, but even low dosages can cause consequences such as heart disease and diabetes(17✔ ✔Trusted SourceAcromegalyGo to source).

Question: Which doctor should I consult for a Human Papillomavirus infection?
Answer: Depending on the location of your warts, you can consult a dermatologist, a podiatrist or someone who specializes in reproductive organs like a gynecologist or a urologist.

Question: What could be the first signs I may experience of contracting HPV virus?
Answer: You may first experience warts on your skin or in the genital areas. Warts in the genital areas are painful and you should seek medical help to get topical creams.

Question: What can I do to avoid HPV?
Answer: Delay your first sexual experience and do not go along with multiple sex partners. It is important to get vaccinated against HPV types 16 and 18 before your first sexual experience.

Question: Can HPV be cured fully?
Answer: In normal people with strong immunity, the HPV virus usually clears on its own. However in people who have a compromised immunity, it may stay on in the body and manifest as cancers. There is no cure for the HPV virus per se but its manifestations like warts and cancers can be treated.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Hunter syndrome?
Answer: Hunter syndrome is observed in infants and children and hence, a pediatrician should be consulted.

Question: Is there a cure for Hunter syndrome?
Answer: Hunter syndrome can be managed with appropriate genetic and laboratory testing. Prenatal testing provides families with the opportunity to learn the available options for treating the condition. Hunter syndrome is a genetic condition and hence, can only be managed with enzyme replacement therapy but cannot be cured.

Question: What are the risk factors of Hunter syndrome?
Answer: Being male and having a family history of an affected X-chromosome are risk factors for Hunter syndrome.

Question: What are the other names for Hunter syndrome?
What are the other diseases belonging to the mucopolysaccharidoses group?
Which doctor should I consult for Huntingtonâ€™s disease?
Answer: You should consult a neurologist for Huntingtonâ€™s disease. He may refer you to a geneticist to diagnose the condition. Further treatment may require an integrated approach of a neurologist, psychologist, physiotherapist, occupational therapist, speech therapist and others depending on the symptoms.

Question: Does the child always inherit Huntingtonâ€™s disease from the parent?
Answer: No, the child has a 50% chance of inheriting the condition. If he is lucky enough that he falls in the safer 50%, he will neither suffer from the condition nor pass it on to the next generations. There are some cases, that the child may inherit a milder form of the condition. Therefore, he may not suffer from any symptoms, but there is a chance that he can pass it on to the next generation.

Question: How long do patients with Huntington disease live?
Answer:
If the disease is present in adulthood the patients will usually live for about 15 to 20 years after signs and symptoms begin. 
However, if the disease appears at younger age it is called Juvenile Huntington disease and it progress more quickly than the adult-onset form. These affected individuals usually live 10 to 15 years after signs and symptoms appear.

Question: If I have Huntingtonâ€™s disease what are the chances that my child will get the disease?
Answer: Huntington''s disease is an inherited disease from either one or both parents. If both parents have the gene the chances are all children will have the disease but in most instances only one parent carries the HD gene and then the chance getting the disease is 50%.

Question: Is new research available that will cure Huntingtonâ€™s disease in the near future?
Answer:
Yes, there could be an eventual cure for Huntingtonâ€™s Disease. Experiments on mice are showing ways to lower the production of mutated Huntington protein. This breakthrough will not only slow the progress of the disease but also improve symptoms that have already appeared and eventually extend the patient lifespan. 
In 2013, a new ground-breaking clinical human drug trial was announced in Vancouver. The new drug has the potential to turn off the gene that causes Huntingtonâ€™s disease.

Question: Which specialist doctor treats Hydatid disease?
Answer: This depends on the location of the Hydatid disease. For lung hydatid â€“ you will need to consult a thoracic surgeon or Respiratory medicine doctor. For Liver Hydatid â€“ you will need to consult a gastro-intestinal surgeon.

Question: Can echinococcosis recur?
Answer: Yes. Hydatid disease can recur even after treatment.

Question: Is there a vaccine against echinococcosis?
Answer: There are no human vaccines against any form of echinococcosis.

Question: Can sudden death occur in Hydatid disease?
Answer: Sudden deaths have been reported in cases of AE.

Question: Who should be consulted to treat a hydrocele?
Answer: You can consult a General Surgeon or Urologist.

Question: Can a child have both Hernia and a Hydrocele?
Answer:
Yes, they can. Normally the testis develops inside the abdomen. Just before delivery of the baby, the testis comes down into the scrotum. For this to happen, there exists a connection between the abdomen and the scrotum known as the processus vaginalis. This connection usually closes off around the time of birth. In some children, it remains open. Intestines can then move into the connection and appear as a hernia.
If the opening of the processus vaginalis is very small it does not permit the intestine to come thorough. All our abdomens contain some fluid. This acts like a lubricant, allowing smooth movement of the intestines. This fluid can trickle down through this small connection and this causes a hydrocele.

Question: Do all hydroceles need surgery?
Answer: No, when hydroceles occur in children below the age of one year, there is a 70% chance that they will disappear on their own. The connection tends to close off on its own by 2 years of age and the hydrocele disappears. Only if the hydrocele persists beyond 2 years of age will surgery be required. It is safe to wait until the age of 2 years for spontaneous resolution of the hydrocele.

Question: Who Requires a Hydrocele Operation?
Answer: Any adult who has a moderate or large sized hydrocele will require a hydrocele operation procedure. If left untreated, the hydrocele will become enlarged and cause pain, discomfort, swelling, infection, or serious illness. Simply draining off the liquid using needles will result in more liquid accumulating within two months.

Question: Can a hydrocele recur after surgery?
Answer: Recurrence is very uncommon after surgery. However large hydroceles can be difficult to treat and may recur after surgery. If surgery is not successful, then sclerosing agents can be considered.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for Hyperacusis?
Answer: You should consult an ENT specialist

Question: How long does hyperacusis last?
Answer: It usually lasts approximately 8 to 12 weeks depending on the severity of the attack. Hyperacusis does not last longer than 24 weeks even if it's severe.

Question: Is there a cure for Hyperacusis?
Answer: Unfortunately, there is no known cure for hyperacusis; however, there are treatments, which can help people cope with the condition.

Question: Which doctor should you consult for hypercalcemia?
Answer: You should consult a General Physician (Internal Medicine â€“ MDs) who may further refer you to an Endocrinologist for treating hypercalcemia.

Question: When should one consult a doctor?
Answer: One must contact a doctor if one develops any signs and symptoms that may indicate hypercalcemia or calcium excess â€“ such as being extremely thirsty, urinating frequently and having abdominal pain; also when one has a family history of hypercalcemia or hyperparathyroidism with similar complaints.

Question: Do corticosteroids cause hypercalcemia?
Answer: No, steroids in fact may be useful in countering hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity.

Question: What diseases can develop from a tumor in the parathyroid gland?
Answer: A tumor in the parathyroids can be benign leading to parathyroid adenoma. It can be premalignant-like generalized hyperplasia, or malignant like multiple endocrine neoplasia type1 or 2 (MEN1/2). The malignant form means cancerous and more severe.

Question: When should I take calcium supplements?
Answer: The calcium required daily allowance (RDA) is about 1 g/day in adults and non-lactating women. If you are not fulfilling this daily requirement in your diet you need calcium supplements.

Question: Can you have too much calcium?
Answer: Yes, one can have excess of calcium supplements which can lead to hypercalcemia; hence one must take supplements only after consulting a qualified dietitian or a physician.

Question: How does hypercalcemia cause peptic ulcer?
Answer: Hypercalcemia can cause peptic ulcer due to the stimulation of enzyme gastrin which in turn irritates the stomach by causing the release of hydrochloric acid.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for excessive sweating?
Answer: A primary care physician or a dermatologist can assist in making the preliminary diagnosis. If the condition requires invasive treatment such as surgery, the individual will be referred to a surgeon.

Question: What is Freyâ€™s syndrome?
Answer: Freyâ€™s syndrome is a form of gustatory hyperhidrosis that occurs when hot or spicy foods are consumed. It occurs when the facial nerves are damaged with lesions in the salivary gland. The syndrome may also occur as a result of a tumor operation, or diabetes, or due to hereditary genetics.

Question: What is Harlequin syndrome?
Answer: Harlequin syndrome is another form of focal hyperhidrosis that results from damage to the sympathetic nervous system.

Question: What are the subjective tools to determine the severity of excessive sweating?
Answer: The Visual Analog Scale (VAS), the Hyperhidrosis Disease Severity Scale (HDSS), and the Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) are some of the tools to determine the severity of hyperhidrosis. The HDSS scale ranges from 1 to 4 with 4 being the best score in the reduction of hyperhidrosis after therapy.

Question: What are the complications of hyperkalemia?
Answer: Hyperkalemia can cause arrhythmia and sudden death, so it should be treated quickly in patients with abnormal ECG.

Question: What are the sources of potassium?
Answer: Fruits, vegetables and whole grains are rich sources of potassium.

Question: What is pseudo hyperkalemia?
Answer: It is a falsely elevated level of potassium in the blood sample when the patient is asymptomatic. It occurs in cases where injury to the red blood cells causes an elevated level of potassium in the collected blood.

Question: Which specialist doctor should I see if I have hypermobility syndrome?
Answer: You may initially consult a general physician who may refer you to a specialist dealing with bones (orthopedic), if hypermobility is suspected.

Question: Can the condition be inherited?
Answer: There is a tendency of hypermobility to run in families, as certain genes that predisposes a person to the development of hypermobile joints are inherited.

Question: If I have the condition will my children get it?
Answer: If you have hypermobility syndrome the chances of your children getting it are higher than that for a child whose parents are normal.

Question: Which specialist should I consult for symptoms of hyperparathyroidism?
Answer: You may see the family physician, who may refer you to an endocrinologist for further tests and work-up. If surgery is necessary, consulting a surgeon experienced in performing parathyroid surgery is required.

Question: Are all parathyroid growths malignant?
Answer:
Most parathyroid tumors are either adenomas or glands that have undergone hyperplasia. These are benign, but can be overactive and cause symptoms of hyperparathyroidism. They remain localized and surgical excision may be curative.
Rarely, the parathyroid growth may be cancerous. Cancers are responsible for less than 1% of hyperparathyroidism.

Question: What is done in parathyroid surgery?
Answer:
Parathyroidectomy is the removal of one or more of parathyroid glands surgically. Success rates are high if done by an experienced surgeon. The surgery is done as a minimally invasive radio-guided parathyroid procedure (MIRP), or by using an endoscope, if only one gland has to be removed. The patient will be discharged on the same day.
If more than one gland has to be removed, the procedure takes longer and the hospital stay might be longer, with patient needing to stay overnight.

Question: Is parathyroid surgery safe?
Answer: Parathyroid surgery is usually a safe and effective procedure. Complications, though rare, are seen more often in traditional operations compared to MIRP or endoscopic surgery. There is a minimal chance that the nerves supplying the vocal cord will be damaged during the surgery, resulting in hoarseness of voice. It is also likely that calcium and vitamin D supplements need to be taken for many years following surgery.

Question: When will I be able to resume normal activities following surgery?
Answer: Many patients return to their work the week following surgery. Patients who have physically demanding jobs should take more time off from work. Heavy weights should not be lifted for at least 3 weeks after surgery.

Question: Is parathyroid surgery done as an emergency?
Answer: No. It can be scheduled at a convenient time and date. Very rarely, when calcium levels are very high, immediate surgery may be needed.

Question: Will the incision scar be long and unsightly?
Answer: The length of the incision is usually 1 to 2 inches long. However, the precise length and location of the incision may vary according to the procedure.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hyperprolactinemia?
Answer: A gynecologist should be consulted if you are suffering from hyperprolactinemia.

Question: Can a woman get pregnant with high Prolactin levels?
Answer: High Prolactin levels can interfere with ovulation, thereby causing hormonal imbalance and irregular periods, which decrease the chances of getting pregnant.

Question: Can stress cause high levels of Prolactin?
Answer: High levels of stress can cause increased Prolactin levels.

Question: Can a Prolactinoma cause weight gain?
Answer: A Prolactinoma may cause irregular menstrual periods or complete loss of menses which may lead to weight gain.

Question: What is the normal range of Prolactin?
Answer: The normal range for Prolactin in your blood is less than 20 nanograms per milliliter, 2 to 18 nanograms per milliliter for men, 2 to 29 nanograms per milliliter for nonpregnant women and 10 to 209 nanograms per milliliter for pregnant women.

Question: Whom do I consult if I have a family history of HCM?
Answer: Consult your general physician, he does your preliminary screening and when necessary he may refer you to the cardiologist

Question: Is it necessary to see my family physician before joining sports, even if I donâ€™t have a family history of HCM?

Question: Which doctor should be consulted for hyperventilation problem?
Answer: Your GP can do the initial exam. If he finds anything serious he may refer you to a specialist.

Question: What are panic attacks?
Answer:
If some emotional stress or fear precipitates overâ€”breathing it is due to panic. There may be fear of heights (like standing and looking down from a tall building) or the fear of crowds or snakes or death.
Sometimes hyperventilation and panic can become a vicious combination, where panic leads to hyperventilation and further panic.

Question: Is hyperventilation dangerous?
Answer: No, this condition is not dangerous and it is usually self-limiting. The symptoms usually last for about 15 to 30 minutes.

Question: Is hyperventilation common during labor of pregnancy?
Answer: Yes especially if the woman is delivering for the first time the rapid deep breathing to push the baby down can cause hyperventilation and she may blackout for a short period.

Question: Whom do I consult for hyperventilation?
Answer: Consult an emergency room, when you experience the episode of hyperventilation for the first time.

Question: Will hypnotherapy work always?
Answer: Hypnotherapy will not work if the patient is doubtful about it, if the patient does not want it or if the patient is not focused about its healing properties.

Question: Is hypnosis a type of sleep?
Answer: Hypnosis is not a type of sleep. Rather hypnosis is a state of awareness and increased concentration.

Question: Is the patient under the control of the therapist during hypnotherapy?
Answer: Contrary to popular belief the patient is not under the control of the hypnotherapist.

Question: Does the patient lose control over himself during hypnotherapy?
Answer: The patient does not lose any control during hypnotherapy. In fact, hypnotherapy enhances the patientâ€™s control over himself. He cannot do anything that he does not want to during hypnotherapy. The patient can choose either to explore his subconscious mind, the visual images and the sensations or he can decide to open his eyes and return to his present environment.

Question: How can a patient put himself in deep sleep?
Answer:
This can be achieved through self-hypnosis. An example is given below. 
Sleep happens when focus is switched from external environment to internal reality. As the patient is falling asleep and crossing over from wakefulness to sleep, the mind generates images. So if the patient has difficulty in sleeping, he has to purposefully generate mental images of something pleasant or boring, for e.g. counting sheep is a classic example of self-hypnosis, he can also think about pleasant things like a day on the beach/garden, etc. The patient should avoid worrying thoughts as it will produce stress hormones and these will keep him awake.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hypochloremia?
Answer: If you experience any of the above symptoms that can lead to low chloride levels, you can consult your primary healthcare provider or in cases of severe dehydration visit your nearby hospital. Further, depending on the underlying disease condition, you may be referred to a nephrologist, endocrinologist, gastrologist, or cardiologist.

Question: What is the reason of low chloride in blood?
Answer: Serum chloride level drops due to loss of body fluids caused by prolonged vomiting and diarrhea, intake of diuretics and nasogastric suction. Your kidney controls blood chloride levels. In cases of chronic kidney problems, chloride imbalances are seen.

Question: How do you add chloride to your diet?
Answer:
The Food and Nutrition Board at the Institute of Medicine recommends 2.3 g daily intake of chloride in adolescents and adults aged 14 to 50 years. Requirements vary based on age, sex, and other factors.
Chloride is present in most of our foods and people probably consume more than necessary in the form of table salt. It is also found in many vegetables and foods such as salted meats, tomatoes, lettuce, celery, olives, and butter. In addition to this, also remember that consuming large amounts of baking soda or substantially more amount than the recommended dosage of antacids can cause low blood chloride.

Question: Why does hypochloremia cause metabolic alkalosis?
Answer:
Metabolic alkalosis is a condition in which the pH of the tissue is elevated beyond the normal limit.
Prolonged vomiting, secretory diarrhea or nasogastric suctioning results in the loss of gastrointestinal chloride (hydrochloric acid) and metabolic alkalosis may develop as a result of gastrointestinal chloride loss. In such cases, extracellular volume is usually contracted, hypochloremia develops, and the urinary chloride level is usually less than 20 mEq/L.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hypoglycemia?
Answer: If you suspect hypoglycemia (sweating and feeling faint) Blood glucose should immediately be measured with glucometer and you should  take sugar or glucose, whichever is at hand. You should also visit your primary care physician or your diabetologist for adjustment of the dosage of your anti-diabetes medication.

Question: I take metformin and have been told that it does not cause hypoglycemia. Is it true?
Answer: Though insulin and anti-diabetes medications are listed as the principle causes of hypoglycemia, not all anti-diabetes drugs cause hypoglycemia. Some drugs like sulfonylureas (for example, glyburide and glimepiride), repaglinide and nateglinide act by releasing insulin in the body, and thereby can cause hypoglycemia. Drugs like metformin, pioglitazone and acarbose do not release insulin. These drugs do not cause hypoglycemia when used alone. For more information on anti-diabetes drugs, please refer to http://www.medindia.net/patients/patientinfo/diabetes-oral-hypoglycemic-agents-and-glycemic-control.htm

Question: Is hypoglycemia fatal?
Answer: Since the brain requires a constant supply of glucose, severe hypoglycemia can result in coma and can even be fatal if adequate steps are not taken immediately to restore the blood glucose level.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for hypogonadism?
Answer: An endocrinologist should be consulted for hypogonadism

Question: What is the normal level of testosterone for a healthy male adult?
Answer: The testosterone level should be between 300 ng/dL and 1000 ng/dL for an adult male.

Question: What are the side effects of hormone therapy?
Answer: It is important to watch out for any side effects that may arise as a result of hormone therapy and to consult a doctor immediately about altering treatment or discontinuing till it is safe to resume. Some of its side effects include weight gain, lowering of sperm count, mood swings and sleep apnea.
