Question: Which doctor should I consult for Renal Artery Stenosis?
Answer: You can visit a Nephrologist or Urologist for consultation.

Question: What are the types of renovascular diseases?
Answer: Atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis (AS-RAS), the abnormal narrowing of the renal artery caused by fat deposits in the inner lining and fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD), which is an inherited disorder caused by destruction of arterial blood vessels are the two types of diseases of the renal (kidney) arteries.

Question: What is Renal Angioplasty?
Answer: Renal angioplasty is a procedure used to widen the arteries that supply blood to your kidneys. This procedure is done when your renal arteries become very narrow.

Question: What can be expected after undergoing renal artery stenosis?
Answer: Improvement in kidney function as well as normalized blood pressure are the possible positive outcomes. Unless careful post-treatment follow up is done, the disease may occur after a period of 40 months, in patients who have undergone balloon angioplasty. Patients with atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis treated with balloon angioplasty and stent, may find difficulty to control high blood pressure or progression of kidney failure.

Question: Who performs a radionuclide scan?
Answer: A radionuclide scan is carried out by a nuclear medicine specialist trained in the procedure.

Question: Is the procedure painful?
Answer: The procedure does not cause any pain. The only pain may be felt during the injection of the radionuclide.

Question: Will my insurance cover the procedure?
Answer: This varies from country to country and also depends on your policy. Please check with the insurance provider before seeking an appointment for the scan.

Question: Can the radio-isotope radiation harm me?
Answer: No, the isotope amount injected is very small and less than the x-ray exposure you get with a chest x-ray. The radioisotope will wash out within 24 hours from your body.

Question: Will I feel the radio-isotope as it is injected?
Answer: No, the only thing you will feel is the needle insertion. There will be no feeling of the actual injection.

Question: Can I do isotope scan if I am breast-feeding?
Answer: No, both in pregnancy and breast feeding, the isotope scan should be avoided.

Question: When will I get the report of the renogram scan?
Answer: Usually, it is available the same day or the next day.

Question: Why did the doctor ask for a repeat scan, when I went for a follow-up visit?
Answer: In some condition. a repeat scan is useful to decide further course of treatment. For example, if you have had a repair of an obstructed kidney (PUJ Obstruction), the doctor may want to monitor if there is any change in the kidney function over time and will need a yearly scan for a few years. Depending on the findings, he may advice you to do nothing or have further tests or perform another surgery.

Question: What is renal osteodystrophy?
Answer: Renal osteodystrophy is a condition that affects bones and joints due to imbalance of calcium and phosphorus levels in the body.

Question: Does renal osteodystrophy affect kidney disease patients only?
Answer: Yes, renal osteodystrophy is more common in kidney disease patients especially those who are on dialysis for a long time. In children, this condition might present without any signs of kidney disease, but an underlying kidney disease is present.

Question: Why does imbalance between calcium and phosphorus levels arise?
Answer: An imbalance in calcium and phosphorus levels in renal dystrophy happens due to inefficiency of the kidney to convert vitamin D into calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D. This leads to increased bone turnover, low calcium levels and increased phosphorus levels. This in turn stimulates the parathyroid gland for secreting more parathyroid hormone. Phosphorus levels also increase because of the inability of the kidneys to excrete excess phosphorus.

Question: How is renal osteodystrophy diagnosed?
Answer: Renal Osteodystrophy is diagnosed with the estimation of serum calcium, phosphorus levels, parathyroid hormone and calcitriol levels. A bone biopsy is done to determine the density of bones.

Question: How is renal osteodystrophy treated?
Answer: Renal osteodystrophy is treated with diet modification, dialysis and drug therapy. Measures to control parathyroid hormone levels and maintain optimal phosphorus levels along with supplementation of calcitriol are the mainstay of treatment.

Question: Which doctor treats renal tuberculosis?
Answer: Renal tuberculosis is treated by a nephrologist in association with specialists trained in the treatment of tuberculosis.

Question: Is renal tuberculosis difficult to treat?
Answer: Once the diagnosis of renal tuberculosis is made, it may be easier to treat than lung tuberculosis since the number of bacteria may be less, the anti-TB medications penetrate the kidney lesions better, and high concentration of the drugs is achieved in the urine. However, the main problem in renal tuberculosis is the difficulty in diagnosing the condition.

Question: Which specialist doctor should be consulted for this condition?
Answer: You should consult a Nephrologist or Urologist.

Question: What is Fanconiâ€™s syndrome?
Answer: Fanconiâ€™s syndrome is a genetic condition that affects the entire tubule. The patient loses a large amount of bicarbonates, proteins, electrolytes, amino acids and glucose through the urine. The affected child is prone to developing rickets.

Question: What is rickets and osteomalacia?
Answer: Rickets and osteomalacia are conditions where the bone becomes soft due to lack of calcium and Vitamin D. The condition is called rickets when it affects children and osteomalacia when it affects adults.

Question: What are adrenal glands?
Answer: The adrenal glands are small glands located on the top of each kidney. They consist of an outer zone or cortex and an inner zone or medulla. The cortex secretes hormones like glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) and angiotensin. The medulla secretes adrenaline.

Question: Which doctors treat acute (or adult) respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)?
Answer: ARDS is a critical condition that is treated in an intensive care unit under doctors trained in critical care as well as pulmonologists. A neonatologist or a pediatrician treats ARDS in children.

Question: Is treatment with surfactant useful in ARDS?
Answer: Surfactant treatment has been useful in Respiratory Distress Syndrome of the Newborn. However, its usefulness in ARDS has not been established.

Question: Can corticosteroids be used in ARDS?
Answer: Corticosteroids have not been found to be useful in ARDS and have resulted in complications in some cases.

Question: Is putting the patient in prone position during ventilation useful?
Answer: Putting the patient in prone or face down position may help to improve the delivery of oxygen during ventilation. However, studies have failed to prove that it improves the survival in these patients.

Question: Which specialist doctor to consult for heart diseases?
Answer: Cardiologists are the doctors specializing in diagnosing and treating blood vessels and several cardiovascular diseases. A visit to a cardiologist would mainly assess and help learn about the  risk factors pertaining to a heart disease. A cardiologist also finds out what measures  can be taken for better heart health.

Question: What is a good resting heart rate by age?
Answer: Normal heart rates at rest:

Question: What is a bad resting heart rate?
What should a walking heart rate be?
Answer: Visiting the doctor is a must if the heart rate is consistently above 100 beats per minute or below 60 beats per minute (and a person is not an athlete).

Question: How do you calm a racing heart?
Answer:
One way to determine walking fast enough is to measure the heart rate.
A safe target for the heart rate while exercising, for most adults, happens to be 50 to 85 percent of the maximum heart rate.

Question: Why should I have my resting metabolic rate tested?
Answer: Metabolic rate varies as per age, height, weight, and body composition. If your metabolic rate is lower than average, you may gain weight. Conversely, if your metabolic rate is higher than normal, you need not to worry about weight loss.Knowing about your metabolic rate alarms you when to start taking care of your diet and daily routine very seriously.

Question: What can I do to increase my metabolic rate?
Answer: Adequate sleep, decreased stress, small meals at fixed intervals, adequate water intake, and regular exercise also can help increase your metabolic rate.

Question: What is the difference between basal metabolic rate and resting metabolic rate?
Answer: BMR stands for basal metabolic rate; rate at which you burn calories while your body is at rest( while sleeping ). RMR is the amount of calories you burn if you rested all 24 hours.

Question: Does metabolism change with time?
Answer: Metabolism is determined by amount of muscle and fat composition of the body, weight, age, genetics and gender. Weight loss or a change in body composition can significantly effect metabolic rate.

Question: Despite daily exercising, my resting metabolic rate has not increased. Why?
Answer: Aerobic exercise burns calories which helps in balancing the caloric intake in the body, thereby preventing weight gain.But they do not increase muscle mass in the body. Strength training, adds more muscle to body, leading to increase in resting metabolic rate.

Question: Why is my resting metabolic rate lower despite weight loss?
Answer: Metabolic rate is altered by total body mass composition. When you lose weight, there is a decrease in total body mass, leading to decreased energy consumption for maintaining body''s vital functions. This results in lower RMR. Your resting metabolic rate (RMR) decreases as you lose weight.

Question: I am suffering from viral infection. Is it OK to measure RMR now?
Answer: If you are on any kind of antibiotic medications, do not schedule your metabolic rate test. As your body is undergoing stress which would falsely elevate your actual RMR.

Question: Which specialist doctor usually treats Retinal Detachment?
Answer: Opthalmologist or an eye doctor with an interest in Retinal surgery usually treats such patients. A speciality eye hospital or a department of a teaching hospital usually has facility to treat such patients.

Question: I wear glasses of -6 Diopters both eyes. My number is stable since the last 5yrs and I am comfortable with my vision. Do I need to see an eye doctor regularly?
Answer: Yes, patients with glasses more than 6 Diopters are called high myopes. High myopes have a higher incidence of retinal detachment. Hence you need to see an eye doctor regularly, at least once a year for dilated retinal examination to look for any predisposing condition for retinal detachment or any early signs of detachment.

Question: I was recently operated for right eye retinal detachment, are there chances that I can develop a detachment in the other eye?
Answer: The chances of a retinal detachment increase in the other eye after one eye suffers the same. A regular dilated retinal examination in the other eye and timely treatment of any predisposing conditions can help prevent a detachment in the normal fellow eye.

Question: I did not gain any vision after my retinal detachment surgery.  What could be the reason?
Answer: You need to see your eye doctor. It could either be due to a long standing retinal detachment or any complication of the detachment surgery like corneal edema, secondary glaucoma or choroidal detachment.

Question: Do all diabetics have high chances of a retinal detachment? I am suffering from Grade 1 diabetic retinopathy.
Answer: No, only those with advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy have very high chances of detachment. You need to strictly control your blood sugar and visit your eye doctor regularly for a dilated retinal examination.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for ocular migraine?
Answer: If you experience any of the above symptoms, please do not delay in consulting your ophthalmologist.

Question: What is the link between ocular migraine and stroke?
Answer: A period of visual loss or darkness may also be caused by a mini-stroke, which should be ruled out in a patient with ocular migraine.

Question: Is ocular migraine possible in children?
Answer: Ocular migraine has been reported in children as young as 8 years old.

Question: What is the frequency of retinal migraine in women?
Answer: Retinal migraine is seen slightly more often in women in their childbearing stage with a frequency statistic of female: male as 1.4:1.

Question: Are the symptoms of retinal migraine persistent?
Answer: The symptoms of retinal migraine usually recur but the patient is normal between attacks. Some patients however can suffer from permanent vision loss.

Question: Which doctor should you consult for retinitis pigmentosa?
Answer: Retinitis pigmentosa can be consulted with an ophthalmologist.

Question: Is only vision affected?
Answer: No, sometimes non-vision related problems can affect a minor section of people. One example is Usher's Syndrome, in which deafness accompanies retinitis pigmentosa.

Question: Does "night-blindness" mean a person has retinitis pigmentosa?
Answer: No, night blindness also called as nyctalopia is a symptom arising in case of multiple eye disorders and not necessarily only in retinitis pigmentosa. Night blindness can occur due to vitamin A deficiency, nearsightedness, retinal detachment or cataract. But retinitis pigmentosa remains the most common cause.

Question: How quickly does retinitis pigmentosa progress?
Answer: Progression of retinitis pigmentosa varies from person to person. But usually the progression is very slow. There might be phases in which there has been no deterioration between annual checkups.

Question: Does exposure to bright light impact the eyes of those suffering from retinitis pigmentosa?
Answer: As a precaution, it is suggested that people suffering from retinitis pigmentosa should avoid very bright light.

Question: What if a person suffering from retinitis pigmentosa develops cataract?
Answer: Cataract is easily removed by a minor surgical intervention and the vision loss owing to cataract can be restored. But this does not improve the vision loss owing to retinitis pigmentosa. Only the stage of vision wherein cataract had started developing gets restored.

Question: What is Usherâ€™s syndrome?
Answer: Usher syndrome is a genetic disorder in which blindness is associated with neurosensory hearing loss. Blindness is due to retinitis pigmentosa.

Question: Which doctor should I consult to check my child for retinoblastoma?
Answer: You can consult an ophthalmologist if you wish to check your childâ€™s eyes for retinoblastoma.

Question: My child has been successfully treated for retinoblastoma in one eye. There is no other person in our family with retinoblastoma. Should my child undergo continuous surveillance?
Answer: Yes. Rarely, even with successfully treated tumors, recurrences can occur. In addition, even a person with a unilateral retinoblastoma can have what is referred to as mosacism (mixed genetic pattern), with a low risk of tumor occurring in the other eye. Hence a regular a regular clinical eye examination and ultrasound examination is recommended.

Question: Can a biopsy (cutting a piece of the tissue for pathologic examination) be done in doubtful cases of retinoblastoma?
Answer: It can be done, and is performed occasionally. However, it is generally not recommended as there is risk of spread of the tumor beyond  the eye.

Question: How is ophthalmic artery chemosurgery done?
Answer: Under general anesthesia, a small sized catheter (tube) is inserted via the femoral artery (near the groin) and under fluoroscopic observation is guided to the entrance of the ophthalmic artery, into which the chemotherapeutic drugs are injected.

Question: Should a child who has been diagnosed with retinoblastoma wear protective eyewear?
Answer: Yes. Vision in an eye following retinoblastoma is often compromised.  So the eyes should be protected from injury (which could potentially further compromise vision) when outdoors. This is especially important in children  with only one functioning eye.

Question: If the eye is removed because of retinoblastoma, can an eye transplant help regain vision?
Answer: No. During eye transplant, only the outer transparent dome of the eye called the cornea is replaced. The whole eye cannot be transplanted following surgical removal.

Question: Why are children with heritable retinoblastoma more susceptible to non-ocular cancers?
Answer: In heritable retinoblastoma, every cell in all the organs of the body has  one copy of the mutant RB1 gene. Suppression of this gene can predispose to other cancers as well. So suppression of the second allele of this gene can occur in other organs at any time in oneâ€™s life, resulting in second non-ocular cancers.

Question: My child has a unilateral retinoblastoma with a single tumor. There is no family history of retinoblastoma, and both of us parents have been examined and found to be normal. Since this is likely to be the non-heritable retinoblastoma, is genetic testing for my child necessary?
Answer: Yes. In some cases of unilateral retinoblastoma, the first "hit" occurs during early formation of the embryo, and this results in a germline mutation, making it a heritable retinoblastoma. In such a case, all the precautions for heritable retinoblastoma have to be taken.

Question: Which Doctor Should I Consult for Retrorperitoneal Fibrosis?
Answer: Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a rare inflammatory disorder and involves kidneys and ureters. For this an experienced urologist should be consulted. Other specialists may also be consulted depending on the organ affected.

Question: When Should I Contact a Medical Professional?
Answer: You need to contact your health care provider if you experience lower abdomen or flank pain and also less output of urine.

Question: What are the Risk Factors for Developing Retroperitoneal Fibrosis?
Answer: Retroperitoneal fibrosis is most common in people in the age group of 40 to 60 years. Men are twice as likely to develop this condition as compared to women.

Question: Who treats Rett Syndrome?
Answer: A pediatrician is the one who will have to be first consulted. Other experts such as gastroenterologists, cardiologists, physiotherapists and geneticists will be involved in the management of Rett syndrome patients.

Question: What are the chances of me having another child with Rett syndrome?
Answer: Most often, the condition arises as a result of sporadic mutation. The chances of a person with a Rett syndrome child having another one are less than 1%.

Question: Is Rett syndrome a degenerative disease?
Answer: Rett is not degenerative but a neuro developmental disorder. If complications and illnesses are taken care of, living up to adulthood is possible.

Question: What are the other conditions that should be ruled out?
Answer: Angelman syndrome, cerebral palsy, autism, neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis must be ruled out while diagnosing Rett syndrome.

Question: What are the activities possible for a girl with Rett syndrome?
Answer: She will need help for most daily activities. Nevertheless, she can learn some skills that will make her independent â€“ they include learning to use the toilet with assistance or feeding herself by using hand or utensils. She can learn to enjoy family and friends and can live well up to adulthood.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for rhabdomyolysis?
Answer: Rhabdomyolysis is treated by a Orthopedic Surgeon. Supportive care is provided by an intensive care physician and a nephrologist.

Question: Is there any dietary supplement to treat statin-induced rhabdomyolysis?
Answer: Supplements like coenzyme Q10, magnesium, broad spectrum carnitine and D-ribose have been used to treat statin-induced rhabdomyolysis, though their benefit has not been established.

Question: Is rhabdomyolysis usually fatal?
Answer: Rhabdomyolysis may be, fatal if not diagnosed correctly and if the causative agent is not taken care of. Among statin users fatal rhabdomyolysis is a rare event. (1 death per million prescriptions).

Question: Can lack of exercise or lack of walking cause rhabdomyolysis?
Answer: Lack of exercise might lead to weight gain and finally obesity, which is a risk factor for acute postoperative rhabdomyolysis.

Question: Which doctor treats rhabdomyosarcoma?
Answer: A team of doctors comprising of pediatric oncologist, oncologists, radiologists and surgeons treat rhabdomyosarcoma.

Question: What are the risk factors for rhabdomyosarcoma?
Answer: In the majority of the cases there is no identifiable risk factor. Sometimes, the disease can appear as part of a genetic syndrome.

Question: Will radiation be used to treat my child?
Answer: Radiation is often employed at sites where the rhabdomyosarcoma tumor is visible. When surgery cannot be used, radiation is administered to control cancer spread.

Question: How long will treatment take? How long will my child be in the hospital?
Answer:
Chemotherapy is given in cycles of 2 to 5 days every 3 weeks. The total duration of chemotherapy ranges between 12 and 45 weeks and this depends on the type and stage of the disease.
If surgery is done, the patient may take 2 weeks to recover. Radiation therapy is often given for 5 days per week and may last for up to 4 to 6 weeks.

Question: Will my other children get rhabdomysarcoma?
Answer: The chances of this happening is very rare.

Question: Which are the locations that  rhabdomyosarcoma spread to?
Answer: The tumor cells can spread to a wide variety of locations in the body such as brain, lungs, liver, breast, bones, bone marrow, lymph nodes, spleen and other sites of soft tissue.

Question: Can rhabdomyosarcoma recur?
Answer: Unfortunately, it can come back to the original site or any other site, even after treatment. Once this happens more treatment is required.

Question: What is the nature of research that is being conducted on rhabdomyosarcoma?
Answer: Scientists are analyzing the biological and genetic basis of this sarcoma. These studies hope to contribute to better ways of diagnosing and treating rhabdomyosarcoma and to prevent the recurrence of the disease.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for rheumatic heart disease?
Answer: You can consult a cardiologist or a pediatrician for rheumatic heart disease.

Question: What precautions are to be taken after surgery of RHD?
Answer: The patient should be given both benzathine penicillin as well as anticoagulants (drugs that prevent clotting) lifelong or as advised by the doctor.

Question: Which specialist should I see to treat rickets?
Answer: You should see a General Physician, Paediatrician or an Orthopaedic Surgeon if surgery is required to correct any deformities.

Question: Is Osteomalacia different from rickets?
Answer: Rickets and osteomalacia though similar in many respects are also dissimilar in a few. Rickets and osteomalacia are different manifestations of the same underlying pathologic process, depending on whether the patient is a child or an adult. Rickets is a disease of childhood, while osteomalacia (softening of bones) is of adult life. The former is present while bones are being constructed, while the latter is only found after bones are formed. The demarcation is made at the time of closure of the growth plates.

Question: How different is osteoporosis from osteomalacia?
Answer: Osteoporosis differs from osteomalacia in several aspects. Osteoporosis is a disorder in which there is little bone meaning that for the volume of bone, it contains the correct amount of calcium and phosphorus, but there is too little of it. In osteomalacia however, the amount of bone may be normal, but there is less mineral in the bone. Osteoporosis is an asymptomatic disease until there is fracture, while there are usually symptoms with osteomalacia like aching bones. The treatment for osteoporosis and osteomalacia are also different.

Question: How soon does a child show symptoms of rickets? Is there any regular screening that can be done to identify the condition?
Answer: If your child shows a tendency for bow legs or other physical deformities, you should take your child to a pediatrician for a check-up. Simple routine physical examinations are adequate enough to identify the condition at an early stage.

Question: How much exposure to sun is beneficial in preventing the disease?
Answer: In tropical countries, like India, exposure to sun is rarely a concern. In temperate countries however, exposure of the child for just 2 or 3 hours to the sun is sufficient enough.

Question: Which doctor should I consult if I have symptoms suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever?
Answer: If you have a good reason to believe that you may be coming down with Rocky Mountain spotted fever, it would be wise to consult your family physician immediately. Inform him about your suspicions and the reason for your doubts and he will be able to advise you if your concerns are unfounded or not. If the symptoms are severe or in an advanced state, you may need immediate hospitalization.

Question: Is Rocky Mountain spotted fever contagious?
Answer: The disease is infectious but it is by no means contagious. It occurs as a result of bacterial infection, but the bacterium is not passed on through human contact and you do not need to worry about picking it up from or spreading it to anyone in your family.

Question: Which doctor should you consult for rosacea?
Answer: You should consult your general practitioner first who might refer you to a dermatologist if needed. If your eyes are affected, you might also be referred to an ophthalmologist.

Question: Is rosacea contagious?
Answer: No. Rosacea is not considered contagious or infectious as it does not spread via skin contact or by sharing personal belongings.

Question: If it is not rosacea than what else could it be?
Answer: Cases of rosacea are easy to diagnose but can be mistaken with other skin conditions like:

Question: How does rosacea affect the nose?
Is rosacea hereditary?
Answer: One of the first facial areas affected severely by rosacea is the nose. It develops visible dilated small blood vessels. This makes the nose red and bumpy. This can advance into a condition called rhinophyma if left untreated. Rhinophyma results in a red enlarged nose, bulbous, and thick bumps causing disfiguring of the nose.

Question: Can a baby have rosacea?
Answer: Rosacea involves swelling of the blood vessels beneath the skin. The exact cause is unknown but genetic links have been found.

Question: What is roseola?
Answer: Although rosacea mostly affects adults, it can rarely affect children too.

Question: Are eczema and rosacea the same?
Answer: Roseola is a common viral disease affecting young children causing high fever and spotty rash. This viral disease usually resolves on its own without any treatment. It is different from the non-infectious rosacea.

Question: How can I take an injection?
Answer: An injection must be administered by a medical personnel such as a registered physician or a nurse. In some cases, it requires an aseptic condition.

Question: What is meant by bioavailability?
Answer: The portion of the administered dose of drug in unchanged form that reaches the blood circulation is called as bioavailability.

Question: What is first pass effect or first pass metabolism?
Answer: It is the process of drug metabolism by which the concentration of the drug is reduced significantly by the liver particularly after the oral administration of the drug.

Question: What are suppositories?
Answer: Suppositories are the solid dosage forms, which are small, roughly cone or cylinder in shape inserted into rectum or vagina. It melts in the body temperature and delivers its action.

Question: How tunneled central lines are used in intravenous administration?
Answer: Tunneled lines are used to get an access to a vein particularly for a long period of time which is commonly placed in the neck. The procedure is usually performed nearly for an hour under sedation.

Question: Which Doctor Should I consult for RSV?
Answer: You can consult a pediatrician for RSV in children or a general physician in case of an adult.

Question: Is RSV deadly?
Answer: RSV is deadly only in preterm infants with congenital heart disease, asthma or bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

Question: How long does it take to recover from RSV?
Answer: Most people recover from an RSV infection within one to two weeks.

Question: Can RSV cause long term problems?
Answer: Children with RSV who required hospitalization may develop long term problems such as wheezing and childhood asthma.

Question: Can babies pass RSV to adults?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Does RSV cause permanent lung damage?
Answer: Most infections settle down without complications. Lung damage may rarely occur in very young babies with weak immunity and the elderly with coexisting chronic medical conditions.

Question: Which doctors treat patellofemoral pain syndrome or runnerâ€™s knee?
Answer: Patellofemoral pain syndrome or runnerâ€™s knee is treated by an orthopedic specialist, who will refer you to a physiotherapist for muscle stretching and strengthening.

Question: What is the long-term prognosis or outcome of runnerâ€™s knee?
Answer: In most patients, recovery of runnerâ€™s knee takes place without the need for surgery. However, some cases may worsen, resulting in osteoarthritis of the knee.

Question: Is chondromalacia patellae and runnerâ€™s knee the same?
Answer: No, runnerâ€™s knee causes severe anterior knee pain and does not involve cartilage damage, whereas chondromalacia patellae results in cartilage softening making movements difficult. Both are common among athletes and runners.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for sacroiliac joint dysfunction?
Answer: You should consult an orthopedic specialist for sacroiliac joint dysfunction.

Question: What is the prognosis or outcome of ankylosing spondylitis?
Answer: The prognosis of ankylosing spondylitis varies among patients. While some patients suffer from mild episodes, others may suffer from chronic pain. Some patients may suffer from limitations of movements due to fusion of bones due to the disease.

Question: What kind of physiotherapy will help?
Answer: Gradual physical exercises assist in strengthening the muscles around the sacroiliac joint. Simple aerobic exercises will increase blood flow in the region, stimulating faster healing. Chiropractic treatment will also help relieve pain.

Question: Can I apply a hot water bag for relief?
Answer: Yes, Application of heat wrap or hot bath can help in the healing process. But heat therapy may be less effective for acute and intense pain.

Question: Will I need to take time off work?
Answer: If the pain is really terrible, then taking some time off can benefit your aching joints. Get plenty of bed-rest and gradually ease back into your daily life.

Question: Who advices about safe sex?
Answer: A general physician or an internist or a family physician.

Question: Will a condom guarantee total protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STD)?
Answer: No. No condom can give a 100% guarantee against STDs. Most health experts believe that the risk of contracting STDs will be greatly reduced if a condom is used properly.

Question: How do I choose the right kind of condoms to prevent STDs?
Answer:
Always read the label carefully. The label should say that the condoms are to prevent STDs. Certain condoms such as Novelty condoms are for sexual stimulation only. 
Use latex (rubber) condoms only. Tests have shown that latex condoms can act as a barrier against transmission of infectious disease germs. Lambskin (natural) condoms are ineffective in preventing infection.

Question: What if my partner refuses to get medically tested for STDs before we get into a sexual relationship?
Answer: Do not have sex with anyone you are not sure about. Better to be safe than sorry.

Question: If I have had casual sex with an unknown person at a wild party how will I know if I have or havenâ€™t contracted a sexually transmitted disease?
Answer: See a doctor the very next morning. Most STD germs will be dormant for even six months before the disease symptoms appear.

Question: How to avoid sagging breasts?
Answer: Sagging is a part of the aging process and so we cannot completely avoid it. However, through regular upper body exercise and good health care measures, the effects of sagging can be controlled and minimized.

Question: How to lift sagging breasts?
Answer: Many women are unsure as to what to do about sagging breasts and they invariably turn to so-called â€œmiracleâ€� creams and remedies for sagging breasts. However, these creams can do little to help, as the problem is not just skin deep. While there are ways to tackle the problem of sagging breasts, the only way to get an actual â€œliftâ€� is to opt for surgery.

Question: What is the best surgery for sagging breasts?
Answer: There is no single surgery that is considered the â€œbestâ€� as surgical requirements vary from one woman to the next. Mastopexy is the term for the plastic surgery procedure to modify the size and elevate the breasts. These surgeries can be classified into four categories based on the type of incision that the surgeon employs. The Crescent Lift and the Circumareolar Lift are not very invasive and are generally used in mild and moderate cases. The Lollipop Lift is often recommended for women with low hanging breasts while the Anchor Lift is the most invasive of all the breast lift procedures. Women with sagging breasts need to discuss all their options with their doctor or a plastic surgeon before making a decision.

Question: Which specialist doctors treats salivary gland cancer?
Answer: A general surgeon performs the surgical excision. Oncologist would deliver the chemotherapy and radiotherapist plans radiotherapy.

Question: Can complementary or alternative medicine treatments cure salivary gland cancers?
Answer: No complementary or alternative medicine treatments can cure salivary gland cancer.

Question: Do patients who undergo radiation therapy experience fatigue?
Answer: Many people do. Complementary therapies can help you. Talk to your doctor before trying out methods like acupuncture, massage therapy, etc.

Question: Which specialist should I consult if I have salmonellosis?
Answer: You can consult a General Physician.

Question: Does Salmonellosis spread from one person to another?
Answer: The bacteria may spread to other people in the household who share utensils, towels, etc., if the infected person does not wash hands properly after using the toilet.

Question: Can Salmonella cause typhoid?
Answer: Yes. Salmonella bacteria could also cause typhoid fever.

Question: What should I do to stop diarrhea?
Answer: In most cases replacing lost fluids to prevent dehydration is the only required treatment. Medicines are helpful in some cases, but they are usually not recommended for people whose diarrhea is caused from a bacterial infection as stopping the diarrhea will tend to trap the organism in the intestine, prolonging the problem.

Question: Which specialist doctor should I see if I am suffering from Sarcoidosis?
Answer: See a general physician or Chest Physician.

Question: How long will I need to take the medication?
Answer:
If the disease is mild and remitting, you may not be required to take medicines. But if the disease is more serious then the physician may treat the symptoms.
For how long you need to take medicines depends on the severity of the disease and also on your response to the illness.

Question: Will I get bed-ridden with the disease?
Answer: If you do not respond to medications the way you should, your condition may become severe and may confine you to the bed for short or long periods of time.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for sarcopenia?
Answer: A General Practitioner can be consulted initially. A physiotherapist, nutritionist and other specialist doctors can be consulted later on depending on oneâ€™s medical condition.

Question: Why do we lose muscle mass as we age?
Answer: We lose muscle mass as we age because the bodies of older people build muscle from food less efficiently than young people. Also the muscles of the older people are not able to use insulin as efficiently as younger peopleâ€™s muscles. Also, the blood flow in the leg is comparatively lesser in the older people due to which the supply rate of nutrients and hormones is lower. This further contributes to muscle mass loss.

Question: Why do we gain weight as we age?
Answer: The bodyâ€™s metabolic rate decreases about 1% per year starting around 30 years of age. Physical inactivity, stress and decrease in hormonal levels as we age lead to weight gain.

Question: What is high protein diet?
Answer: Researchers define a high-protein diet as one where at least 20% of the calories consumed come from protein.

Question: Is high protein diet harmful in old age?
Answer: In those aged 65 years and above, high protein intake was linked to a 60% reduced risk of dying from cancer and a 28% reduced risk of dying from disease. However, plant-based protein diet is preferable to animal based protein. In those aged 50 to 60 years high animal based protein diet has been linked to cancer and diabetes.

Question: Which doctor should I visit in case I suffer from itching of the scalp?
Answer: You should visit a skin specialist or a dermatologist in case you suffer from itching of the scalp.

Question: How can lice infestation be treated?
Answer: Lice infestation is treated using medications that contain pyrethrins or permethrins. Recently, a medication containing ivermectin has also been approved by the FDA for the treatment of lice. The patientâ€™s clothes and bed linen should be washed with hot water. Combs and hair brushes should be well cleaned. The furniture of the house should also be vacuumed to remove any lice around the house.

Question: How can I know if I am suffering from a fungal infection of the scalp?
Answer: Your doctor will usually be able to diagnose a fungal infection of the scalp on examining the scalp. He may scrape out a few flakes and examine them under a microscope or a magnifying glass. In some cases, if the diagnosis is doubtful, he may take a biopsy of the lesion.

Question: Which doctor treats scalp psoriasis?
Answer: Scalp psoriasis is treated by a dermatologist.

Question: Is scalp psoriasis contagious?
Answer: No, scalp psoriasis is usually hereditary and is precipitated by external conditions.

Question: Will the hair loss on the psoriatic patch be permanent?
Answer: No. Hair usually grows back on the psoriatic patch once it is treated.

Question: What is unique about scaphoid fracture?
Answer: Most of the time the patient feels that only a sprain has taken place. Besides, deformity is uncommon in these fractures.

Question: When should cast be avoided in treating fractures?
Answer: When a bone is displaced it is important to do a surgery. Placing in a cast will not bring in the necessary healing and is likely to cause deformity and pain.

Question: What happens if a scaphoid fracture does not heal?
Answer: In this case, traumatic arthritis sets in and the bone becomes stiff and there is pain.

Question: When can I continue my usual activities after surgery?
Answer: Once the X-ray or scanning tests confirm complete healing you may continue sporting or heavy activities after three months.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for schistosomiasis?
Answer: Patients affected with schistosomiasis may consult their family physician who will recommend the necessary diagnostic tests to identify the condition and depending on the organ affected may refer to a urologist for bladder problem or gastroenterologist for intestinal problem.

Question: What are the other names for schistosomiasis?
Answer: The other names for schistosomiasis are snail fever and bilharzia.

Question: Which are the countries where schistosomiasis has been successfully controlled?
Answer: Saudi Arabia, China, Brazil, Egypt, Cambodia and Mauritius are some of the countries where schistosomiasis has been successfully controlled.

Question: Which other disease conditions are observed in schistosomiasis-infected individuals?
Answer: Schistosomiasis-infected individuals are susceptible to tuberculosis, acquired-immunodeficiency virus infections, and malaria.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for schizoaffective disorder?
Answer: You should consult a psychiatrist or a psychologist in case of schizoaffective disorder.

Question: What is it like to live with schizoaffective disorder?
Answer: Being schizoaffective means having manic depression and schizophrenia at the same time. It is incredibly difficult to live with such symptoms. A person having paranoia, intrusive thoughts and delusions can face difficult daily battles at times.

Question: Can schizoaffective disorder go away?
Answer: This illness is difficult to diagnose accurately; so, if the correct diagnosis is done on time it can go away. If the person experiences any kind of delusions or hallucinations that go away in less than two weeks when the mood is "normal," it is bipolar disorder. And if someone experiences psychosis for 3 to 4 weeks while in a manic phase, then it is not a schizoaffective disorder.

Question: Is schizoaffective disorder a disability?
Answer: It is a serious mental disorder and if the symptoms qualify for SSD (Social Security Disability) or SSA (Social Security Administration) benefits as per medical records, only then will it be considered a disability for the person.

Question: Can you get disability benefits if you have schizophrenia?
Answer: Yes, you can get disability benefits if you have schizophrenia, but a simple diagnosis of schizophrenia is not enough to get disability benefits. If an individual suffering from schizophrenia is unable to work properly despite taking anti-psychotic medication and if he or she is able to prove it, then he can get disability benefits.

Question: Is it possible to prevent schizoaffective disorder?
Answer: Once schizoaffective disorder has occurred, prevention of future conditions can be achieved if the person receives consistent treatment, including medication and psychotherapy.

Question: Which Doctor Should I Consult for Sciatica?
Answer: For treatment of sciatica, orthopedic doctors qualified by education, training and experience should be consulted.

Question: Which Individuals are more Commonly Affected by Sciatica?
Answer: Sciatica is common in middle-aged people between 40 and 50 years of age. It occurs more commonly in men than women.

Question: What is the Outcome of Sciatica?
Answer: Recovery from sciatica usually takes place in around six weeks. Surgery may be required in around 10% to 20% cases.

Question: What are the Risk Factors for Developing Sciatica?
Answer: Risk factors which predispose to developing sciatica are middle age, obesity, occupation which involves lifting heavy weights, prolonged/continuous sitting and diabetes

Question: If I suspect symptoms of scleroderma which doctor should I go to?
Answer: Your GP may want to refer your case to a Dermatologist or skin specialist who may take the help of a Rheumatologist (a doctor who treats diseases like arthritis), Internal medicine expert, Nephrologist, Cardiologist, GI specialist, and a Dentist depending on the symptoms.

Question: Is scleroderma likely to affect my life?
Answer: Yes, scleroderma will affect the patientâ€™s ability to go about their day-to-day activities, how they feel about themselves and the way they look. It could come in the way of relationships, impair the ability to have babies and change life altogether.

Question: How can the patient help?
Answer:
The patient must learn and understand more about the disease, extend full co-operation and should follow the doctorâ€™s advice implicitly. He must never fail to take his prescribed medications and must be quick to report problems. Learning coping skills, in order to do daily tasks, can be of immense help.
It would also help to join a support group to tide over the shock and depression that is likely to follow a diagnosis.

Question: Can I get married if I have scleroderma?
Answer:
Scleroderma can affect the way you look, and feel about yourself, forever.
It can affect your relationship with your spouse and interfere with your sex life. Although there are indications of genetic factors being involved it is not clear if the disease will be transferred from parent to offspring.
It would be wise to keep the overall picture in mind before embarking on marriage.

Question: Which doctors treat sclerosing cholangitis?
Answer: Specialists like medical and surgical gastroenterologists or Hepatologists treat Sclerosing Cholangitis.

Question: What is cholangitis?
Answer: Cholangitis refers to inflammation of the bile ducts. This is mostly caused by bacteria because of blockage of the bile duct. It can spread to the liver.

Question: Is the patient completely cured after liver transplantation?
Answer: Liver transplantation increases the chances of survival in a patient with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis. However, the patient may develop Sclerosing Cholangitis in the transplanted liver after sometime. In addition, the patient may suffer from complications of liver transplantation like infection and rejection.

Question: What is recurrent cholangitis?
Answer: This is caused by frequent bouts of bacterial cholangitis due to gallstones in the bile ducts. It is seen in Hong Kong and other South east Asian countries.

Question: What are the symptoms of a â€˜cholangitis attackâ€™?
Answer: â€˜Cholangitis attackâ€™ is caused by bacteria and occurs suddenly. It is just a flare up when you have primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and does not indicate that the disease is progressing. Flu like symptoms and dark urine are observed.

Question: What is the survival rate for a person with PSC after he has undergone a liver transplant?
Answer: The survival rate is 60% which is a good reason for a person with PSC to undergo this surgery.

Question: Which doctor should I consult for scoliosis?
Answer: A family physician could be consulted initially. A referral may be made to an orthopedic doctor if required.

Question: Can you correct scoliosis without surgery?
Answer: Surgery is performed when the spine curve continues to progress despite bracing and the curve progresses past 40 or 50 degrees. In milder cases observation and non-surgical methods are advisable.

Question: Can scoliosis cause pain?
Answer: Scoliosis patients may experience pain when spinal curvature has worsened over the years causing, narrowing of the spinal canal which can lead to compression of the spinal cord and nerve roots. Symptoms of nerve compression may include radiating pain, numbness, weakness and tingling in the lower extremities. Also, adults who develop lower back curvatures due to degeneration may experience localized lower back pain.

Question: Can heavy backpacks cause scoliosis?
Answer: No. but it may cause pain in the back, neck or shoulder.

Question: What are spinal deformities?
Answer: Deformity of spine is any abnormality of the formation, alignment, or shape of the vertebral column. Examples include scoliosis or side-to-side curvature, kyphosis or hunchback.

Question: How early should children be screened for scoliosis?
Answer: The Scoliosis Research Society recommends that girls be screened twice, at 10 and 12 years of age and boys once at 12 or 13 years of age.

Question: Can scoliosis curves get better by themselves?
Answer: Curves in children who are almost full-grown may stop getting worse. If a child's spine is still growing, it is likely that the curves will worsen. Also, curves in the upper back have a tendency for progression. The larger the curve at diagnosis, the more likely it will worsen. Curves in girls tend to be larger than boys with higher chances of progression.

Question: Can exercise help?
Answer: Exercises have not been shown to prevent scoliosis from getting worse. But it is important to exercise to keep bones strong and remain physically fit.

Question: Does scoliosis run in families?
Answer: Yes, approximately 30% of Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis patients have a family history of scoliosis. About 1 in 3 children whose parents have scoliosis develop scoliosis.

Question: Is it possible to prevent scoliosis?
Answer: As in almost 80% of scoliosis cases the causes are not known there is no way as yet to prevent the problem. However, it is speculated that certain exercises that twist the spine such as gymnastics, pilates, yoga, or carrying weight on one side of the body may potentially worsen scoliosis.

Question: Which doctor should I visit to get a clinical breast examination done?
Answer: You should visit your general physician or gynecologist for a clinical breast examination. If there is any abnormality detected, you may be referred to a general surgeon/cancer surgeon for further workup and treatment.

Question: Which is better â€“ breast self-examination or clinical breast examination?
Answer: Current evidence does not indicate that breast self examination reduces the number of deaths due to breast cancer. Clinical breast examination has a sensitivity i.e. ability to detect breast cancer of 40% to 69%, whereas the sensitivity for breast self examination ranges from 12% to 41%, which is much lower. Thus clinical breast examination is better, though breast self examination can be done in the comfort of oneâ€™s home.

Question: Which is the best screening test for breast cancer?
Answer: Mammogram done between the ages of 50 and 79 years of age has been shown to reduce deaths caused due to breast cancer. If mammography is done as recommended, clinical breast examinations may not show any additional benefit in diagnosing breast cancer. However, in places like India where mammography is not feasible or widely available, clinical breast examination continues to play an important role in the detection of breast cancer. A complete clinical breast examination with the health care professional spending adequate time in examination helps in screening for breast cancer in these situations. It is also useful in younger women, in whom mammography may not be of much use.

Question: Which specialist doctor conducts screening for HIV/AIDS Test?
Answer: Any general physician or an Infectious disease doctor can conduct a screening test for HIV/AIDS.

Question: What is window period?
Answer:
â€˜Window Periodâ€™ describes the period of time between HIV infection and the production of antibodies. Antibody tests give â€˜false negativeâ€™ results during window period. Antibody tests are hence recommended three months after potential exposure to HIV infection so as to avoid false negative results.
If the test remains negative even after 3 months, then the person may not be infected with HIV. It is important to know that a person can transmit virus to others during the window period. In very rare cases, it can take up to 6 months to develop antibodies to HIV.

Question: What if my HIV test is positive?
Answer: Testing positive for HIV is a life-changing event. Seek medical attention as soon as possible.

Question: Are home self-tests available?
Answer: Rapid HIV tests are available as already mentioned.

Question: Are there urine tests?
Answer: Yes just like blood tests and oral fluid tests, urine tests are available. Accuracy is low.

Question: If I test HIV negative, does that mean that my sex partner is HIV negative also?
Answer: HIV test reveals only your HIV status. Hence a negative result doesnâ€™t mean that your partner is HIV negative.

Question: Is HIV testing important during pregnancy?
Answer: Yes. It is vital since timely antiviral therapy can prevent infections. It can also prevent vertical transmission of infection from mother to child.

Question: When should I get tested for HIV?
